subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Abetz, at the request of Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:

That the following bills be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the National Health Act 1953, and for related purposes; a bill for an act to amend the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988, and for related purposes; and a bill for an act to amend the law relating to therapeutic goods, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Abetz) agreed to:

Bills read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I table the explanatory memoranda relating to the bills and I move:

speech.para: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—
NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1999

This bill gives effect to a budget decision last year to address the problem of medication, subsidised under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS), being taken or sent overseas either for sale or for use by persons not eligible to receive medication subsidised by the Australian taxpayer.

The bill prohibits the export of medications unless the medications are not prescription drugs; or they are prescription drugs but no Commonwealth benefit has been paid; or they are for the personal use of the person or another person accompanying the person. Based on data provided by the Australian Customs Service (ACS) and on information obtained by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC), it is estimated that medication subsidised to the value of some $20 million per annum is being exported inappropriately.

The bill provides the ACS with the power to detain medication in cases where the Customs officer forms the view that the medication is not for the personal use of the person who is either carrying or shipping the medication overseas. Medication detained by a Customs officer will be transferred to the HIC. The Customs officer has a discretion to detain only some of the medication, allowing the raveller to retain the remainder.

The HIC will be responsible for determining whether or not a Commonwealth benefit has been paid for the medication. The medication will be forfeited to the Commonwealth unless the medication is not a prescription drug; or that no Commonwealth benefit has been paid or is payable; or it is for the personal use of the person concerned.

The bill allows the Chief Executive Officer of the ACS to issue guidelines for the use of Customs officers relating to the examination of baggage, detention of medication, transfer of medication to the HIC, and copying and retaining documents provided in relation to the medication.

The bill further provides that the HIC may issue guidelines for the use of HIC officers when dealing with medication transferred from the ACS, dealing with claims for the return of medication, and dealing with the disposal of medication that has been forfeited to the Commonwealth.

Where the HIC establishes that the detained medications are prescription drugs, it must notify the exporter that an application may be made within 60 days for the return of the medication. The HIC must consider any submissions seeking the return of the medication. In order for the medication to be forfeited and destroyed, the HIC must apply to a court for an order authorising the proper destruction of the medication.

These provisions are meant to address situations where a person is attempting to carry or send large quantities of medication overseas; quantities which cannot reasonably be considered to be for personal use; where the prescription labels do not relate to the person who has possession or control of the medication; or where the prescription labels have been removed or defaced so as not to allow identification of the person to whom they were supplied.

The bill specifies a formula, for most medication allowing at least 12 months' supply, under which the possession or attempted export of a greater quantity constitutes a prima facie offence. The bill does not affect travellers who are entitled to medication subsidised under the PBS and which are for the traveller's personal use or are for the personal use of a person accompanying the traveller.

The National Health Act 1953 currently prohibits a person from disposing of a PBS medication in a manner not intended in the prescription. This includes selling or exporting the medication overseas. The bill will now allow the HIC to address the situation where the subsidised medication is in the possession of another person or is being forwarded overseas by a person for whom the medication was not prescribed.

The bill has been the subject of extensive consultation between the HIC, the ACS, the Department of Health and Aged Care, the Attorney-General's Department and the office of Director of Public Prosecutions. The work on this bill was initiated by a recommendation of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs in its report Concessions—Who benefits?

In conjunction with this legislation, the HIC will undertake action to inform potential travellers, prescribers and pharmacists of the amendments to the National Health Act 1953. The information will be advertised in professional and travel publications, on ethnic radio and in ethnic newspapers.
I now commend the bill.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (PLANNING AND LAND MANAGEMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1999

The purpose of this bill is to increase the attractiveness of the Australian Capital Territory to potential investors by removing the perceived disincentive to business and other investment brought about by the limit of land tenure to 99-year estates, as distinct from freehold title enjoyed elsewhere in Australia.

The objectives of strengthening land tenure security and allowing the ACT Legislative Assembly to extend ACT leases from 99 years to 999 years were stated in the Coalition Policy on the National Capital in both 1996 and 1998.
Section 9 of the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910 provides that no Crown lands in the Territory may be sold or disposed of for freehold estates.

The Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988 provides for land in the act to be National Land or Territory Land. National Land is land so declared by the Commonwealth Minister as land used or intended to be used by or on behalf of the Commonwealth. Land that is not National Land is Territory Land. The ACT Government manages Territory Land on behalf of the Commonwealth and may grant, dispose of, acquire, hold and administer estates in Territory Land.

The ACT Government sought an amendment to the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988 to enable it to issue leases for a maximum term of 999 years. The Chief Minister, Mrs Carnell, has cited the 99-year limit as antiquated and unduly restrictive. ACT business representatives have supported the proposed amendment. A regulation impact statement is included in the explanatory memorandum.
This bill is consistent with the Australian Capital Territory being a self-governing territory.

The proposed amendment was first introduced into the House of Representatives as the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Amendment Bill 1997 on 4 December 1997 and was passed by the House without amendment on 10 March 1998. It was introduced into the Senate on 12 March 1998.

The bill was referred to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on 12 March 1998. The committee tabled its report in April 1998 with the majority recommending that the bill be passed without amendment. The committee concluded that the bill is an appropriate form of enabling legislation allowing the ACT Legislative Assembly to enact a change of leasehold term from a maximum possible term of 99 years to 999 years.

Following its inquiries of the ACT Government as to the machinery proposed for administration of any changes to the term of ACT leasehold approved by the Commonwealth Parliament, the committee was satisfied that the passage of the bill should be supported.
Effect of the bill

The proposed amendment will increase the maximum permissible limit for the grant of new estates in Territory Land to 999 years. The bill will not provide for automatic extension of existing estates. A leaseholder seeking a term longer than 99 years will need to apply to the ACT Government for a new grant.

The ACT Government has indicated that a modest administrative charge will apply to the grant of new leases to existing leaseholders, provided no terms of the lease, other than the lease period, are changed.
The proposed amendment removes the reference to `or such longer period as is prescribed' so that no terms of estate greater than 999 years will be possible.

The Regulations currently applicable which relate to 999-year leases granted for tertiary education or church purposes prior to the introduction of Self-Government in the ACT will be unaffected by the proposed amendment.
The act is proposed to take effect upon receiving the Royal Assent.
Financial Impact

The proposed amendment will have no direct impact on Commonwealth revenue or outgoings. However, it is intended that the amendment will bring positive effects to the ACT economy by increasing the Territory's attractiveness to investors.
THERAPEUTIC GOODS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1999

This bill represents an important moment in the regulation of therapeutic goods in Australia. This bill encompasses the first component of a package of reforms designed to provide a new and appropriate framework for the regulation and management of complementary medicines. This bill also makes a number of more general amendments to improve the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989.

It is estimated that over 60 percent of Australians use complementary health care products at least once a year. These include vitamins, minerals, herbal, naturopathic and/or homoeopathic preparations with therapeutic properties.

There are now around 17,000 such products on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods and an estimated 6,000 complementary medicine practitioners (not including massage therapists) operating in Australia.

In December last year I announced the formation of a Working Party, bringing together industry representatives, consumers and Government, to develop reforms in the regulation of complementary medicines. Along with many of my colleagues on both sides of the Senate, I considered this extremely important given the growing use and acceptance of complementary health care products in this country and throughout the world.

Both government and industry have been struggling to balance the need to improve market access with the need to uphold consumer confidence. Reviewing advertising regulations, substantiation of therapeutic claims and post market vigilance are critical issues to government, industry and consumers alike. It is also essential to secure the ongoing involvement of the complementary medicines industry in providing advice to government and evaluating and regulating complementary medicines.

I am delighted that the Working Party was able to address these issues and agree on a well considered and comprehensive framework for complementary medicines which addresses market access, the ongoing control of complementary medicines and most importantly the maintenance of public health and safety through co-operation and regulation.

The package of reforms for complementary medicines includes some legislative changes, some changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act regulations, major administrative reforms plus information and consultative initiatives.

The bill that I am presenting today includes the legislative component of complementary medicine reforms. It ensures that through appropriate regulation, the Australian public can be confident that the medicines they consume and medical devices that they use are safe, effective and of a high quality.
In summary, the bill makes amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 in three key respects:
Firstly , it amends key definitions in the act to provide greater clarity and certainty in relation to the application of the legislation.

Secondly, it includes amendments which acknowledge the shift of focus from pre-market clearance to post market vigilance for low-risk `listable' goods. This is achieved by, for example, providing a more streamlined and efficient process to enable sponsors to market low risk products without undue delay while ensuring that consumers continue to be protected from unsafe products.
Thirdly , this bill includes a new part in the act that establishes as a statutory body, the existing Complementary Medicines Evaluation Committee.

The opportunity has also been taken, with agreement from industry, to address other matters in the bill including the establishment of the existing National Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee as a statutory committee and the inclusion of a new Part which describes penalties and offences in relation to the publication of advertisements which have not been pre-cleared.
Allow me to explain the key components of the bill in a little more detail.

The bill amends key definitions in the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 (the act) to provide a better interface between foods, complementary medicines and other medicines such as over the counter and prescription medicines. Changes have been made to reduce confusion at the food-therapeutic goods interface and make it clear when a good is a therapeutic good (regulated by the Therapeutic Goods Administration) and when it is a food (to be dealt with by the Australian and New Zealand Food Authority).

para.inline: Enhanced market access and increased post market vigilance

speech.para: A number of amendments to the bill operate in conjunction with each other to improve market access for complementary medicines while at the same time increasing post market monitoring to ensure that consumers continue to access only safe and reliable products.

At present, once the TGA is satisfied that a substance is sufficiently low risk for its intended purpose, such goods may be eligible for `listing' in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG). These goods are referred to as `listable' goods. However, changes to the documentation of goods that qualify as `listable' goods requires an amendment to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations. This is a cumbersome process that often fails to accommodate the commercial realities involved in enabling low-risk products to become publicly available.

To address this problem, the amendments contained in this bill propose the use of a gazettal notice by the Minister in lieu of an amendment to regulations. This will enable a quicker, more responsive process to be adopted to achieve the same results—that is, low risk products gaining swift access to the market and consumers having access to new products more quickly.

Quicker market access does not mean marketing of less safe products or misleading marketing claims. The bill confirms the existing condition that requires the sponsor to hold evidence supporting any claims.

This supporting evidence will not be required as a matter of routine but will be called upon in cases where there is a clear public health or safety matter at issue or where there has been deliberately or recklessly misleading information provided to the public about a product. The level of evidence that will be required, will be directly related to the risk associated with the product and the nature of the claim made about the product. However, it is important to note that testimonials alone are not acceptable proof of efficacy. The Complementary Medicines Evaluation Committee will advise the TGA and sponsors on appropriate levels of evi dence for claims made for various substances and products.

The combination of these measures will help facilitate growth in the area of complementary medicines and promote public confidence that the complementary health care products marketed in Australia are safe, effective and of a high quality.

The Complementary Medicines Evaluation Committee (CMEC) was established in December 1997. This bill will strengthen and enhance the standing of the Committee and complementary health care products generally by establishing CMEC as a statutory committee.

The establishment of CMEC as a statutory committees under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 is an acknowledgment of the growing significance of this industry and the need to improve the government's access to expertise in this area. This will provide an opportunity for expert, experienced and appropriate input into the evaluation of medicines and for important issues to be discussed amongst peers both within and outside the public sector.

This legislative change, will also be accompanied by a range of administrative reforms aimed at improving the management of complementary medicines and ensuring the involvement of industry and consumers in policy making. For example, I will be setting up an Office of Complementary Medicines within the Therapeutic Goods Administration, responsible for the regulation of the complementary medicines industry and staffed by senior and experienced personnel. I will also be inviting consumer and industry groups to join a Complementary Health Care Consultative Forum.

Another critical issue which the government intends to address through administrative reform is the advertising of therapeutic goods. It is recognised by both the TGA and industry that the existing Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code is somewhat outdated and no longer meets the needs of industry or government. The TGA has therefore undertaken to conduct a comprehensive review of the Code and the guidelines issued in relation to the Code.

The aim of the review will be to create a system of regulation in relation to advertising which is: simple; easily understood by advertisers, sponsors and the media; consistent with modern best practice; and capable of addressing a range of products and claims so that consumers can be appropriately informed. The review will, of course, be characterised by extensive consultation and expert input, particularly from the Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code Council.

As I mentioned earlier, in addition to the reforms proposed in respect of complementary medicines, the opportunity has also been take to make some more general amendments which improve the application of the therapeutic goods legislation in respect of all medicines and devices.

One such amendment formalises existing arrangements in relation to the scheduling of drugs and poisons. The bill creates a new Part in the act which establishes the existing National Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee. The Committee's functions include: making decisions in relation to the classification and scheduling of substances; maintaining the Poisons Standard; and providing advice to government on legislative restrictions and policies in relation to substances.

It should be noted that this Part of the bill, including the definitions adopted specifically for this Part, do not relate to the reforms in respect of complementary medicines. The Part focuses specifically on the work of the existing Commonwealth/State body known as the National Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee.

Another more general amendment included in the bill relates to offences and penalties for publication of advertisements in mainstream print media for which prior approval for such publication has not been obtained.
These offences and penalties previously resided in the Therapeutic Goods Regulations. They are however, much more appropriately placed in the Therapeutic Goods Act itself.

The penalties have been increased from $1,100 to $11,000 to bring them more in line with penalties for the broadcast of product advertisements and to reflect the Government's commitment to ensuring that advertisements which have a wide audience have been appropriately cleared.

In closing, I believe that this bill introduces important amendments which will improve the capacity of the legislation to appropriately regulate complementary health care products and other medicines and other therapeutic goods. The reforms provide a unique opportunity to achieve a co-operative approach to health care and provide assurances to the Australian public that the medicines they consume are safe, effective and of a high quality.
I commend the bill to you.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of these bills be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the winter sittings of 1999, in accordance with standing order 111.
Ordered that these bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

Debate resumed from 15 February, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 and in doing so point out that this is, in the vernacular, a crook bill on electoral matters. It is shameful of the government to bring in this bill with the measures it contains.

speech.para: From 1983, the former Labor government and the former minister in charge of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, my colleague from South Australia Mick Young, established a process where the parliament would have due process over reviewing each election, dealing with issues of electoral administration in a timely and considered manner and trying to reach bipartisanship on the way in which we conduct our elections.

Australia has every right to be generally proud of the fact that, at the national level, the conduct of elections since Federation has been very good by world standards. However, as the joint committee looking at the Electoral Act in 1983-84 recommended, there should be a standing committee to review our Electoral Act and look at ways of improving it on the principle of making it easier and more timely for people to be able to vote in an election.

What we in the Labor Party are about is always ensuring that it is easy for the members of our community to exercise their democratic right—some would say that sacred privilege—to vote. That is a process that, unfortunately, many countries of the world still do not have or do not have in an open and transparent way. That was a major reform of the Hawke Labor government and due credit should be given to Mick Young, the minister, and Dick Klugman who chaired the committee which made all of those recommendations.

Since that time the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which I served on once for a term of government, from 1987 to 1990, has performed that function well. But since this government got into office it has used the process only on the basis of how it can shave the edge off improving the coalition's prospects at election time by the way the act is administered, the way it is changed. The sticky fingers of my colleague Senator Minchin, who in the last period of the government had some interest and responsibilities in this area, are all over this bill in finding ways to give an electoral advantage to the coalition.

Nick Minchin was the State Director of the Liberal Party in the 1980s while I was State Secretary of the Labor Party in South Australia. During that period we fought out a number of election campaigns. I do not think the partisanship that one brings to helping one's party win an election is the right attitude to have in this parliament—drawing up legislation to try to advantage your party at the expense of democratic principles. That is what this bill is about. It is a crook bill and in a number of areas the opposition is going to move amendments to or oppose the provisions of the bill.

I want to mention the extraordinary episode of the so-called Greenfields Foundation. If ever there were an example of how the Liberal Party will find a loophole, even a very small one, and try to drive the Queen Elizabeth ship through it to their electoral advantage, it is the Greenfields incident. Fortunately, the Electoral Commission is now finding ways to further call on the people involved with the Greenfields operation to disclose where the money came from and how it was raised and to ensure that there is proper transparency. In 1983 the then committee, chaired by Dick Klugman, a member of the other place at the time, under the terms of reference from Mick Young, inquired into two major areas of reform: public funding and disclosure.

At the time the Liberal Party opposed public funding, but when it came in they never sent the cheque back. They always took the money, though they said that ethically they disagreed with it. If they had some ethics about it, if they believed it was unethical to get public funding, why did they keep accepting the money? Even in the 1984 election Mr Peacock, the then Leader of the Opposition, campaigned to remove this provision of public funding. Of course, he lost the election. The Liberal Party still accepted the money under their entitlement. It is the height of hypocrisy for the Liberal Party to go around questioning issues of public funding but still be willing to accept the cheque.

Public funding is a very important part of our democratic process. It ensures that political parties get access to reasonable funding to run their election campaigns so that the public have an opportunity to hear all views. It is not just advantaging those political parties that have access to the most money. It was and is a very important reform. But on the disclosure side, it is equally important for people to see who is putting the money up for various political parties. Of course, that was opposed by the Liberal Party. They said that all sorts of terrible things would happen, that intimidation would occur, to those who had been giving money to one party and not to the other. Not one scrap of evidence has anywhere been presented that any organisation which gave more money to one political party than the other has suffered intimidation.

I stand to be corrected—there might be a case—but I cannot recollect since 1983 or 1984, when the legislation came in, anyone being charged with intimidation or threatening somebody who made a political donation to a political party. The disclosure rules have worked very well. It is published, so that you can see who is putting the money into which party. People can make their own judgment as to whether that party's policies have been duly affected by those donations.

The Liberal Party has always been embarrassed that it has to rely solely on money from the big end of town, from the big companies, to keep them going. Four or five years ago, at the time of Alexander Downer's leadership of the Liberal Party, the big end of town, the big companies, decided that his leadership was so bad that they told the Liberal Party: `We won't be putting any more money in.' So in a sense they helped in the downfall of Alexander Downer and Mr Howard became leader again of the Liberal Party.

At that time the debts left in the Liberal Party were substantial. I think the National Australia Bank made a generous facility loan available of $4 million or $5 million to the Liberal Party. Ultimately, they wanted their money back, and how did the Liberal Party do it? They established the Greenfields Foundation whereby, by claiming it is a loan from this company, it does not have to be disclosed. It is absolutely breaking the spirit of the law that we introduced in 1983 and subsequently amended through the 1980s and early 1990s.

The Liberal Party think they are very smart in finding a loophole. Fortunately, the Electoral Commission appears to be now chasing this down. We will be moving amendments to make the Greenfields example no longer available to any political party, so that the disclosure laws work very well.

I would also point out about disclosure and about funding the oddity that the Liberal Party often complains that trade unions make donations to the Labor Party but do not make them to the Liberal Party and that this is unfair. Those donations to the Labor Party have been disclosed in the annual accounts of every trade union under the industrial legislation in Australia for many years, long before public disclosure. So they are available to every union member to see where their membership fees are going.

In South Australia at the moment the Liberal government is trying to outlaw trade unions making such donations. But they are not making any suggestion that you cannot make a donation from a trade union without a specific plebiscite or vote of all the members of the union. They do not want to put that into the provision. However, they are not putting in a provision saying that publicly listed companies have to take a vote of all their shareholders to see whether they should make a donation to a political party.

BHP, Western Mining Corporation and other companies have publicly disclosed that they are making donations to both sides of politics, usually much more to the Liberal Party than to the Labor Party. I would like to see the chairman of the board at the annual general meeting of such companies move a resolution to the shareholders saying, `I hereby move that we make a donation of half a million dollars to the Liberal Party, $100,000 to the Labor Party, $5,000 to the Democrats and the Greens get nothing,' and a ballot of every one of those hundreds of thousands of shareholders of those companies—and see what happens.

If the Liberal Party in South Australia was fair dinkum about this proposal they would amend it to include the fact that every share holder in every company has to be consulted before any political donation can be made to any political party. They will not do that, of course. They want to hit the trade unions around the head. The trade unions have always been open about their affiliation and payments to the Labor Party. The Liberal Party want to remove from the shareholders their opportunity to be consulted and have a vote on whether they believe the dividend money paid to them should be paid to political parties.

I think the issue of disclosure, the Greenfields operation, is a shameful one for the Liberal Party. As I said in my opening remarks, this is a crook bill. It is a disgrace to the process of bipartisanship that we have had over most issues of improvement in the Electoral Act. Many of the other provisions in this bill have only been designed by the Liberal Party because they think they will have the advantage of getting people who they think may not vote for them off the roll and stop them voting.
It is a disgraceful bill in most of its aspects. We will be moving amendments to a number of areas of the bill and rejecting others.

talk.start.para: —At the outset, I thank senators from the opposition and other parties for their contributions to this debate.

speech.para: There are areas of agreement in relation to this legislation. Perhaps it is easier to identify those areas where there is not agreement, and deal with the closure of the rolls. In relation to that closure, the AEC is currently embarking on a process of continually updating the rolls. In fact, this issue has been raised with me by a number of people. They say, `You are shortening the period from the issue of the writs to the closure of the rolls. People will have less chance to get on the roll.' The government says that the ideal situation is that you update the rolls continually outside an election period.

In one exercise—which is a very good one—the AEC has combined with the Victorian Department of Transport to send out notices to those young people who have just obtained a driver's licence. That is a way of reminding young people that they are eligible to get on the roll.

talk.start.para: —What about all the other states?

—Senator Conroy is perhaps jumping ahead of things, because I was coming to that. The AEC is looking at dealing with this in other states, so that young people will have a chance to get on the roll, and, combined with the updating that I have mentioned, this will ensure that people do not have to embark upon that last minute rush which has been a problem of past times. In fact, the AEC has indicated to me that over 400,000 transactions have taken place during the period of the closure of the rolls.

speech.para: Another area of disagreement is the question of prisoner voting. This recommendation was made by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and the government believes it is following community opinion in relation to this matter by extending the bar on voting to prisoners in general. At the moment, roughly a third of prisoners cannot vote. That, of course, will be extended by these provisions and will bring us into line with such countries as the United Kingdom, Switzerland, Belgium and some of the states of the United States of America.

Another area of contention is the disclosure levels of donations. We believe as a government that those are important because we do not believe that parties should be reliant solely on public funding. Recently over $3 million was given to One Nation as a result of public funding and a number of Independents received funding due to the percentage of votes they received during the last election.

We believe that public funding is a good thing. However, political parties should also be given the opportunity to raise their own funds. The levels have not been addressed for seven years and the government believes that it is now time that the thresholds for disclosure should be raised. We do believe as a principle that parties should not rely solely on public funding as a source of revenue. We saw that happen recently in the last election.

There is also the question of the provisions dealing with the verification of enrolment. I would put to the Senate that, when someone enrols to vote, that is an important process in the community, as important as opening a bank account—in fact, more important. Yet the requirements for verification of enrolment are less than those required for opening a bank account. The government believes that there should be some tightening of provisions in relation to that, but not so as to disfranchise people. We have provided in our regulations, which have been circulated in draft form, for a wide class of people to be able to witness the enrolment.
There are some ALP amendments that the government agrees with, and we will be coming to those in due course during the committee stage. There are, of course, others that we do not agree with.

In relation to one aspect which was raised by Senator Hogg, I did take that up with the AEC. Senator Hogg mentioned that his son had made a lodgment and then the process had taken some five days. I am advised by the AEC that, upon lodgment, processing takes place but, because the mail goes out once a week, it may be some days before someone receives notification. That notification is not the substantial registration of that person; registration occurs when the lodgment and processing takes place on the day the form is lodged. In the current situation, with the period for enrolment after the issue of writs, notification can still be received after the time for enrolment has expired.

What I am saying is that the action of lodgment is really what you have to look at, not so much the notification. Some people think they are not enrolled until they receive notification, so that is perhaps a matter which needs clarification. Other than that, I commend the bill to the Senate. In the committee stage, we can deal with those amendments and the final detail.

subdebate.1.para: The bill.

talk.start.para: —We have a running sheet for this bill. The first item relates to schedule 1, items 1 and 2, which are both, I understand, to be opposed by the Democrats and the Australian Greens.
—At the outset, I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill. This memorandum was tabled in the chamber on 15 February this year.

—As indicated on the running sheet, the Democrats wish to oppose schedule 1, items 1 and 2, which relate to the provision of salutation and date of birth information on the electoral roll. As I am sure all senators know, but perhaps not all of the public, the electoral roll is available to all MPs and registered parties already via CD-ROM, so utilising that information and manipulating the data is something that can quite easily be done.

speech.para: Currently, the information that is made available does not include salutation—which I do not think has been recorded by the Electoral Commission yet—and date of birth. Date of birth is in the Electoral Commission's information but has not been provided to date to MPs or registered political parties. This part of the bill will enable that to happen, so in the information to be made available, which I assume will also be provided as part of the information on the CD-ROM, political parties or MPs will be able to sort data by date of birth and salutation.

The Democrats have concerns about this in terms of privacy implications. I realise there are other components of the bill that insert and increase penalties for improper commercial usage of this information, but in our view it is not information that should be made available. Like all parties and people involved in politics, we are trying to encourage people to participate in the electoral system, to participate in our system of democracy and to get on the roll. It is a big issue to make sure people even get on the roll. If people are aware that information such as their date of birth will become readily available to a wide range of people, that may serve as a disincentive for them to get on the roll. There are clearly a lot of privacy concerns in the community, and I do not think this section of the legislation will assist.

Of particular concern is the fact that this information will go to registered political parties. As I indicated in my speech on the second reading debate, there is a long list of bodies that are registered as political parties, many of which are quite obscure and which people know very little about. I for one certainly would not be confident that that information would not be misused.

For instance, organisations such as One Nation, which is actually structured as a company, would be able to utilise such information. You could see David Oldfield, a well-known casanova, being able to do a sort on his computer to extract all the females who have the salutation of `Miss' and who are under the age of 35 so he could send them a personal invitation. He would be able to do that quite easily with this sort of information, and I think that gives an indication of some of the ways this information could be used which are not commercial. I do not know whether that would come under `misuse' in the bill.

In terms of the commercial value of this sort of material, it would be immensely valuable for organisations—whether you are talking about organisations that describe themselves as One Nation Ltd or other organisations outside the political sphere that may be able to get hold of this material—to be able to get the details of basically every adult in the Australian community, in terms of their date of birth and marital status, to some extent, or salutation. The sorts of penalties that are proposed by the government, which I know we will get on to in future amendments, could quite easily be absorbed by a commercial operation into its overall cost structure. An $11,000 fine would be a fairly small amount to pay compared with the amount that a commercial operation would be able to extract from using such a list if it was done in a targeted manner.

For all of those reasons, the Democrats believe that this is not an appropriate measure. It is not appropriate that political parties and parliamentarians should have access to date of birth information. Obviously, it would be beneficial to the Democrats, as to all other MPs, to be able to have access to that infor mation in terms of targeting our message. But we believe we should not have that level of personal information about Australia's citizens.

talk.start.para: —I agree with that. The Greens feel very strongly opposed to this amendment which will give all political parties and all politicians not only the list of names on the electoral roll which, in common with every other member of the Australian public, we have access to at the moment but also—unlike the rest of the Australian public—access to two things: first of all, the date of birth of everybody on the electoral roll, and then the salutation. That is whether a person prefers to be called Miss, Ms, Mrs, Mr, Doctor, Professor—whatever it might be.

speech.para: I understand that this is new. The minister may be able to tell the committee that the salutation will be collected and will be something that people will be required to give when they fill in an application to go on the electoral roll. If that is so, what we are witnessing through this amendment is the electoral office being used to get information that will advantage the political parties. It is not something that the electoral office itself has up until now apparently wanted.

What you can see here is what so often happens in parliament, and that is the big political parties wanting to change the Electoral Act in a way which gives the incumbents an advantage. Of course, when it comes to the next election or the election after that, this information is going to be available to political parties and politicians, but it is not going to be available, for example, to Independents standing for that election. They are going to be clearly disadvantaged—much the same way as they are currently disadvantaged by the rule which says they must always go at the end of the ballot paper.

It is another tilting of the balance towards the incumbents when the balance should be struck and, if anything, turned in the other direction, because what Australians are looking for in this day and age is greater diversity, more individualism, more difference in the range of people they can vote for. This is simply another measure to help entrench the big political parties and give them advantage.

I would ask the minister: to what use can the salutation and date of birth, along with the name of people on the electoral roll, be put by political parties or politicians who get them? Or, conversely, to make it a bit easier: are there any uses which are prohibited under the electoral law? For example, can a political party send out to everybody on the electoral roll a request that that person consider joining the political party? Can they garner a donation? Are they able to invite people to otherwise contribute to the strength and wellbeing of that political party under this amendment in a way that other people are not going to be able to? Where is the line of commercial use? Where is the line of abuse in political parties and politicians getting access to these private details of members in the electorate—access which the Australian people themselves cannot get?

I believe there is a simple rule here. That is, the information on the electoral roll that is available to political parties and politicians ought to be exactly the same as the information that is available to every other citizen. Parties and party machines should not be getting information that is not available to the very people that information is kept on. As Mr or Mrs Citizen, the average Australian is not going to be able to get this information about the date of birth of their neighbour or how the person down the road prefers to be addressed for their Christmas card. Why should the political parties? It is a self-interested amendment. The Greens totally oppose it.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes this amendment, because it flies directly in the face of what the government is proposing. At the moment the AEC collects gender, and that is nothing new. What is proposed here is that the date of birth and salutation be included. It is the view of the government that it is only appropriate to ask people as to the title by which they would like to be addressed. There is no great revelation or no great privacy consideration in that, the government would submit.

speech.para: There are safeguards in relation to the use of information from the roll and the habitation index. There are penalties involved to ensure that the information is not abused. The current situation allows for medical researchers to make use of the information on the roll, and that is for screening for breast cancer and the like. That is covered by regulation.

What we are proposing here is to allow for electoral research by political parties. We do not see that is such a problem. It is all part of the democratic process that there be communication between political parties and those who are entitled to vote. We do not see this as breaking down any great walls of privacy, if you like. What we are dealing with is information which people commonly provide: the salutation, a title by which they wish to be addressed; the date of birth; and, as I say, the gender is already there on the record. I believe that this will assist greatly in how political parties deal with the electorate at large.

talk.start.para: —The question I asked the minister was: what are the limits to which the political parties can put this information? Can they raise money through it? Can they gain membership through it? What is the limit on it? Also, why should the general public not have access to the same information? What sort of research is it, Minister—through you, chair—that the political parties are going to undertake?

speech.para: I can tell you that it will not be selfless research in the interests of the wider Australian public. It will be research aimed at trying to entrench or increase the number of people elected by the big political parties. I have another question for the minister: was the Privacy Commissioner consulted about this amendment; if so, what was the opinion that was given?

talk.start.para: —In relation to the question of the purpose of the use of this measure, I have stated that it is for electoral research. The Australian Electoral Commission is the body that oversees this. Naturally, if someone used it for fund raising purposes—which would not come within the definition of `electoral research'—the AEC would act accordingly. What this facilitates is an ability for political parties to communicate with the electorate. It does not extend to the public at large having that access, because it then would be open to abuse. In relation to the question of advice between the AEC and the government, that is a matter between the AEC and the government.

—There are two points raised there. Is the minister really trying to convince this committee that the political parties are, in some way or another, paradigms of virtue that will not abuse this system in the way that the wider public would? That statement, in itself, has the government saying that the public does not have the ethical standards that the political parties have. I think you would have a lot of trouble sustaining that argument out in the public arena.

speech.para: This is a very clear move by the political parties to gain self-advantage. This is not a move to, in some way or another, act in the wider public interest. This is a self-invested move by the government—and the Labor Party is supporting it—to get information on electors: information which is not available to those electors themselves; information about other people not just to consult or do research, as the minister says, but to be able to at least send out information in an attempt to get electors to support those political parties in a way that other people standing for election cannot. And that is wrong.

There were two other questions. One was whether the Privacy Commissioner was consulted; and, if so, what was the response? And, just going back to the first question I asked of the minister: where are the boundaries of the uses to which this so-called `research' by the political parties can be put? It is not good enough for the minister to say, `Oh, we'll leave that to the Electoral Commission.'

If you are to have good laws, it is up to this parliament—and, in this case, it is up to those putting forward the amendment—to state explicitly the purposes for which the use of salutations and date of birth of Australians in general can be put by the political parties. It is not to be left vaguely to some arbiter because, as you know, that will lead to abuse. I suppose we will get no further answer out of the minister on that, although I invite further comment about what the government believes is a fair use of this information, and that should be on the record at this juncture in this debate.

talk.start.para: —Just briefly on that last point, section 4 of the act contains definitions. One is `electoral matter' which touches, or gives some guidance, on electoral research, and I would refer Senator Brown to that.

speech.para: But the question of the involvement of political parties is not something which is quite mysterious or devious. Political parties play an essential role in the running of democracy in this country, despite the fact that a lot of people do not think so. They contribute to the good order of the running of the parliament and also in the running of elections. I would say that Senator Brown needs to remember that there is recognition of this fact by public funding in relation to elections.

Political parties play a very important role, and electoral research is part of that role. They need to know what the electorate is thinking. They need to communicate their ideas, their policies to the electors of Australia so that, knowing what is on offer, they can have a viable choice. That is what it is all about. It is really about informing the electors of Australia.

I reject the notion that political parties are subversive or, in some way, that they are devious in this regard. I think all political parties have a genuine will to impart their message to the community at large, and that can only be good for democracy in any election.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will not support Senator Bartlett in his opposition to schedule 1, items 1 and 2. The electoral rolls and the habitation indexes, of course, are currently provided either in print or on tape to members and senators of political parties, and that occurs under section 91 of the Electoral Act.

speech.para: As far as the opposition is concerned, we think that it is useful for parliamentarians to have access to further information such as elector's date of birth and salutation details so that we have greater capacity to more accurately address the concerns of the constituents and, I think, also target information more directly.

I do, however, hear what Senator Brown is asking in relation to the involvement of the Privacy Commissioner, and the minister has not yet responded directly on that. I do accept that the privacy issue that he raises is an important one. Certainly, it is recognised by the opposition. We need to acknowledge the sensitivity of the information that has been referred to here. Obviously, it has quite significant value in terms of commercial marketing companies. The opposition does acknowledge that. We believe, as a result, it is important that there are sufficient penalties for misuse of such information. I think it is important to address that concern. I think the opposition's amendments in relation to increasing penalties does address those concerns. I would commend them to Senator Brown's and Senator Bartlett's consideration. As far as the opposition is concerned, we will not oppose this first schedule for the reasons I have outlined, while acknowledging the significance of some of the concerns that have been raised and the approach the opposition has been taking to address them.

talk.start.para: —I would like to ask the minister about the involvement of the Privacy Commissioner. Was there any consultation?

—The Privacy Commissioner has been consulted on this, and I understand the Privacy Commissioner has raised the concern of the electoral research aspect of the extent of it. That is something which the government has actively got under consideration. The AEC will monitor that. In election periods, for a start, if anything is misrepresentative or misleading, the AEC has a role in adjudicating on that. This is nothing new in giving to the AEC a power to govern an area where people might step beyond the mark.

speech.para: I refer you to section 91A, the use of information from the roll and habitation index. In that section there are permitted purposes on how that use is to be put. What I am saying is that of course the privacy considerations were in the mind of the government at the time of this drafting, but it does not believe that the privacy considerations are such as to be a bar to this legislation when it is weighed against the benefits. When you look at the safeguards already in place, section 91A of the act and the definition of electoral matters and the fact that the Electoral Commission will have supervision of this, the government, weighing all those factors, is of the belief that privacy considerations will be looked after.

talk.start.para: —We have at least elicited that the Privacy Commissioner has concerns about this. The minister might tell the committee whether there has been any written comment by the Privacy Commissioner on this section or the other amendments. If so, the minister might be good enough to table those so that we can see what the Privacy Commissioner had to say.

speech.para: Secondly, the minister says, `Look at section 91A as a guide to how the Electoral Commission might adjudicate whether or not the use of data birth and salutation exclusively by political parties and politicians can be put.' When you look at that, you find that the sky is the limit. The information can be used for any purpose in connection with an election or referendum or the performance by the senator or member of his or her functions as a senator or member in relation to the people on the electoral roll. That has no real definition or limitation at all. I suppose by comparison we might say, if we accept that political parties have a special place of honour when it comes to using information about the electorate, information which the electorate itself cannot get, why not give it to the churches? Why not give this information to welfare organisations in the country? Why not give it to ethical organisations so that they might do some research? Are they less worthy of this information than political parties? I think not. Let us be straight about this: this is a direct effort at political self-investment, political self-advantage, getting the political drop by the big political parties on the electorate. That is why we oppose it.

talk.start.para: —The question is that schedule 1, items 1 and 2 stand as printed.

—I did ask if the minister would be good enough to table any correspondence from the Privacy Commissioner on this matter, seeing we have elicited that the Privacy Commissioner was unhappy with the potential of this information being used by political parties.

—To correct the record, I did not say that the Privacy Commissioner was unhappy. Naturally, anything of this sort would attract the attention of the Privacy Commissioner, quite properly so. Because the Privacy Commissioner gives attention to the extent of a definition, that does not mean that the Privacy Commissioner is necessarily unhappy. What I am saying is that there was contact between the Privacy Commissioner and the government, quite naturally so. That is nothing untoward. In fact, it is absolutely proper. I understand what Senator Brown is saying about the communication, and I will take it on notice as to what communication there has been. But the concern I mentioned was, as I understand it, of a general nature. With definitions, you need to have some supervision, and the AEC is in that place.
—The question is that schedule 1, items 1 and 2 stand as printed.
—by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 1 and 2 on revised sheet 1232:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 8, page 3 (line 27), omit "100 penalty units", substitute "1,000 penalty units".
(2) Schedule 1, item 9, page 4 (line 2), omit "100 penalty units", substitute "1,000 penalty units".

In a sense—as I flagged in my previous contribution—this penalty provision deals with the issue that we have just been debating. It goes particularly to the issue of privacy, about which a number of senators have expressed concerns. The government's proposal in the bill to increase the penalty to 100 units—which is effectively an $11,000 penalty—is a step in the right direction, but I believe that a more severe penalty should be imposed, given the increased access to information on electors and the sensitivity and value of that information. The opposition amendments propose to increase the number of penalty units to 1,000 for disclosure or for using this information for commercial purposes. That would mean it would attract a fine of $110,000, and I think that is more appropriate and would reflect the value of the information that is provided to parliamentarians and those involved in the political process.

The disclosure of this information to marketing companies could offer an enormous commercial advantage to them, and it is essential that a penalty exist to act as a serious deterrent to any such commercial advantage—in other words: use this information for what it is intended to be used for. The minister has indicated on behalf of the government the sorts of constraints that apply. I think this is an important amendment to ensure that no individual strays beyond those sorts of constraints. We do not think that the government's proposal for 100 penalty units or an $11,000 penalty does that; we believe that the very significant increase to $110,000 would. As a result, I commend the opposition's amendments to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will be supporting the amendments moved by Senator Faulkner. We also realise that any commercial entity will have the capacity to absorb an $11,000 fine in their business dealings, and let us not forget that a few political parties actually structure themselves as private companies. If fines are to be effective, the Democrats believe that the $11,000 fine outlined in the legislation is not a sufficient disincentive. We beli eve that the $110,000 fine, as put forward by the opposition, is a much better deterrent in anybody's language. Therefore, it is something that we strongly support.
—The Greens support these amendments.

—These amendments are supported by the government. The government was proposing an increase in penalty to ensure that there was not a misuse of the information on the rolls, but it has no problem with the more severe penalties sought by the opposition.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I suggest that opposition amendments Nos 3 to 7 on sheet 1233 might actually be better dealt with after we determine the threshold issue of prisoner voting, which goes to the provision of mobile booths, et cetera. I respectfully suggest that it might assist the committee if we dealt with this after schedule 1, item 29 on the running sheet just before opposition amendment No. 1 on sheet 1233. I do not want to spend a lot of time on this, but it just seems that we are going to be a bit out of kilter here otherwise.
—Is it the wish of the committee? There being no objection, it is so ordered.
—I move Opposition amendment No. 2 on sheet 1233:

speech.para: (2) Schedule 1, item 10, page 4 (lines 3 and 4), omit the item, substitute:
Insert:
(ba) is serving a sentence of imprisonment which:
(i) commenced on or before the return of the writs for an election for the House of Representatives or the Senate; and
(ii) continues at the issuing of the writs for any succeeding election for the House of Representatives or the Senate, as the case may be; or

This amendment is an important one. It omits item 10 and proposes in its place amendments to tighten the current provisions. The provisions in this bill would deny all prisoners a vote. Therefore, a person, say, who was sentenced to eight weeks in gaol coinciding with an election period could not vote. Another prisoner who was sentenced to two years in gaol coinciding with a favourable electoral cycle would be able to vote.

The truth is that parliament has accepted that certain classes of prisoners should not be able to vote. We do not oppose that view that has been expressed by parliament previously. But we say that it is possible to distinguish between major and minor crimes, as has been decided previously by this parliament and a range of state parliaments. That is why we will be opposing measures to abolish mobile polling booths for prisons and postal votes for prisoners, which was the item that we have deferred to a little later in our considerations and deliberations.

Our amendments will ensure that, if any prisoner has been continually in prison from the return of the writs of the previous elections to the issuing of the writs for the next election, their vote will not be admitted to the count. And we think that this is an improvement to the current act, that it actually provides greater consistency to the five-year rule. We have picked up suggestions, arising from the debate in the House of Representatives, to leave item 29 as it is. Item 29 provides for the controller-general of prisons in each state and territory to forward to the AEC lists of persons who have been convicted and are serving a sentence of imprisonment. To make the opposition's amendment effective the provision of that information is essential.

Fundamentally, we are saying that, above and beyond the five-year rule, which we believe ought to remain in place, any prisoner who has not been able to be involved at all in the political process from the return of the writs of one election to the issuing of the writs at the next ought not to be entitled to vote because, of course, there has been no capacity for a prisoner in that circumstance—in any sense, or in any way—to participate in the political process.

This is, I suppose, Mr Temporary Chairman, an amendment that could be described, in one sense, as a minor tightening of the current provisions. Nevertheless, I think it is a balanced approach that the opposition is taking on this issue and I think it strengthens the provision in the current act. I commend it to the committee.

talk.start.para: —I will be supporting that amendment but, as the committee and Senator Faulkner will be aware, the Greens not only oppose the amendments which are going to discriminate further against prisoners in Australia—in breach, we believe, of a number of international civil rights covenants—but will move to ensure that all Australian prisoners have the right to vote. Currently the law is that if you are sentenced to five years or more, you cannot vote. Senator Faulkner's amendment is an improvement on that. But the best thing that can be done is to get rid of that provision altogether. There are a number of reasons for this. Firstly, it is up to the courts to put a penalty on a person who infringes against society; it should not be for parliaments to be adding to that penalty. If we were having a move here today to say judges may be able, in their considerations, to deprive some prisoners of votes, then so be it. But this universal imposing of extra penalties above those of the courts is not a good way for us to be going. What other rights will the parliament, generally, take away from prisoners?

speech.para: There is a very good reason for giving prisoners the vote—that is, we all want to see prisoners out of jails, where they cost a lot of money, and back in society in a rehabilitated form so that they feel part of society and feel they can contribute to society and not go back to prison. Where you deny prisoners the right to vote, you send a clear message to them that they are rejected by society and that they have a right to feel further alienated. The impact of this is to lessen the likelihood of people coming out of prison with a better attitude towards society than when they went in. It is not that we would be alone in this. As I mentioned, there are a number of international covenants which say that every citizen should have a right to vote. The measures being put forward here by the government—to further trammel the right of prisoners to vote—goes against those covenants.

Around the world, countries which ensure that prisoners do have the right to vote include Cyprus, England, Hungary, Israel, Kenya, Netherlands, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Japan, Norway, Poland and Zimbabwe, as well as five states in the US. I think we are following the pattern of the United States—which is trying to contain the extraordinary levels of crime it has compared to Australia; and the misguided philosophy behind its crowded gaols, which have over a million prisoners these days—where the belief is that, in some way or another, depriving people of civil liberties will teach them something that will help them when they come back into society. The reverse is the case.

Following a number of peaceful environmental protests, I have found myself for a period of time with prisoners in Tasmanian gaols. They are alert to what is going on in politics. They read the papers. They watch television. They discuss these matters. I think we ought to encourage that, not discourage it. The deprivation of a person's right to vote is a very clear discouragement. As I said, if that is to be a penalty for prisoners, let the courts impose it.

Senator Ray said in this place the other day when we were talking about these matters that anybody who gets up and tries to improve the lot of prisoners—I am paraphrasing here, but I agree with this sentiment—is going to cop a bucketing out in the community. That does not make it wrong. That is why I will not only be supporting this opposition amendment, which is a fair one, but also be moving, as you know, amendments a little further down the line to ensure that prisoners do have the right to vote in Australia, as they do in many other countries around the world.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will be supporting this opposition amendment, for reasons similar to those just outlined. We also strongly believe that it is important, except in exceptional circumstances such as treason, et cetera, that prisoners should have the right to vote. We do not believe it serves any useful purpose to deny prisoners that right, particularly in relation to some of the reasons why people end up in gaol these days.

speech.para: Senator Cooney, in his contribution at the second reading stage, pointed out the problems of mandatory sentencing laws in the Northern Territory. Mandatory sentencing also exists in Western Australia. The Democrats are strongly opposed to the mandatory sentencing regimes in those areas and, indeed, anywhere in Australia. The attempt to deprive citizens of their entitlement to vote, we believe, is unfounded and unhelpful in terms of trying to ensure as comprehensive a democratic system as possible.

It probably would be unreasonable of me to suggest that this may be the government's motivation. I am sure it is not. Nonetheless, it is still appropriate to point out that it would be reasonable to assume that the potential political beneficiaries of such a measure would be conservative parties. I think it would be reasonable to suggest that, demographically speaking, people in prison would be less likely than those in the broader community to vote for conservative parties. Whilst I am not suggesting that is the government's motivation, it nonetheless has that potential effect.

As with any change to the electoral law, I think it is important to highlight those sorts of issues. As I said in my contribution in the second reading debate, all of us in this place are not just legislators but a prime interest group in relation to the impact of this legislation that deals with electoral law. We need to highlight that up-front and be clear about that.

There are a number of other amendments that the Democrats and Senator Brown are proposing, as have been indicated on the running sheet, to ensure that prisoners have the right to vote. In relation to Senator Faulkner's amendment, we believe it is an improvement on the bill as it stands at the moment, and we will support it.

talk.start.para: —The government is opposing these amendments for a number of reasons. Firstly, the unworkability of this would make the AEC entirely reliant on timely advice from prison authorities following the issue of the writ. The AEC has to deal with not only six states but also two territories in dealing with prison authorities. I also note that there is no proposed amendment to section 109 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Section 109, `Lists of convictions to be forwarded', provides that the Controller-General of Prisons shall forward a list each month to the Australian Electoral Commissioner of the names of those people who have been sentenced to a period of five years or longer. That is the current provision. I note that that has not been amended by the opposition. That is a flaw that would need to be amended as well.

speech.para: The other thing is that the amendment would be extremely impractical to implement, even with the current seven-day close of rolls period. It would be difficult for the AEC to determine the eligibility of prisoners as this could only be resolved when the date of the issue of the writ is known.

The other problem you have with the opposition amendment is that it deals with the return of the writs for an election for the House of Representatives or the Senate and it continues to the issuing of the writs for any successful election for the House of Representatives or the Senate. There are different times for those. Whilst the writs of the House of Representatives are returned together, the various writs from the states for the Senate may not all be returned on the same day. That is another administrative aspect which the government has a problem with.

In total, the government's proposal is a much simpler one in dealing with this issue. This deals with the recommendation made by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters—that is, that those who disregard the laws to a degree sufficient to warrant imprisonment should not expect the right to retain a franchise. As I say, in any event, there is provision at the moment for those sentenced to a period of five years or over to lose that entitlement. On that basis, the government opposes the opposition's amendment and maintains its proposal as previously stated.

talk.start.para: —The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Faulkner be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —We will now move to schedule 1, items 18, 36, 49, 59 and 69.

—The sections here all relate to schedule 1, items 18, 36, 49, 59 and 69 which remove the provisions containing the right to vote for prisoners. These amendments are identical to the Greens amendments.
—They are all opposing items. The question will be that the items stand as printed.

—The aim here is to oppose the government's amendments which would deprive prisoners who are sentenced to less than five years in gaol of their right to vote. Some time ago the parliament, as Senator Faulkner has said, decided to take away from prisoners who are sentenced to more than five years in gaol the right to vote. This move means that all prisoners will lose their right to vote. That goes against, as I have said, a series of international covenants. It overrides what I believe is the court's sole prerogative to be giving penalties to people who break the law, and it puts us out of line with a lot of countries around the world in ensuring that prisoners do have the right to vote.

speech.para: It is also totally unfair, and there is no way that the government is going to fix this up. It means that, if you are in gaol for a relatively minor crime which has involved no physical harm to anybody else, when Mr Howard calls an election you lose your vote. Of course, if you have just finished your sentence—your two months or your one month—and you are out of gaol you keep your vote. If you go to gaol just after the election you keep your vote. If you just happen to be the one who is in gaol when the election is called you lose your vote. It, on the face of it, means that those prisoners who happen to be serving their sentence at, and only at, the time an election is called will be deprived of privileges which prisoners who have just got out of gaol are going to maintain.

I and other senators have had a very strong letter from the South African communities organising for public safety and for a sensible and effective prison policy, Ms Johnson, saying, `Don't do this.' It is saying that these organisations are horrified to hear that the Prime Minister and the government have put forward this bill with the intention of removing prisoners' right to vote. It says:

I remember the years we South Africans could rely on Australians to stand up for human rights by supporting the anti-apartheid movement, demonstrating at Springbok rugby and cricket games when racist-minded bureaucrats allowed them to travel to your country. I consider Australia as the progressive country, with its fair share of problems but working to address them in a fair and equitable manner.
It mentions, by the way:
I remember—
says Ms Johnson—

reading about the ground-breaking prison reform attempts of Mr Tony Vincent in New South Wales, which focused on addressing the real problems of prisons ravaged by riots and institutionalised brutality with rehabilitation, education and empowerment. Mr Vincent was correct when he sought to introduce the humane principle that a prisoner must retain certain inalienable rights if the hopeless cycle of recidivism, that is, going back to crime, is ever to be broken. The right to vote should be an inalienable right for all citizens of all countries.

This South African correspondent goes on to point out that, of course, by denying prisoners the vote, including prisoners who are sentenced to less than five years, if you look at the statistics, will have an undue effect of depriving indigenous people of the right to vote. Remember that, wholesale, indigenous Australians were not recognised or given that right until just a couple of decades ago. Here we have a move which is going to unfairly discriminate against indigenous Australians for the simple reason that they go to gaol, they get locked up, 10 to 20 times as much as the rest of the population. The reasons for that we all know—the poverty, the dispossession of land, the enforced breakdown and deprival of culture, and so many other things.

Added on top of this is a disproportionate and I believe racist amendment in its effect in depriving an undue number of indigenous Australians of the right to vote. I totally object to it. The Greens are totally opposed to this. We think this committee chair would do well to listen to the letter from South Africa saying, `Don't do it.' Prisoners, like everybody else, should have the right to vote. It should be an inalienable right. Taking away their right to vote is not going to help with reform, reduction of crime, or improvement of behaviour when prisoners get out of gaol, which ought to be the aim of their time in gaol. I would submit that this is the case, in particular, for people sentenced to gaol for less than five years, who so often have not caused physical harm but have in other ways broken the law—very often over monetary matters. This measure is discriminatory in a number of ways and that is why we oppose these government amendments.

talk.start.para: —The government will be opposing these amendments put forward by the Greens; I think our reasons for so doing were stated adequately previously.

—Effectively, I think Senator Brown is right when he makes the point that the current bill as it stands—if these amendments were not accepted by the committee—would deny all prisoners the right to vote. This goes to the issue of mobile polling booths, capacity for postal voting and enrolment and the like. I think the issues have probably been well canvassed in our previous debate on the threshold issue of prisoner voting. The opposition obviously will be supporting the amendments that stand in our name and, in this case, identical amendments that stand in the names of Senator Brown and Senator Bartlett.
—The question is that schedule 1, items 18, 36, 49, 59 and 69 stand as printed.
—According to the running sheet, we are now dealing with schedule 1, item 10—prisoners.
—I move:

speech.para: Schedule 1, item 10, page 4 (lines 3 and 4), omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the paragraph.

This is an amendment to carry into effect the assurance of the right to vote of all Australians. At the moment, due to past legislation, that right has been taken away from people who happen to be in gaol for more than five years. I have canvassed the issues before. It is logical to carry it through. That inalienable right should be there for all citizens, regardless of their circumstances. So I am moving further here to have the right to vote restored to all people who are in gaol.

talk.start.para: —I indicate the Democrat's support for this amendment.

—I have made pretty clear the position of the opposition in relation to this amendment. The opposition has tried to take a sensible and balanced approach here. Fundamentally, with the amendments that have been moved to improve the current five-year rule, we think that the five-year rule is a reasonable one. I have used the terminology `balanced' and that is what I stress to the committee I think is the opposition's approach here. It is balanced. It reflects what happens in a majority of the state and territory jurisdictions. I think we have made sensible improvements to the Electoral Act in the committee today, and the opposition would commend its approach in relation to this issue.

speech.para: We will not accept the direction that the government is moving in. I suppose on this particular occasion we find ourselves as the ham in the sandwich between the approach that Senator Brown articulates on behalf of the Greens and Senator Bartlett articulates on behalf of the Australian Democrats and the approach of the government. In a general sense, we have got a pretty balanced provision here. I think we had a balanced provision; it has now been improved in the committee. I would commend that to the committee.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes the amendment proposed by the Greens and supported by the Democrats, again for reasons that I have outlined previously.

—I thank the Democrats for supporting this amendment, because I think it is a very important one. It carries through the logical thrust of the vote that we have seen a while ago and this debate that the rights of prisoners should not be infringed outside those that are taken away by the courts.
