This amendment would bring us into line with a great number of similar countries and jurisdictions overseas and would take away the imputation that we are in breach of a number of international covenants to do with human rights by depriving some prisoners in Australian gaols the right to vote. But I can see that the numbers will be against this.

speech.para: Senator Faulkner says that the Labor Party is in the middle on this. Just listening to the debate you can see that the Labor Party is a long way ahead of the coalition's philosophy when it comes to civil rights in this matter. It is just a pity that the Labor Party is not making the stand it would have made five years ago on this matter.

talk.start.para: —We have been consistent on this one, Senator Brown; I think you have to acknowledge that. We have always supported that five-year rule—always.
—I apologise to Senator Faulkner; I did have it in my mind that in the past the Labor Party had been opposed to the removal of the right of prisoners to vote.
—If you look at the state jurisdictions you will see in many of them a pretty similar provision. But anyway, this is not a debate.
—There we are. The Greens stand very strongly by this amendment. I am frustrated that it is not going to pass.
—The question is that the amendment to schedule 1, item 10 moved by Senator Brown be agreed to.
—As I read the running sheet, the Democrats would now seek to oppose item 10. Is that your understanding, Senator Bartlett?
—This basically preserves the status quo by removing item 10 from the legislation. It is the same issue in relation to a prisoner's right to vote, so I won't go over those arguments again.
—The question is that schedule 1, item 10 stand as printed.
—I seek some guidance from you here. Item 10 has been omitted, has it not, by successive opposition amendment No. 2 on sheet 1233?
—I think that is a question to you, Senator Bartlett.

—Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, I am a little surprised that Senator Bartlett is proceeding with this one, given the fate of opposition amendment No. 2 in my name on sheet 1233, that's all. I am a little perplexed, I suppose.

—Given that we have been through the debate and addressed the issue when we had the vote on Senator Faulkner's amendment earlier on and that this one is slightly in conflict with it, it would probably be easier not to proceed with it. So I will withdraw it.
—The question is that schedule 1, item 10 stand as printed.

—The running sheet calls next for Senator Brown from the Australian Greens on schedule 1, item 29. Are you still proceeding with that item, Senator Brown? The advice we have here is that you would not proceed with it.
—That's correct, Chair, so I will not proceed.
—That then brings us to the Democrats, schedule 1, item 29, prisoner lists. Senator Bartlett, you are opposing item 29?
—Yes. This is, again, on sheet 1227. It is simply to oppose schedule 1, item 29, relating to prisoner lists.
—I haven't got the amendment sheets in front of me but, in effect, this is removing the words `five years or longer', is it not, from section 109?
—Yes.

—Again, given the fact that my earlier amendment was carried and that there is some sense in the `five years or longer' being removed from the act and given where we are going, I am afraid I would need to be convinced that this is not a sensible change in these circumstances by either Senator Brown or Senator Bartlett. I think the direction in which the committee is moving almost requires this provision in the bill to stay.

—Maybe Senator Faulkner can help clarify the matter. I am under the assumption that the amendment which the committee adopted earlier means that prisoners who are sentenced to five years lose their vote only if they have been in gaol for two election calls.
—Yes, or five years or longer.
—And they will need not only to have been sentenced to five years but also to have been in gaol when the previous election was called.

—Well, no. That is not quite the intention, as I explained to the committee. It is, as I have described, a moderate strengthening of the provision that goes to those prisoners who have been in gaol from the time of the return of the writs in one election to the issue of the writs for the next. So as I explained in my brief but, I hope, comprehensive speech in support of my amendment, it effectively involves those prisoners who are not able, because they are in gaol for the whole of that period between the return of the writs in one election and the issue of the writs for the next election, to take any part in the political process. That is why, consequently, the words `five years or longer' seem to me to be able to be removed from the act. Hence on this occasion, unless I can be convinced otherwise by solid argument from either you or Senator Bartlett, the opposition would find itself in support of the government on this provision.

speech.para: The minister might care to make a comment on this, but as I would understand it, unless this provision in the bill stands, it will lead to an administrative nightmare for the AEC. That is what I am assuming. I was not actually convinced by the minister's arguments in relation to the difficulties of administration last time, but I am jumping to a conclusion here. Senator Brown, Senator Bartlett and I are all grappling with the issue of what the administrative consequences are.

On the basis of the AEC's administration—given the vote of the committee in relation to my previous amendment—I am coming to the conclusion, unless someone can convince me otherwise, that this provision in the bill should stand. I think it makes sense.

talk.start.para: —I have been under the misapprehension that the previous amendment was to apply to those people who had been convicted of a crime and sentenced to more than five years in gaol. That has been my misapprehension. Senator Faulkner has got through to me that when he uses the word `strengthening', it means in effect that people who are in gaol for two or three years will have their vote removed. I was under a misapprehension there. I will be opposing this amendment if that is the case, and will move to have the previous vote resubmitted at a later stage.

—Can I clarify this amendment to be clear what we are talking about? It deals with section 109 of the existing act. The bill that we are considering seeks to take out the reference to `five years or longer'. The section deals with the Comptroller-General of Prisons forwarding at the beginning of each month a list of the names, addresses, et cetera, of persons who have been convicted in that state during the previous month, and forwarding those lists to the electoral office. At the moment those lists are only of people who are serving a sentence of five years or longer for any offence. That is what is in the act at the moment.

speech.para: The legislation that we are discussing today seeks to remove the requirement that the list consist of those people serving a sentence of five years or longer, and change it to anybody who is serving a sentence of imprisonment, which is obviously in line with the government's initial intention to deny all prisoners the right to vote.

Since we now have Senator Faulkner's amendment through, which modifies that to people who are in prison for two elections, the five years is actually fairly incongruous and will not necessarily assist the Electoral Commissioner to accurately determine who is eligible to vote and who is not.

In that sense, it may actually be better to proceed with what is in the bill which would require a list of everybody who is imprisoned. This will give the Electoral Commission as much information as possible to help them decide who should vote and who should not. It may even need extra information about length of sentence or something like that, but I would leave that to the drafters in the government's office.

Therefore, it probably makes sense for me to withdraw this amendment to schedule 1, item 29, having finally figured out where we are at. Unless somebody wants to object to that, I might proceed down that path.

talk.start.para: —I understand where Senator Bartlett is coming from. I will respond to Senator Brown. The opposition's position in relation to this issue of prisoner voting has been absolutely consistent from the time the minority report on the bill was brought down and of my second reading speech. There have also been a range of public utterances on this and I am sorry if it was misunderstood.

speech.para: The terminology I have used, which is either `strengthening' or `tightening', is reasonable in this circumstance. It is only a moderate tightening. It keeps the five-year threshold, but does go to also removing a right to vote for a prisoner who is in gaol for the period that we have spoken about.

Senator Brown is saying to me that he misunderstood the opposition's amendment. I accept that, as one does in these circumstances. I hope he is not suggesting in any sense that the opposition has been misleading. This has been a very consistent position that we have adopted. I have always taken the view, as you know, that, if at the end of the day you get a different vote because of some problem in the committee stage, you want the committee vote to reflect the will of the committee. Senator Bartlett's contribution which just preceded mine is a sensible way to proceed, if the decisions of the committee stand.

talk.start.para: —I would vote differently on opposition amendment No. 2, which put in effect the removal of the vote from prisoners who had been in prison at the previous election, even though they may not be serving a five-year sentence. The best way to proceed would be for that vote to be resubmitted, because the amendments we are looking at now are consequent upon that vote. I therefore request that opposition amendment No. 2 on sheet 1233 be resubmitted for determination.

—I agree with the course of action proposed by Senator Bartlett. It would be incongruous to have the five-year period in section 109 of the act in view of the opposition amendment that has just been passed. It works out quite ironically that the government's amendment dovetails with the opposition amendment which has been successfully passed, because the proposal by the government is to remove that five-year provision in section 109.

speech.para: Senator Bartlett is quite right. If the government's proposal is passed, the list of all those in prison will be forwarded to the AEC. The AEC will then apply the formula as passed by the opposition here today, and that will be it. But if you include the five-year provision which is currently there in section 109, you will complicate matters further.

talk.start.para: —It is getting more confusing by the minute. If we are going to bounce back and reconsider Senator Faulkner's amendment, then what we are doing now may or may not be the way to go. We probably need to resubmit Senator Faulkner's initial amendment and then come back to the amendment which I was talking about withdrawing.

—I was actually going to proceed to put the question that schedule 1, item 29, stand as printed. Assuming that was carried, I would then move back to ask that opposition amendment No. 2, by leave, be recommitted. If that procedure is followed, it should resolve things.

—Mr Chairman, I strongly believe you are better off not putting that question. If we are going to go through the process of recommitting—and hopefully it would be by leave, which I want to make a point about in a moment—let us not complicate it further so we will have to come back and deal with it later. I think it would be a mistake to put that question before the chair because the risk is that we will have to go and undo that also.
—Senator Faulkner, perhaps while you have the call, you can move that schedule 1, item 29 be postponed.

—It is not necessarily that common that we have recommittals in the committee stage. I think Senator Brown has made it clear that there was a genuine misunderstanding here about the effect of what I describe as the opposition's threshold amendment on prisoner voting.

speech.para: I also make this point to the committee: the vote on the opposition amendment that stands in my name was won by the opposition by two votes. I am not sure who the government culprit was who did not attend the division. No doubt the search party is out now, and he or she will be rounded up and disciplined in accordance with the standard operating procedure you have when senators miss divisions. However, even if Senator Brown had voted differently, the amendment would not have found favour with the committee on equal voting.

I think in this situation, given that we have a genuine misunderstanding from a senator which would have made a difference to the outcome of the division and given that, with all the difficulties, we are still progressing reasonably through this—and I am disappointed that this is probably going to mean the opposition's proposal, which I described as sensible and balanced, will go down—recommittal is reasonable. This also means that we will probably be falling back to the amendments that go to the retention of the current five-year provision as it stands currently in the act.

So the committee stage debate will evolve quite differently if we have this recommittal. Hence, Mr Chairman, I think you made the right decision not to put the question that was before the chair. We have postponed that. With that explanation, all I can suggest is that we get on with it. Even though I was a victor, I suppose I will just have to wear the glory of having that significant reform through the parliament for only a short period of time.

talk.start.para: —Is leave granted for the recommittal of opposition amendment No. 2?
—I now put opposition amendment No. 2 to schedule 1, item 10. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —Senator Faulkner, do you wish to recommit items 18, 36, 49, 59 and 69 at this stage?

—On that point, I do not think there is any need to, but you might care to seek the minister's guidance. I do not think there is any suggestion that senators from the opposition and minor parties who voted on those particular provisions would vote any differently. It would not be my intention to do so, unless you wanted to test the will of the committee. Given that we are unpicking a range of decisions that we have made, I appreciate that that might be the view of the minister at the table. I do not see a necessity to do it, unless someone informs me that it is likely to involve the committee coming to a different view.

speech.para: They are effectively a range of provisions that allow prisoners to vote, whether it be mobile polling booths, a facility for postal votes or even retention of enrolment. It seems to me, given what we have heard in the debate, we are likely to see the committee not change its view on that particular matter. It was the opposition amendment on which, after further explanation, the final vote did not reflect the will of some senators who had a misunderstanding about the impact of that particular amendment. That would be my view, Mr Temporary Chairman. The minister may have a different one, as may other senators, but I think we can stick with it.

talk.start.para: —Is it the wish of the committee that we go back to postponed item 29?

—Mr Chairman, it is not a question of recommittal because Senator Bartlett did not move Democrat amendment (2) on sheet 1227 revised 2. Now that I think we have unpicked what occurred previously, it is important that you call Senator Bartlett to move that amendment. Once that amendment is moved, we will be able to progress through the running sheet.
—Senator Bartlett, will you be opposing item 10?
—Yes, we will be opposing item 10 of schedule 1.
—Is leave granted to return to item 10? There being no objection, I call Senator Bartlett.

—The Democrats oppose item 10 of schedule 1. Just to be clear, I think we are still talking about the right of prisoners to vote. Now that Senator Faulkner's amendment has gone down, we are discussing whether what is currently in the government's bill—which is that all prisoners be unable to vote—should stay. By opposing this part of the bill, basically the Democrats wish to retain the existing situation of the five-year imprisonment; that is, that only prisoners who are sentenced for five years or more be unable to vote. So it is a status quo situation.

speech.para: Whether we wish to have the status quo or go in the direction the government is suggesting, which is to prevent any prisoner from being able to vote, I think is the threshold test on which we now need the Senate's indication, before figuring out where we are to go with any consequential amendments. Given that the Senate has already decided that we should not expand the right to vote to all prisoners, the Democrats are obviously of the view that the next-best fall back option is to retain the status quo. Therefore, we will be opposing item 10 of schedule 1.

talk.start.para: —I support the proposal by Senator Bartlett. After the committee's revisionism on the opposition's preferred amendment and approach, I think it is important that now this particular amendment be supported so that the provisions in the current act in relation to prisoners, at a minimum, stay. At a later stage Senator Brown may again engage in the debate about progressing his other amendments. But this, though not the preferred approach of the opposition, does maintain the five-year rule in the act. And I think that is important.

speech.para: I think that is a much better compromise than the government's proposal to remove all entitlements for prisoners to vote and enrol. I would point out to Senator Brown that ensuring that all prisoners, regardless of length of sentence, can participate in the electoral process is a more balanced approach than what the government is proposing, which is to remove all rights for prisoners in relation to voting and enrolment.

It is not perfect, and obviously the opposition's amendments would have improved the act as it currently stands. But this is the preferable course of action to maintain this provision that not only is current Commonwealth law but, of course, has also found favour in a majority of state and terri tory jurisdictions. So there is also this issue of consistency across the states, territories and the Commonwealth. So I think, in the circumstances and, as I say, after the committee's recent revisionism, Senator Bartlett's amendment is worthy of support and is a principled position to draw the sort of distinction that is appropriate in relation to prisoners' voting rights.

talk.start.para: —Chairman, what is before the chair? I thought the motion put before the committee is that the schedule stand as printed. Is it not?
—The question is that item 10 stand as printed.
—That is right. So there is no real amendment by Senator Bartlett, as I understand it.
—No, I think there has to be a vote on that first.
—It is his amendment not to remove item 10, Senator.
—I am sorry, I am getting a bit lost. Thank you.

—It certainly is complicated. What Senator Bartlett's amendment is doing is effectively stymieing the government's effort to have all prisoners lose their votes and maintaining the preferable position of the status quo, which has the vote only removed for prisoners who are sentenced to more than five years in gaol.
—The question is that item 10 stand as printed.
—The question now is that item 29 stand as printed.

—This takes us back to where we were before we decided to recommit, which relates to the list that states that prison directors or controller-generals have to forward to the Electoral Commission. Given that we have now retained the status quo of the five-year limit, it is obviously consequential that this section of the bill also be not proceeded with. The Democrats will be opposing item 29.
—I have nothing to add to my previous eloquence on this issue.
—The question is that item 29 stand as printed.
—We move to opposition amendment No. 1, sheet 233. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, are we on clause 2?
—We are on clause 2, prisoners.
—This is consequential to the opposition's amendment that at first found favour but then seemed to hit the rocks. I do not think there is any need for me to progress this one.
—We will move on.
—Mr Chairman, I would like some clarification. I thought this was consequential on opposition amendments Nos 3 to 7, which had already been passed, rather than the one that went down.
—My understanding is that perhaps it does have to proceed. I think Senator Faulkner will have to move his amendment and see how the cards fall.
—I move the amendment standing in my name:

speech.para: (1) Clause 2, page 2 (line 1), omit ", 18, 29, 36, 49, 59 and 69", substitute "and 29".

talk.start.para: —The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Faulkner be agreed to.
—Mr Chairman, we were dealing with the consequential opposition amendments which flowed from the original opposition amendment which was initially won and then lost.
—No, I think not. I thought that myself, but it was the ones that were carried.
—Okay.

—On a separate point of order, Mr Chairman, can you advise me on the fate of the amendment that was moved by Senator Bartlett, Democrats amendment No. 4 on sheet 1227? Debate was postponed when we decided to go down the track of recommittal. I want to be clear on the status of that.
—Item 29 was negatived.
—We have dealt with it?
—Yes. It is not an amendment because it does not exist. We now move to Democrat amendment No. 13 on sheet 1227. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.
—I understand that these are consequential amendments, given that we have voted to preserve the status quo. I move amendment No. 13 on sheet 1227:

speech.para: Prisoners
(13) Clause 2, page 2 (line 1), omit ", 9, 10, 18, 29, 36, 49, 59 and 69", substitute "and 9".

talk.start.para: —The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Bartlett be agreed to.
—Mr Chairman, could this be explained as to how that fits in?

—My understanding is that this amendment seeks to remove a range of numbers from the list at the start of the legislation that deals with commencements of various items. Those are items that we have now voted to omit from the legislation. To ensure consistency, those numbers need to be taken out for the date of commencement.

—I am getting rather confused. The advice coming from the clerks is a little different. Perhaps we may have to go back. Opposition amendment No. 1 should not have been moved because Democrat amendments Nos 2 and 4 were agreed to, not opposition No. 2, if that makes sense. Do you understand that?
—No.
—My information is that Democrats amendment No. 13 should be moved, not opposition amendment No. 1, because Democrat amendments Nos 2 and 4 were successful and not opposition amendment No. 2.

—I think the opposition No. 1 lists omitting Nos 18, 29, 36, 49, 59 and 69 and leaving 29. Mine includes those numbers plus 10 and 18 and removes 29. I think it removes a few extra numbers. If we need to withdraw opposition No. 1 for some technical reason, that is fine.
—Senator Bartlett, I think the easiest way out of this is for you to move your amendment in the amended form, which would include those bits that were left out.
—I am sure you are being well advised, so I will do as you request. I move:

speech.para: Clause 2, page 2 (line 1), as amended, omit ", 9, 10 and 29", substitute "and 9".

talk.start.para: —The question is that the revised amendment moved by Senator Bartlett be agreed to. Those of that opinion, say aye—
—On a point of order, I would like to be absolutely clear as to what is before the chair.

—Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman: Senator Bartlett, how is Democrats' amendment No. 13 consequential? What is the effect of this amendment? I think what we are missing at the moment is how it works into the tapestry.

—As I understand it, this amendment deals with the start-up dates for the start of legislation and lists the date of commencement of the various items. Amendment No. 13—which I believe I have moved—omits the numbers 9, 10, 18, 29, 36, 49, 59 and 69 and substitutes `and 9'. So 9 is still in there, but the amendment omits seven other numbers. I believe that is because we have voted to omit the relevant items in the body of the legislation. We have removed items Nos 10 and 18 already. Those are the items that deal with prisoners' right to vote. That is my understanding of why this amendment is consequential. As long as the numbers that are in my amendment correspond with the numbers of the items that we have already decided to omit from the bill, it would be consequential. If they do not, obviously we are going to have a messy outcome.
—One could be confused and think that it is Saturday night Keno with all these numbers floating around. I hope that has answered the queries.

—I think this sometimes happens when you go a long way down the track and decide to throw the Senate committee into reverse gear and go about 15 furlongs backwards. Needless to say, I just want to be clear as to the question before the chair. I am clear about Democrats amendment No. 13, sheet 1227. What I am not clear about is in relation to the revision that we are speaking of. I assume that relates to the government amendments.

speech.para: Mr Temporary Chairman, is it correct that you have asked Senator Bartlett to move his amendment as revised? Does `as revised' relate to the recent government amendments? Is that what is occurring? What is the revision?

talk.start.para: —It seems that a lot of these numbers are identical to the amendments you were proposing, the only differences being 9 and 10. We understand from the people who drafted this that Senator Bartlett's amendment is correct. It takes on board your amendments plus two others.
—Now I come back, Mr Tempo rary Chairman, to you explaining to us what the question is before the chair.
—The question before the chair is that Democrats' amendment No. 13, moved in the amended form, which takes on board 9 and 10, be agreed to. Is that clear? Senator Ellison, are you happy with that?

—There is a question I want to ask Senator Bartlett. Senator Bartlett, are you saying that your amendment takes away the commencement dates which related to prisoners? Those commencement dates are no longer relevant because the government's proposal in relation to prisoner voting has been defeated. Therefore, are you are saying that there is no need now for a commencement provision?
—Yes.

—That is what your No. 13 is doing? If that is what the effect of it is, it is appropriate to move that and it would work in with what has been passed to date. The government would oppose that but only in order to maintain its adherence to the principle of prisoner voting. I can see the efficacy of what you are proposing, Senator Bartlett. It does afford what has taken place the opportunity to work.

—Thank you, Minister, for that clarification. You have certainly made my job a little easier. The question is that Democrats amendment No. 13, as moved in the amended form by Senator Bartlett, be agreed to.
—Having disposed of those matters, we now move to opposition amendments Nos 1 to 4 on sheet 1235, as revised.

—These particular amendments effectively go to the very important issue of the closure of the rolls. These items would see the rolls closed three working days after the issue of the writs and would set up a postponement period during which new names could not be added or deleted from the roll as a result of enrolment applications. The postponement period for new electors commences at 6 p.m. on the date of the issue of the writs until the close of polling. This means that no new electors can get on the roll once the election has been called. That is the effect of what the government is proposing.

speech.para: The rationale that is provided for this—and it is a pretty flimsy one, I have got to say—is that the new proof of identity and other cross-checks for new electors will take too long to carry out and will not make the three-day limit. About 80,000 new enrolments occur once the election is called. Closing the rolls so quickly would disenfranchise a huge number of first-time voters. Do not forget that most of these are young people. Even worse, of course, the postponement period for new electors would see all of those 80,000 new voters, who apply to get on the electoral roll when the election is called, disenfranchised.

When an election is called, there is obviously a rush of people who try and get on the electoral roll. They either apply to get on the electoral roll as first-time voters, or they need an update on their electoral enrolment, such as a change of address. The fact that an election is called obviously motivates people to move quickly in this regard. But we all know about electoral behaviour in Australia. It is often not until an election is actually called that many people take this course of action, that they consider the status of their electoral enrolment. We had evidence given by the AEC to the Senate committee showing that a majority of the 320,000 notify a change of address at the last available opportunity. That is just the way it works.

It is clear that the restriction of three days for change of address prior to an election is going to be massively distorting and a real impediment to the democratic process. It could lead to anything up to 200,000 people voting at their previous address. That is not what the intention or the spirit of the Electoral Act is about. These are very unreasonable provisions in the bill and we will oppose them in order to retain the integrity of the Electoral Act.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will also be opposing these sections of the bill, as outlined in my speech during the second reading debate. I will not go through that whole section of the speech again, but I think it is worth recording once again the Democrats' strong opposition to what the government is attempting to do in this legislation.

speech.para: I realise their purported rationale is to deal with minimising the opportunity for electoral fraud. I suppose if you cut everybody off the roll then you have got a chance of minimising electoral fraud, but you are obviously much more likely to minimise electoral participation. That is something that the Democrats are very concerned about. We do not believe there has been very strong evidence of electoral fraud, but there is certainly very strong evidence about the need for maximum electoral participation if our democratic system is going to have any sort of integrity at all.

As has been pointed out, this will effectively disenfranchise about 80,000 people and the Democrats believe that it should be strongly opposed because of the hole it will blow in the integrity of our voting system. Clearly, it will impact not solely but, predominantly, on first time voters—on younger people. Again, these are the very people we are trying to encourage to be involved in the political process. It is these very people who, perhaps even more than the rest of the Australian community, wonder whether politics and government and parliament are really worth the bother; and whether or not they should just ignore it all as something that they cannot really do anything about—as some sort of fairly distasteful show that happens down in Canberra that they cannot impact upon.

All of us, I am sure, want to try to reverse that by whatever means we can. We want to try to encourage younger people to get on the roll to vote, to realise their voice is important, that they can make a difference, that they have a legitimate and crucial part to play in the direction of our democracy and that they have the ability to determine who represents them in the parliament and who forms government.

This measure is clearly going to reduce the incentive and the opportunity for younger people and first-time voters to be involved in the electoral process. If an election is called, under this measure that the government is proposing, at 6 p.m. on the day of writs being issued, that is it—the guillotine comes down. As Senator Faulkner said, the reality for all of us—not just younger people—is that we tend not to get around to something like fixing up our new address on the roll or on a driver's licence until some specific event comes along which motivates us or pushes us into doing that. For most people, that event is the calling of an election.

You can imagine the great degree of enthusiasm that young people and potential first-time voters have when they hear an election is called. They think, `I had better get on the roll; this is my first chance to vote and I am going to make a difference.'

talk.start.para: —No new elector would get on the roll.

—No new elector would get on the roll. They would hear the election called. They would think, `Great. This will be my first chance to make a difference. This will be my first chance to finally have my say about all these policies that the government and various other parties are putting forward.' They would turn up at the electoral office the next day and get told, `Sorry, you are out. The rules were changed. Bugger off.' The Electoral Commission would probably say something more polite than that. Nonetheless, that would be the effect.
—That language is a bit rough. Perhaps you might care to amend it.

—Yes, I apologise. I was putting myself in a young person's mind just for a moment. But basically that is the message they would feel they would be getting from the government and from politicians in general. They would not discriminate and say, `This is the coalition's fault.' They would say, `It is those politicians again. They do not even want us to have a say.' That will be the effect, and that is clearly detrimental to the future functioning of our democracy.

speech.para: Chances are they may not even put in an application at that stage to go on the roll for a later election. Their enthusiasm for the whole process may be such that by the time the next election comes around in two or three years time they will feel even less connected, more disfranchised and less interested than ever. Clearly that is a negative outcome.

In speaking to the previous amendment I said that a possible effect may have been to benefit the coalition but that I would not suggest that was the motivation. With this particular amendment I feel a little more inclined to suggest that that is probably a strong motivation for the coalition because it will clearly disfranchise predominantly younger people. As all of us know, support for the coalition amongst younger people tends to be less than amongst older people, for whatever reason that may be. For that reason alone, I think it is something that should be pointed out and opposed.

But more strongly than that, if we are going to amend the electoral system to benefit one party over another, if there is a proper underlying principle, then that will be the outcome. Clearly the underlying effect of this amendment, more than anything else, will be to disfranchise younger people, to destroy even further their faith and interest in the political process. We already have a major problem with that issue in this country, as I am sure we would all admit. We need to look at implementing measures that will improve that situation, not make it worse.

talk.start.para: —The Greens agree with that. As far as I know, the first Greens legislation ever passed in this country was in 1989 and 1990 in the Tasmanian House of Assembly and it came from Reverend Lance Armstrong, the then member for Bass. The legislation was to protect young voters' rights in the same way we are trying to protect them by opposing this government move here. That was consequent upon an election being called by the then Premier, Mr Gray, on a Wednesday or Thursday afternoon and the rolls closing on the Friday afternoon. A lot of young Tasmanians did not have time to get on the rolls for that election, and they felt very frustrated, I can tell you. We had a lot of outpouring of frustration and anger about that.

speech.para: If we were to support the government move here, we would be aiding and abetting the same situation. It is unconscionable that we should change a current situation to one in which, as other speakers have said, some 80,000 young voters are likely to find themselves unable to vote in their first national election. That would only increase their cynicism as well as their sense of frustration about an electoral system that average citizens already feel too cut off from and too divorced from what goes on in their parliaments. We will not support the government in this move. The Greens will join with the ALP and the Democrats in trying to fend it off.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes the proposal put by the opposition. The government's view has been clearly stated in the second reading speech, and I will not go into it in great detail other than to say that the ideal is for there to be a continual updating of the roll. Past experience shows that over 400,000 transactions occur in the period between the issue of the writ and the close of the rolls. This places a great deal of strain on the Australian Electoral Commission. In that rush of transfers and new enrolments, the commission has to verify that indeed those transfers and enrolments are legitimate. The government is concerned that we concentrate more on those activities outside of the election cycle.

speech.para: As I mentioned earlier, the Electoral Commission has taken up an initiative with the government of Victoria to contact those young people who have just obtained a driver's licence with a view to getting them onto the rolls. This will be pursued with other states. You will see during the course of this year with our referendum that there will be a communications strategy whereby people will be urged to make sure that they update their details on the roll if they have moved or that they get on the roll if they are not on it. That is the ideal situation.

This legislation allows three working days for anyone to notify change of address after the issue of the writ. That excludes public holidays and weekends. The government believes that is sufficient time for a person who is transferring to lodge that detail. In any event, that transferor is not disfranchised because that person is still entitled to vote in their old electorate.

With respect to new enrolments, they make up some 80,000 of the in excess of 400,000 transactions I mentioned. We believe our strategies, which we are pursuing, will ensure that young people are not disfranchised but that it will be administratively more efficient to have enrolment on the day of the issue of the writ. For those reasons, the government maintains its initiative in this regard. This was a recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. For those reasons, the government will oppose the proposal put by the opposition.

talk.start.para: —I understand what the minister is saying and the material that has been put before us in respect of the over 400,000 transactions after the particular time of the issue of the writs. I am not convinced though that that should be the catalyst for amending the legislation, which has been in place for some considerable time and which does give recognition to the principle that persons who are eligible to vote be able to vote.

speech.para: I do not accept the pejorative terms or the inferences by Senator Bartlett and Senator Brown that this is some sort of conspiracy by the government to deny young people their vote. I was on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters years ago. I know this has been a concern of the Electoral Commission for some considerable time. I am very pleased to see that Senator Ellison and the government are taking action between elections to get on the rolls as many people as possible who are eligible to vote, particularly focusing attention on young people. So that does really give the lie to anybody who is criticising the government that this is some sort of attempt to be an electoral gerrymander.

I would suggest to the committee that, if the government's attempts and initiatives are successful, as we all hope they are, at getting on the roll the maximum number of persons, largely young persons, as we know, who are eligible to vote, that will alleviate the situation and the difficulties that are experienced by the Electoral Commission now in respect of the huge number of transactions that take place after the issue of the writs. I believe that we should look to see how these initiatives are going to work out and whether they are going to be successful or not. I do hope that they are, but I am disinclined to vote for the government's amendments to the existing legislation. I believe that the status quo should remain and hope that the initiatives being undertaken by the government will be successful.

talk.start.para: —I wish to respond very briefly to what Senator Harradine said about the spirit of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I think he is right. He accurately reflects what the spirit of the current provisions in the act are about. If this particular schedule of the bill is agreed to, some 80,000 new enrollees are going to be disfranchised. That means that no new elector can get on the roll once the election has been called and, of the 320,000 people who take the opportunity after an election is called to change their address, a very significant number, probably a couple of hundred thousand, will be voting in electorates in which they do not want to vote. They would actually want to enrol for the electorate in which they currently live.

speech.para: This really demonstrates the impact of the provisions in the bill and indicates very strongly the breach of the spirit of the way the Electoral Act has operated. Surely we are not about making it hard for Australians to cast their vote in the electorate in which they reside. We ought to be about reasonable provisions with reasonable time frames allowing the democratic process to proceed, understanding the sorts of constraints that the Electoral Commission have to operate under. They are the sorts of issues that Senator Harradine has also dealt with.

I think this is a real breach of the spirit of the act and the way the electoral process has worked in this country. The provisions in this bill are not provisions that are going to encourage the democratic process. An awful lot of people will either lose the right to vote, or will not vote where they should. We do have a responsibility in this chamber to ensure that the act, which has worked well in this regard, is not changed in a way that will disfranchise so many Australians trying to do the right thing. On this occasion—it is not always the case—I do think that Senator Harradine's comments about the spirit of the act are quite right. I do not think it is something we would want to see changed.

talk.start.para: —The question is that schedule 1, items 11, 12, 14, 28, 30 and 31 stand as printed.
—We now move to schedule 1, items 53 and 54.

—I am opposing items 13 and 15 to 17, and at a later stage hopefully I will get an opportunity to move my consequential amendment to the start-up date. We are dealing here with the issue of the enrolment period and, again, we have proposals which would disfranchise a number of voters, particularly itinerant electors, by requiring those electors to re-enrol within one month of moving. Previously, people were required to reside in their new electorate for a period of one month before being eligible for enrolment in that electorate. They then had 21 days to notify the AEC of their change of enrolment.

speech.para: These items cut that time back to only four weeks. Of course, there is a much greater concern here with itinerant electors. Item 17 seems to actually eliminate the entire category of itinerant electors. Item 17 provides:
Subject to subsection (9), a person ceases to be eligible to be treated as an itinerant elector under this section as soon as the person becomes entitled to be enrolled for a Subdivision.

The thing is that the other items in this group of proposed changes to the act provide that a person becomes entitled to be enrolled for a subdivision immediately, without a waiting period. Of course, then an elector would cease to be treated as an itinerant elector as soon as they moved somewhere.

We did raise this anomaly during the debate on this bill in the House of Representatives, and I want to record in the Hansard the response the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration gave on this issue on behalf of the Australian Electoral Commission. He said:

. . . while the proposed amendments would appear to severely limit an elector's ability to claim itinerant status in the application of the current provisions, the AEC has based the determination of eligibility not solely on the length of residency at a particular address but on whether that address is considered to be a permanent address of the elector—that is, one to which the elector has a fixed intention of returning to live on a permanent basis rather than just a temporary abode for a fixed period of time. The AEC advises that it will continue to adopt this approach in considering applications if the proposed amendments are passed into law.

That is not good enough, and it is not a sufficient response to what I think is a significant issue, a real problem that the government and the AEC probably would have missed if the opposition actually had not drawn their attention to it. So we will not be supporting these provisions, these items, in the bill. I commend the opposition's approach to the committee.

talk.start.para: —I think perhaps you may have jumped a set of proposals there. We are actually talking about items 53 and 54, which are about closing the rolls and the enrolment period.
—I did, indeed. I thought you called me to deal with those items.
—No, we are talking about items 53 and 54 standing as printed, and you have already made your point on that, I think.

—They are consequential provisions to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. I had made, I thought, a very effective point on those—absolutely correct. In relation to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act, of course, the same issue relates to that as relates to the Electoral Act itself. I think the same arguments stand, and I assume the will of the committee would equally apply to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act.
—The question is that schedule 1, items 53 and 54 stand as printed.
—We now move to schedule 1, items 13, 15 to 17, 21 to 23 and 25 to 27. Senator Faulkner has already spoken on this.
—Yes, I think I have spoken on it enough.

—I just indicate on this issue, for the reasons that Senator Faulkner has so eloquently outlined, that, likewise, the Democrats have concerns with the impact of these provisions and will be not supporting those parts of the legislation.

—I agree, and I think the committee needs to think about the effect that these provisions could have on the outcome of an election with people voting across borders in electorates they no longer belong to. We are talking here about a few thousand votes, potentially, in each electorate. You only have to look at the outcome of elections and see how they are decided by less than 100 votes on some occasions to see how this can materially change the outcome of elections, and that is not something that anybody wants. That is why the Greens also oppose these measures and believe that everything should be done to make the rolls correct, to empower voters to vote for the electorate in which they actually live and, of course, as we said before, to make sure that young voters are entitled to vote when it comes to polling day.
—The question is that schedule 1, items 13, 15 to 17, 21 to 23 and 25 to 27 stand as printed.
—We now have a revised amendment to be moved by the opposition.
—I move opposition amendment No. 1 on sheet 1234, revised:

speech.para: This the amendment that I was hanging out to move. It is effectively consequential on the matter we have just dealt with.

talk.start.para: —The question is that the amendment be agreed to.
—The question we now move to is that schedule 1, item 19 stand as printed.

—In dealing with this particular issue we have got a very critical problem in that these items relate to regulations that the parliament has not yet had an opportunity to sight. I have just got a message that they may have actually—
—They went out a couple of days ago.

—You may have sighted them a couple of days ago, minister, but I just heard from my office that they received a copy of them this morning. Would you accept, Minister, through the Temporary Chairman, that that is the case—that they have been provided while this debate is ensuing?
—I thought that they had been provided earlier. I understand that they were provided this morning.

—That is the point I was making, Minister. They have been provided this morning. Because I have been otherwise occupied in the Senate chamber, I for one have not had an opportunity to have a look at them. There is a timing issue here. It is all very well to get these only, I gather, in draft form—even though I have not sighted them yet, but the Minister will confirm this at a later stage—but we have said since May last year, when this legislation was first introduced, that we did not want to support this item until we were satisfied that the draft regulations were acceptable.

speech.para: You have had an awful long time, Minister, to get your act together on this particular issue. I think that is a perfectly reasonable point to make. We have had platitudes from the government that we would be consulted in the drafting of the regulations and that the draft regulations would be made available. But it is nine months after the legislation was first introduced. Finally, the regulations have hit my office this morning. I do not know if they have hit other senators' offices. I suppose it is better that they hit your office before the bill is finally dealt with by the Senate than afterwards, so I will give a modicum of credit for that—but only a modicum, I can tell you. It is simply not good enough. I might say that there have not been any approaches by the government to consult us on the regulations.

We are concerned that the witnessing of proof of identity and citizenship and hand lodgment of enrolment applications provisions and requirements are going to prove so laborious and unreasonable that people will be disfranchised or deterred from pursuing their eligibility.

I have always questioned the government's motivation in relation to this. I think they are motivated by rampant paranoia that there is widespread electoral fraud. That is an unjustified paranoia, and I think it is now starting to diminish a little in the government. If you were going to be that paranoid and you have got hold of the reins of government and you have a good look at some of these issues, you would be starting to think that a little bit of evidence might come your way if there were any justification for the paranoia itself. Of course, there is not. I think it is paranoia rather than a real desire to improve the integrity of the electoral rolls that is motivating the government in this regard.

These provisions will lead to an enormous rise in bureaucratic procedures. They will cost the best part of $4 million a year. We think that those sorts of funds would be far better spent on habitation reviews. It is those sentiments that are guiding the opposition's approach in relation to this particular item.

I suppose we will have an opportunity, given that in 10 minutes the committee will have a break from the laborious examination of this legislation, to look at the draft regulations. I will be able to check when they were actually faxed to my office, at what particular time this morning they actually arrived, given that the government has had nine months to do it. We might be able to have a bit of a look at some of these regulations over the lunch break.

Frankly, the government has not got its act together on this particular item. I think other senators would share my sentiments in relation to that. That is what will guide the opposition's approach. It is disappointing that the government, which has argued so strenuously that these are such serious matters, has not felt that it is able to involve or consult in any way or provide draft regulations to the opposition or any other senators to advance its case. I think its case is extremely flimsy.

talk.start.para: —On that point, we have a list of people which is much the same as the list of people who witness passports. That certainly is something which many Australians have. It is not such a bar to people to go through and find someone from a list of that sort. It is not often when we are debating legislation in the parliament that we have the consequential regulations available for consideration, but in this instance the government had to draft these regulations. We have had the intervening election, which taxed the resources of the AEC, and other matters. We had quite an extensive list here that had to be settled.

speech.para: These regulations are in draft form and they have been circulated. I urge fellow senators from all sides to look at the list because it really is comprehensive. It spans some three pages of people who could witness an enrolment. You have community leaders from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, you have professional people, you have consular people overseas for those Australians who are travelling, you have a number of employees of community groups and women's refuges, part-time and full-time teachers, pilots, a range of people in the area of the judiciary, staff of the Electoral Commission, members of the defence services and people who are involved in Australia Post. You have quite a range of people, even down to ministers of religion within the meaning of the Marriage Act. That really is an expansive list of people who can witness an enrolment.

The current situation simply provides for any person who is eligible to enrol as a voter. That is a very wide class of person indeed. The government thinks that when you are enrolling it is an important transaction between the individual and the state and that there should be a level of scrutiny at that level of enrolment which recognises that fact. I mentioned earlier that when opening a bank account certain things are required. A much lesser requirement is made of someone who is getting onto the electoral roll. After all, that is a very important thing. It entitles you to exercise a very important right as a citizen of this country. So to have a list of people, albeit an expansive one, is important to ensure that the integrity of the process is maintained. This was recommendation No. 2 of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The government is strongly of the view that there should be this scrutiny.

I understand that senators have been provided with a copy of these draft regulations. I have other copies here in case anyone wants to have a look. I see that Senator Bartlett would require a copy. I ask senators to have a look at this list. It also deals with the agencies where you can lodge your application for enrolment. That is important, too. It deals with things like the verification of Australian citizenship and the original documentation that is required from a person who wishes to enrol. So these draft regulations are not just dealing with a list of witnesses. There are other matters which have to be dealt with, as well. That, as you can see, was of some detail. I don't know whether Senator Brown has a copy of these regulations.

talk.start.para: —Only in my office.
—And Senator Harradine as well?
—Yes.

—I urge this government proposal on the Senate as being a sensible one, and one which will not act as a bar to any person wishing to get on the roll. It will not act as an impediment. It will only heighten the integrity of the process of enrolling.

—I haven't seen these before, Minister, so I would not mind a bit of time to go through them—although I would be disinclined to support what is in the bill from my standing position on behalf of the Democrats because I would have concerns that any restriction on witnesses for people who wish to enrol may disenfranchise people. I am not convinced that such a restriction is necessary.
—The question is that schedule 1, item 19 stand as printed.
—We now move to schedule 1, item 20.
—I think I heard Senator Harradine sotto voce vote `aye' then, didn't I?
—That was my understanding, yes.
—Just to clarify the matter not in a sotto voce way, yes, I voted aye.

—I just didn't hear you, Senator; I should have been watching for those lips to move. I stand on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. The only reason I raise this is that I don't want to have an unnecessary division, that's all, particularly at 12.44. I am very popular, as you know, in the Senate but my popularity might just go down the scales a little if I called a division that the opposition would lose at 12.44, when people might be thinking about their luncheon break.
—I am not going to rule on your popularity, Senator, but there is no point of order on the matter that you have raised. It is almost 12.45, which is probably an appropriate time to report progress.
—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

—I rise to inform the Senate that tonight in my home town of Newcastle there is a very important public meeting. It is the Drug Crisis Public Meeting. I have lent my support to this meeting because it is absolutely vital that we start to find more effective solutions to the drug crisis facing our nation. The meeting tonight will have four themes: the drug problem and its effects; remedies being used today; rehabilitation today; and efforts by governments to combat the drug problem both here and overseas, with special emphasis on the Swedish experience.

speech.para: A panel of experts will address the issues. We will have Father Chris Riley from the Youth Off the Streets program who will be talking about the problem as it affects youth, and Angela Woods, the mother of Anna Woods, will discuss educating youth to avoid drugs. We will hear about rehabilitation practices here and overseas and the New South Wales shadow minister for health, Jillian Skinner, will release some of the coalition's policy for combating drugs. As yet no state ALP member has agreed to discuss their drug position, but I will get to the Carr government's record on this matter a little later.

One of the most important issues to be discussed tonight is the concept of custodial rehabilitation. Susan and Allan Forrester, who have spent seven years and $50,000 fighting the heroin addiction of their daughter, will speak tonight as advocates of custodial rehabilitation. Members and senators might recall that in the weekend press both last weekend and the one before they told their story to the whole world, so desperate are they in their fight against drugs. They have seen what drugs have done to their own family and they do not want this to happen to other families.

The drug crisis as it has spread through the families of the nation has reached epidemic proportions and it is time to consider some new measures. I know from talking to mothers, fathers and families of drug addicts how hard it is for drug users to help themselves. The craving for that one hit is often too strong for any individual to overcome once they have been hooked on drugs.

I have been told, `If only there was a place where addicts could safely get medical help to overcome their addiction without being able to sign themselves out or get access to drugs.' The current problem is that addicts can leave their rehabilitation program and it only takes one hit to negate all the good work that has been done.

Custodial rehabilitation for addicts who have been convicted of criminal offences overcomes this problem. When convicted, for example, by a drug court—which has just been established in New South Wales—an arrangement can be made where, for a reduced sentence, and with an agreement to spend the last year of that sentence in custodial rehabilitation, these young people can be put into a drug free environment and get real help. Without drugs and with other support programs, we can actually help them put their lives back together again. Unlike a lot of rehabilitation programs that are currently operating, under this system they cannot sign themselves in and out, and they are not tempted back into their old way of life.

The current drug programs are not working effectively enough. I am not saying that this new approach is the be-all and end-all by any means. We need a whole range of strategies to help ameliorate the drug crisis. We need to put more resources in at both state and federal levels, and we need a greater range of programs to assist in this process. I have heard from people with personal experience that the way to really help an addict who wants to get clean is to make sure that they cannot get access to the drugs, and then they are given professional support.

This crisis must be tackled, particularly in the state of the New South Wales which has the worst record. It seems that the Carr government is very slow in moving on this. What they have said as part of their election promise is that they will hold a drug summit after the election. We have the worst record in New South Wales. This state Carr ALP government has now been in power for four years and their solution is to hold a crisis meeting after the election. The crisis is actually happening now and addicts and their families have waited long enough.

In the report Drugs, money and governments, the Carr government was identified as the worst performing state government in dealing with its drug problem. The report found that in New South Wales expenditure on health related programs to deal with drug treatment and rehabilitation actually dropped in 1996-97. The report says:

It is disappointing to note the very poor performance of the New South Wales government. New South Wales is the largest state and arguably has some of the most significant drug problems, but has failed to prioritise drug problems or make a serious commitment to reducing drug related harm.
In 1996 half of Australia's heroin overdoses occurred in New South Wales, even though it only accounts for around one-third of the nation's population.

No-one from the Carr government, not even one of the local Labour MPs—and I have written to all of them—has agreed to come to tonight's meeting or to participate. I suppose we cannot be too surprised about that; they must be very embarrassed about their own government's record on this matter. Meanwhile the opposition health spokesperson, Jillian Skinner, is eager to share what the coalition will do to fight drugs. She will be there tonight and will actually announce part of the drug policy at tonight's meeting.

At a federal level the coalition government can be very proud of what it has done. It has released the biggest anti-drug strategy in Australia's history with its $290 million Tough on Drugs strategy. This is already making significant progress in fighting the drug crisis. It is a four-pronged approach over four years: firstly, protecting our borders by giving more than $50 million to protect Australia from the international drug trade; secondly, busting the dealers by providing more than $100 million to fight this type of crime; thirdly, funding for schools to educate our children about the dangers of drug abuse; and fourthly, the coalition's policy of zero tolerance of illicit drugs in our schools.

These approaches are combining to help fight this problem, but probably the most important area we really need to focus on is treatment. At the federal level, we are putting $100 million into this program to assist drug users kick the habit and to provide support for their families. This includes more than $50 million over four years for non-government treatment services.

The coalition's Tough on Drugs policy is the biggest single anti-drug initiative taken in the country. In addition, the Prime Minister recently announced funding of $60 million for a new youth homelessness early intervention program. The funding will provide almost 100 new services across the country for assistance for young people and their families. These services will be aimed at reducing youth homelessness, as well as supporting young people who may be at risk of youth suicide, drug and alcohol abuse and prolonged unemployment.

The federal government has been proactive on this issue, but I believe that all governments need to commit more resources to rehabilitation. For this reason, I look forward to tonight's public meeting in Newcastle, where real solutions to the drug crisis will be discussed. I look forward to sharing with the Senate the outcomes of tonight's public meeting.

talk.start.para: —In September 1996, nearly 2½ years ago, former Senator Bob Collins asked questions of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service in the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee about honey exports to New Zealand. He asked when negotiations with New Zealand had commenced for both the exportation of honey from Australia to that country and the importation of New Zealand honey to Australia. Dr Kahn, a senior AQIS officer, told the Senate committee that we had been importing New Zealand honey for four years. She advised, incorrectly, that some honey from Western Australia was being exported to New Zealand.

speech.para: However, in a subsequent hearing of that committee, AQIS corrected its earlier evidence. The new answer was that New Zealand had agreed in principle to let our honey in but wanted assurances about areas' freedom from certain diseases on the basis that that would not be an unreasonable request. The hurdle put in place by the New Zealand government frankly did not appear that high at the time. Dr Kahn advised the committee that:
The information required for exports out of Western Australia is simply surveillance information—

That sounds innocent enough. She said that her advice from Western Australia was that the state already had data it thought sufficient to satisfy the New Zealanders. She also suggested that it might be possible to establish heat treatment procedures to enable exports of honey from other states.

In a written answer to the committee from AQIS, the committee was made aware of the full facts of the case. AQIS said that negotiations commenced in 1990 and New Zealand honey producers were given access to our market in 1991. AQIS also advised that it was given draft conditions by New Zealand for access to its market in November 1995. New Zealand also requested further information about heat treatment to eliminate European foul brood as it is called. I asked that same question again on 26 February this year. The answer was basically the same. We continue to allow New Zealand honey to access our markets, but according to Dr Kahn's memory, we still cannot access theirs. That is still dependent on preparation of a case and presentation of data to the New Zealand ministry.

The honey industry is not the biggest industry in Australia, but it is an important industry. According to the Australian beekeeping industry, particularly in a report prepared for that group at the beginning of last year, the gross value of production for the industry is between $60 million and $65 million a year. It is, however, an important income generator for rural and regional communities, and it is estimated that between 9,000 and 12,000 tonnes of honey are exported per annum. It is not a big number but it is important enough.

I raise the issue today not only on behalf of the Australian honey industry—who you would understand have become completely frustrated with their failure to be granted access to the New Zealand market; in fact, the information that has been given to me indicates that they have all but given up hope—but also in the wider context of the Howard government's approach to both trade liberalisation and the legitimate domestic industries. Take trade negotiations with New Zealand over honey. New Zealand accessed our market quick smart, but we are still waiting, nearly eight years after our application, to access theirs. Unfortunately, the evidence suggests that it is the view of this government that the Australian honey industry is not big enough to worry about. The tone of the latest answer would appear to confirm that view. In fact, it was quite a jocular answer, as I recall it.

When Labor was in office, the Australian government did facilitate New Zealand honey's access to our market but, apparently now, according to the government, it is really up to the Australian industry itself to obtain access to the New Zealand market. In the Howard administration, there is an unfortunate parallel between this industry and other intensive rural activities. Their interests are not high on the government's agenda when it comes to assisting them to expand or when it comes to protecting them. In this case, I am talking about the quite legal protection under World Trade Organisation rules if they suffer damage from surging imports.

Apparently, this government sees industries such as the chicken industry, pork industry and the feedlot industry as expendable and appears to be treating them accordingly. Unfortunately, I must say from the point of view of my state, this theme appears likely in the Howard government's approach in the upcoming budget to a number of industries in Tasmania. At the last federal election there were two federal programs that were the subject of much debate in Tasmania: the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme and the Tasmanian Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme. The continuation of both of those schemes is vital to industry in Tasmania. Together they provide relief against cost disadvantages faced by many Tasmanian industries and, therefore, they underpin many jobs that rely upon trade and transport across Bass Strait.

In the lead-up to the federal election, the Howard government committed itself to upgrading the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme to the tune of an additional $15 million a year. The Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman, also committed the government to a continuation of the Tasmanian Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme, but gave no commitment as to an adequate level of funding. I pursued the future of both schemes at recent estimates hearings because I was interested in just where the government was on these matters. A senior officer from the department told me that cabinet was yet to consider the recommendations of the Nixon inquiry into the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme. He said the actual impact of the review on the scheme would not be known until cabinet actually makes a final decision in the budget context about the acceptance of the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme review recommendations.

The minister responsible for administration of the scheme, Senator Ian Macdonald, gave me an assurance that the additional funding of $15 million was an election commitment. I knew that already, as did many people in Tasmania, from the election campaign. He said the commitment would go into the budget process. We knew that as well. But he could not say what would come out at the other end of that process. Even though he is directly responsible for the TFES, he was unable to say which of the Nixon recommendations might succeed and which might not succeed in the cabinet process.

Officers of the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry also confirmed that there is no money for the Tasmanian Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme next year—that is, the scheme will literally run out of money on 30 June. That scheme was introduced in 1989 by a Labor government to provide assistance to cover blue water freight, wharfage and unloading costs associated with shipping wheat and other grain, I think, across Bass Strait. It was reviewed in 1993 and 1994 and was extended for a further five years at a rate of $2.7 million a year. Funding was also provided to help meet the costs of upgrading handling and storage capacity in Tasmania. This was based on dollar-for-dollar funding arrangements with the state government. But soon after taking office in March 1996, the Howard government all but gutted the scheme. It removed all infrastructure assistance and cut the actual subsidy to just $1.2 million for a period of three years.

During the estimates I asked officials from the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry whether the government had reviewed the effectiveness of the scheme. I was told there had been no review. This government has not checked to see whether the Tasmanian Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme needs more money or less money. It had not checked to see whether the scheme should be improved in any way. So all of the Tasmanian industries underpinned by that scheme—such as the chicken industry, the pork industry, the stockfeed industry and the baking industry—and the 1,600 workers in those industries whose jobs rely on the scheme will not know until the second week in May whether the scheme—and possibly their jobs—will still be there after June.

I also asked the government whether it had looked at the possible impact on these industries and the workers who work in them if the Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme is shut down. Surprising to some perhaps the answer was no, there had been no such inquiry. So federal cabinet, apparently, will consider the future of the scheme without any assessment of its effectiveness and without any assessment of the employment consequences of its termination. This will, therefore, be a decision based on politics and not on proper analysis and sensible public policy. Frankly, this is no way to do business.

Given the importance of these intensive industries to Tasmania and the jobs which they sustain and given the lack of any assessment of the effectiveness or otherwise of the Tasmanian Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme, this government has no choice—I say no choice—but to continue its funding beyond 30 June. It is also important that a formal commitment to the future of the scheme be given as a matter of urgency. As I say, people should not have to wait until after the budget to know what their future is. Such a decision, therefore, cannot wait until the second week in May. Those businesses, industries and employees need to know. The government should also as a matter of urgency initiate discussions with the users of the scheme to see where it might be improved. Frankly, if this government is not prepared to undertake these discussions, then perhaps the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee might have to do its job for it.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.06 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Will the minister now retract her statement from question time yesterday when she said, `I think it is very sad that those who purport to speak for the poor and the disadvantaged frequently do so with total ignorance?' Has the minister's attention been drawn to Treasurer Costello's comments on the same Anglican Church report, when he said, `I think this is probably the strongest statement you have ever seen from a church in favour of a GST,' and wholeheartedly welcomed the report? Has the minister passed on to the Treasurer her strong view that the report he praised and welcomed is based on total ignorance? Will the minister now admit that she clearly had not familiarised herself with the contents of the report before she wandered into the Senate to bucket the Anglican Church?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —When I was asked that question yesterday, I was particularly concerned that we constantly hear from people, who work either in the religious area or in the community welfare area, who have not done their homework before making statements on areas for which they do not have specialist expertise. This was not par ticularly directed to my own church; it is frequently the case. I have seen it happen when the Labor Party was in government, and it has not stopped. I have a pretty good impression, for instance, of Anglicare in the provision of services. My portfolio pays quite a lot of money to Anglicare, as well as Centacare and other community organisations, for the provision of services to needy people in our community. It does not mean to say that they are experts on the tax system. In the announcement that was made yesterday by the Anglican media, Anglicare was arguing against a tax on food. Anglicare obviously has not done its homework, because it is crystal clear from the evidence that has been given to the Senate committees by a long list of experts in this area that taxing food is equitable, is simple and is the best way to go for Australia.

answer.para: We do not want to have small business tied up in knots with great overheads, such as in Britain which has so many exemptions that small business finds it a real burden, we do not want to go that route, because we believe small business has the best chance of helping needy people in Australia get a job, get off welfare dependence and not need the support of the state. That is obviously the best outcome for everybody. I would have thought that the Anglican Church, like other churches and community organisations, would also believe that welfare dependency is not the best option. If you can help people get off welfare and into a job, you are doing them the best service you can.

If small business is tied up in knots with the exemptions to a complicated indirect tax system, we have done small business no good and we have potentially done no good for those who need jobs. We on this side of the parliament are concerned about the equity of the system too. The evidence that has been given to the Senate committees is quite clear—the expenditure by rich families and poor families is pretty much constant on such basics as food and clothing, it is reasonable to continue to use the CPI as a determinant, and across the board families are treated equally and will not be disadvantaged by the measures. No, none of those families will be worse off.

The Labor Party can make a lot of noise and has continued to do so, but it is not only the government making these allegations about equity and simplicity but also the most respected tax experts in our country. I think it would be wiser of church bodies and community organisations who do not have the expertise to take careful note of what the experts have given by way of evidence.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note your claims about these organisations not having sought any expert information, which confirms that you are not across what the witnesses have been saying to us in our hearings.
