I note that you also said in your answer that small businesses could be tied up in knots with compliance costs, et cetera. Why is it that you would argue against compliance costs for small business but not compliance costs for charities like Anglicare—one of the organisations that has said that this will be a great contributor to the costs of their organisation and therefore make it harder for them to deliver the very services that you say you want? Minister, are you also going to raise your points of difference with the Treasurer?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Perhaps another piece of information would help Senator Crowley. The tax office has estimated that Australia will have less than half the number of tax administrators as Britain have per capita. Australia will have one tax official per 390 businesses, while Britain has one for every 149 businesses due to the large number of exemptions in the UK especially on food. That is a pretty important piece of information, Senator Crowley, which I am sure you did not have before. It would also be interesting for organisations like Anglicare, because if Anglicare had that information then they might have a slightly different approach to the equity or otherwise of the package. I have their press release right here. It is pretty clear that they talk about reducing the heavy burden that a GST imposes on the less well-off. The experts across the community say otherwise. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Minister, the coalition's tax reforms will deliver tax cuts worth $13 billion a year, remove the worst state taxes, reduce export costs by $4.5 billion a year and reduce costs to business by $10 billion a year. What would be the impact for small business and jobs, however, if food were exempted from tax reform?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I think we all know how vital small business is to job creation in this country. Indeed, something like 50 per cent of the work force is now employed in the small business sector; and, of the 1.2 million new jobs net over the last decade, more than 90 per cent have been in small business. So it is clearly critical to ensure that small business is not handicapped, that it does not have lead in its saddlebags when it is trying to get on with the business of earning a living and employing more Australians. So what would be the consequences if we were to go down this minefield that the Democrats and the Labor Party are advocating? Just look at Canada, for example. This is the sort of nonsense that you get when you try to draw these distinctions, when you try to work out where the boundary lines are. Revenue Canada says:

answer.para: The federal government is introducing amendments to clarify and simplify the tax treatment of salad sandwiches and other prepared foods. The new rules clarify that salads that are canned or vacuum sealed are zero rated. Sandwiches and similar products will be subject to the GST unless they are frozen.
Then it had to put out a change, saying:
On page 7 paragraph 40 of this publication, please delete the reference to gingerbread houses. Gingerbread houses and similar products are generally zero rated and not taxable at 7 or 15 per cent.

So trying to exempt food would be an absolute nightmare, a legal maze, a quagmire into which small business would sink without any compensation for it. In the UK they have sought to exempt food. What does that mean? You get these inevitable boundary distinctions between `Is it raw, is it processed, is it fro zen?' The rule is that, if sold at the ambient temperature, it is exempt. What happens is that you sell someone a cold pie across the counter so that it is exempt, and then you offer to heat it up for him free of charge. If you go into a milk bar on a very hot day wanting to buy a cold drink, you have to pay more if it is frozen because it then attracts a VAT. So you get all these extraordinary propositions. Confectionary is exempt. How do you define `confectionary'? It is defined as `any item of sweetened prepared food which is normally eaten with the fingers'. So, in other words, presumably a lollipop bar is exempt, but a muesli bar is not.
Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I do not know what Senator Schacht eats—probably everything with his fingers. So he would be in there demanding an exemption. You just cannot have this going on. Here is another classic: standard biscuits include gingerbread men decorated with chocolate, unless it amounts to no more than a couple of dots for eyes. Fruit and vegetable pops are zero rated. So fruit and vegetable, on the face of it, is exempt. But if it is sold as an accompaniment to a hot meal, then it is not. So on it goes. Juice and juice concentrates are at a standard rating, whereas fruit and vegetables are zero rated. Corn chips are zero rated; potato chips are not. `What about yoghurt?' I hear you ask. All sizes of yoghurt will be zero rated when supplied in grocery or convenience stores. This includes single servings sold individually, except when supplied in restaurants and other eating or food service establishments for immediate consumption. `Immediate' is another critical word; if it is `delayed' it is different. Supplies of yoghurt made through vending machines and single servings of frozen yoghurt remain subject to the GST. On and on it goes, all in aid of lawyers' picnics, no doubt. All the smart draftsmen will be having a field day.

answer.para: This is an administrative jungle. What will happen is that small business will spend more and more time on less and less, so that eventually they will have to spend most of their time going to see the lawyers and the accountants in order to arrange how to success fully wind up their business. How does that come about? Because of all the unnecessary paperwork and boundary distinctions that you lot still seem to support. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Out of concern for the manufacturers of gingerbread men and all the other small business men and women who would have to deal with the nightmare, perhaps the minister might be kind enough to outline the consequences in terms of administration costs to small business if the government were to cave in to the nonsense we hear from the other side of the chamber.
—His brains are zero rated!

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —You will be entirely exempt on that count, can I assure you, Senator Campbell. Small business operators would spend all their time sitting by the fax machine, scanning the legal notices, waiting for the latest amendment and change, attending training courses and reading the mail for the latest updates from the tax office. The Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants estimates that attempts to exempt food from the GST would cost the economy over $100 million a year in compliance costs. You have heard Senator Newman say that, in the UK, they have more than twice as many tax inspectors as we have.

answer.para: So, what would happen is that you would have a huge hairsplitting brigade. You would have people hiding around corners, waiting to see whether you actually sold something hot or cold. You would have all the smart operators trying to artificially arrange their food so that they redefined `ambient temperature' or they were able to process it in a particular way. The challenges are endless but all to the detriment of small business—and this is not what the game ought to be about at all. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Air Force: Airspace Trial

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, Senator Newman. Does the minister now regret her refusal to defend the Australian Air Force at estimates last week? Does the minister still have no opinion about the nature of the allegations made of the Air Force by Dick Smith after those allegations have been systematically and comprehensively refuted by senior officials of the department she represents?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer is no.

—My question is also to Senator Newman, but it is a sensible one—that is the difference. As the whole world knows, the coalition government has proposed a sweeping reform of the Australian tax system, with compensation for low income earners. The minister would be aware of recent endorsements of the compensation proposed by the coalition government as part of its tax reform. Minister, would you please inform the Senate of the responses to those compensation measures by those very same people?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Yes, it is true that one of the peak welfare lobby groups in Australia, namely ACOSS, has concluded that low income earners on average would be better off under the tax reforms. The Australian Council of Social Service have appeared before the Senate select committee on a new tax system. At the committee hearing and in their submission to the committee, ACOSS have recognised that the government's compensation package for people on low incomes exceeds the average increase in the cost of living. That is in line with what the government has said all along since the release of a new tax system. The compensation package of a four per cent increase in all maximum rates of social security, veteran and student pensions and allowances provides a 1.5 per cent real increase in the value of these payments. This 1.5 per cent increase is on top of compensation for the effect of the tax package on the consumer price index.

answer.para: The ACOSS submission demonstrated that adequate compensation is in the package for age pensioners, couples with children, sole parents, and single and couple recipients of Newstart, and for sickness payments and disability support pension. The ACOSS submission also noted substantial strength in the government's proposals, such as reducing by over 20 per cent effective marginal tax rates for most low income families, maintaining an integrated system of family assistance for working and non-working families, simplifying the system of family income support by combining 12 separate forms of assistance to families into three, substantially increasing the rate of assistance provided to sole parent families and retaining a separate system of payments to assist parents with the cost of child care.

It is interesting that those who would soon make judgment on this tax reform package are not prepared to listen to what ACOSS has to say about it. It is very pleasing that ACOSS has recognised these elements of the tax reform package. The lessening of poverty traps, which were left to run unchecked during the Labor years, the ones facing low income groups and the greater assistance that is provided to families, are cornerstones of the tax reforms and should, one would have thought, had the unanimous endorsement of all parties in the parliament. But the ALP response to ACOSS was simply one of displeasure and discomfort, because they have backed the wrong horse. Australia needs a new tax system. Australia's families need it. ACOSS blew the whistle through their Melbourne Institute study as to how people would be advantaged by tax reform.

subdebateinfo.title: Social Security Payments: Proceeds of Sale of New South Wales Power Industry

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Can the minister inform the Senate and Australian pensioners whether a one-off payment from the sell-off of the New South Wales power industry would be classified as income, assets or a gift for the purposes of the Social Security Act? Can the minister confirm that, if it is classified as income, this payment will reduce or eliminate a fortnight's benefit, drastically reducing the cash in hand for low income pensioners and recipients of benefits? If shares are classified as an asset, is it not possible that this bribe could affect beneficiaries through the operation of the assets test threshold, deeming rules and the rules for health concession cards? If the cash or shares are classified as a gift, which would reduce the effect on social security benefits, does this not highlight the vote buying intention of Ms Chikarovski's policy—straight out gifts for votes?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I do not have all the detail of the proposal. Nevertheless, I am very happy to help the chamber in general terms as to how these dividends would be treated by Social Security. The shares or cash in lieu of shares are not treated as income for social security pensioners, and that is consistent with the treatment of shares that were received as part of the demutualisation processes for example in AMP. The shares would be treated as financial assets under the assets test and deemed to be earning income. Money in lieu of shares which is held by the customer, for example in a bank account, will be a financial asset and deemed. I do recall that the back to school payment that was paid by the New South Wales government from 1998 was treated in the same way. The bottom line is that for most customers, as I am advised by my department, there would be no impact on their rate of pension.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, if the shares are not classified as an asset, as you have indicated they will be treated, is it not quite likely that this bribe actually could affect pensioners and beneficiaries through the operation of the assets test threshold, deeming rules and the rules for health concession cards? You mentioned the back to school allowance of the New South Wales government. Minister, is it not likely that this policy of Ms Chikarovski is far more likely to affect pensioners than the back to school allowance?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Clearly Senator Faulkner is not aware of the fact that most people applying for assistance under social security legislation never get knocked out by assets tests because they are fairly generous and people do not reach them. The addition of $1,100 worth of shares is most unlikely to take people over the assets test limit. The advice of my department, which has a very good handle on what the assets are of people on our payments, is that for most customers there would be no impact on their assets whatsoever and their pension.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, is it true that there are 2.4 million people employed in small business? Is it true that federal unfair dismissal applications for small business in 1998 have halved to 2,861, a minute percentage of those employees? Has the minister read the evidence from Australia Business Ltd that small business is woefully ignorant of the 1996 changes to the unfair dismissal provisions within the Workplace Relations Act? Since the government spent nearly $20 million telling Australians about tax before legislation was even introduced, how much has the government spent and how much does it intend spending on educating one million small businesses on the changes to federal unfair dismissal laws which did pass the parliament and are working well and have halved the rate?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I cannot, off the top of my head, confirm the numbers of those small businesses or those employed in small businesses. It sounds about right. I do not know the number of applications or whether they have halved or any other figure, but obviously these figures move around a fair bit. Yesterday I think I quoted a figure of something in the order of 15,000 and an aggregate of something like 55,000 over a period of several years. Quite clearly, any level of applications that are not particularly meritorious but result in commercial compromise decisions being made in order to basically get on with the job are fundamentally unhelpful. They are not in aid of protecting those who have been wrongly deprived of their employment. In many instances, they are simply a prospective way of trying to get additional funds out of an employer.

answer.para: I do not think it is correct to say that small business is woefully ignorant about the unfair dismissal proposals. These are a matter of community notoriety. You do not have to be in small business to know that this is a major problem. All of the small business peak organisations, who presumably survey their members on a regular basis, will tell you in spades that this is far and away a very big matter of concern for small business. You do not have to be a world champion to be aware of all the representations that are made to us by all sorts of people who are actual and prospective small business operators. They all know as a matter of commonsense that, if you are going to be tied up in red tape, if you are going to have the might of the trade union movement rushing you off to the arbitration commission—no doubt keeping themselves gainfully employed whilst clogging up the small businesses—it is not in anyone's best interests.

I do not accept for a moment that there is a woeful level of ignorance. However, there may well still be a need to inform people about the way in which a majority of parties in this Senate chamber have consistently refused to support very sensible amendments—ones which we took to the last election and which we had made abundantly clear was a critical part of our package of flexing up the labour market. I think a lot more people need to understand who did it, not just this amorphous term `the Senate blocked them'. The fact is that the Labor Party blocked them, with the Democrats' help. That is how they came to be blocked. If either of those parties had chosen to acknowledge that we ran on this issue and to look at the evidence of a number of small businesses, they would not have been able to get away—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. I am finding the minister's answer helpful, but the question was: how much are you spending, and will you spend, on educating them?
—There is no point of order.

—I will find out the precise figures, but if Senator Murray was putting to me that the number of cases actually determined has fallen quite significantly then, of course, that would be a meaningless statistic. It would simply mean that a lot more were settled because people were not prepared to go right through the torture—
—Applications.
—For all sorts of reasons these numbers can move around. I will find out what the precise figure is and get back to you.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the minister's response. Does the minister know that the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says that half of all small businesses in Tasmania are in fear of the federal unfair dismissal laws but that the total number of small business applications was only 56 in Tasmania? Does the minister know that 53 per cent of unfair dismissal applications are resolved in favour of employers? Is it not true that only 2,861 unfair dismissal applications for small business is an irrelevant fact to the government, and that the reality is that you just want to hire and fire at will?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Murray's bottom line reveals his prejudice in the matter. This is recognised around the world as a very significant inhibitor to job creation. To have a sword of Damocles hanging over the heads of small business—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —If 53 per cent are resolved in favour of employers, I do not know what that tells you. It probably means that, in most instances, the applicants give it away at the last minute when they know they do not have a case. It can tell you anything. Those sorts of statistics are just not helpful. Certainly the number of applications is quite relevant, because the more there are, the more the problem, but there should not need to be very many at all. I do not accept for a moment that there are thousands of employers going around deliberately wanting to sack people for no good reason. I do not accept that proposition. I do, however, accept that there are occasions when there are some—
—What about Patrick's?
—Don't get us going on Patrick's. There are some occasions when rogue employers will act wrongly, just as there will be employers who will harass employees wrongly. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. I refer to the repeated claims that the minister makes that those on low incomes will not suffer under a GST and to her dismissal of the government's critics. How can the minister maintain that the many people her department assists will not suffer, when her department was not involved in the development of the tax package, her department was not involved in the modelling of the tax package and her department has admitted it has done no work to determine the impact of the tax package on its own clients?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I am afraid the premise on which the senator's question was based is utterly wrong. Therefore, there is nothing to answer.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the minister says it is the wrong premise, can the minister explain what action she has taken to discipline the officers of her department who gave that evidence to the community affairs committee only last week? The department's evidence was that there was no modelling, there was no involvement by the department and they had done no analysis of the impact on its clients. If the department lied—because you are suggesting that they have lied to us—what have you done to correct it?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I am suggesting no such thing. I am saying that an officer from my department at the most senior level was seconded to Treasury for the whole process.

—My question is to the minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I refer to a letter from Computer Sciences Corporation saying that the corporation has `made a commitment to the Minister of Education' to donate computer equipment being replaced in electoral offices `to the Computer for Schools Program'. I ask the minister whether the minister for education has insisted on that commitment?

—I can advise Senator Brown that the company concerned, CSC, has committed itself to supplying about 80 per cent of the 5,200 desktop PCs replaced since last November to schools as part of the Computers for Schools program. This 80 per cent target is one which, I understand, will be achieved and can be achieved, notwithstanding what has been said in relation to electorate staff having access to the computers which I think are in the region of three years old. There is no problem whatsoever with this program meeting its goals. In fact, last year, when I was minister for schools, CSC was well on the way to getting these computers out to the various schools across Australia. There has been no necessity, that I am aware of, for the minister to make any insistence at all. As I understand it, CSC is on target for its 80 per cent commitment and that can be achieved as well as providing other computers to electorate staff.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question, as that was an unsatisfactory answer. I put it to the minister that the 20 per cent is the figure that applies to those computers that are in MPs' electorate offices, so that the computers are going to come from elsewhere in the bureaucracy and go to schools, but, when it comes to MPs' offices—
—Your question, Senator?

—Is it a fact that the minister is not going to insist on the commitment that the computers from MPs' offices go to the Australian schools program? I note—for the minister's edification—that the letter from Computer Sciences Corporation did not say 80 per cent. It said `all the replaced Personal Computers and printers in the electorate office' of MPs `would be donated to the program'.

—As I said earlier, CSC Australia has committed itself to 80 per cent of those computers going to the Computers for Schools program. I do not think I can make it any clearer than that. The commitment to the electorate staff, as I understand it, does not impinge upon that commitment; and that is the end of it.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Mobile Home and Caravan Park Site Fees

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Does the minister recall that, during the recent election campaign, the government assured residents of mobile home and caravan parks—most of whom are clients of her department—that under the GST they would be treated the same as other renters, such as residents in flats? Is it true the government maintained that the site fee would be input taxed—that is, that the operator would have to pay—and this price increase would not be passed on to residents? Is it further true that, despite these earlier assurances, the government is now proposing to apply the GST directly to the site fee paid by residents—that is, 100 per cent of the fee paid by short-term residents and 50 per cent of the fee paid by long-term residents? How does the minister explain this turnaround?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Mobile home owners will not be disadvantaged under the GST. The effect for long-term residents in mobile homes will be similar to the effect for private renters—that is, around 2.3 per cent. That increase is more than covered by the increases to pensions and benefits mentioned.

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The coalition government was re-elected with a clear mandate to reform Labor's outdated, 30-year-old, totally failed tax regime. Will the minister explain how tax reform will benefit our indigenous Australians, particularly those living in remote areas?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferris for the question and thank her also for her interest in tax reform and her representation of South Australians—South Australian Aboriginal communities as well. I am pleased to be able to say that the tax package will be of considerable benefit to indigenous Australians, particularly those living in remote and isolated areas. In fact, all low income people living in remote areas, whether indigenous or not, will benefit from the government's tax reform package. In developing the package, we have been very careful to ensure that people who are geographically isolated get as much benefit from tax reform as people living in cities and towns. In specific terms, increases in social security payments and income tax cuts are part of a raft of important compensation measures. These measures will ensure that indigenous people on low incomes, income support and CDEP not only are compensated for the impact of the goods and services tax but also share in the gains of the new system.

answer.para: Social security payments will be increased by 4 per cent to cover an estimated cost of living increase of around 1.9 per cent. Income support benefits will be kept 1.5 per cent higher than they would have been had the normal indexation arrangements applied. In remote areas, where costs can be higher, we have allowed sufficient margin to ensure people are not disadvantaged. Even research by Allen Consulting, commissioned by ATSIC, suggests a cost of living impact of less than four per cent. It also has to be remembered that the indigenous median age is about half that of the wider community. Indigenous families are larger and younger, so they will also receive substantial benefits from increased family allowances.

While some food items might increase, many will, in fact, be cheaper because of the abolition of wholesale sales tax. The reduction of diesel fuel excise will significantly cut transport costs for heavy vehicles, by up to 19 cents a litre. These savings will be passed on to consumers and will be of particular benefit to people living in remote and isolated areas. I note that the Road Transport Forum and the Northern Territory Road Transport Association agree with that proposition. They say that the reduction in diesel excise costs will result in reduced transport costs. They see benefits flowing on to consumers at the supermarket shelf and the petrol bowser. Community groups and businesses in remote communities will also benefit from a range of new measures. This includes an average 3.2 per cent reduction in operating costs.

So, Madam President, I have much pleasure in informing Senator Ferris—although she did not particularly need that information because she was aware of it, to a large degree, but I think many people are unaware—of the positive benefits for remote indigenous communities because of the overall nature of the tax package, which will compensate them disproportionately to those in cities. This is because of the demographic factors that are included in the tax package.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Can the minister explain the reason behind her refusal to schedule a meeting with the state and territory ministers for disability issues until, I believe, the second week in April, despite expressing concern at the high level of unmet need with disability services? Is the minister aware the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare commissioned a report as part of the review of the first Commonwealth-state disability agreement, which revealed that there were at least 13,400 people with a disability who have some element of unmet accommodation and respite care demand? Can the minister explain how delaying this consultation process by five months will see issues progressed for any of those 13,400 people still waiting for assistance?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —It is an important question that Senator Crossin has asked, and I appreciate her asking it. You will recall that prior to the election Warwick Smith was the minister responsible for disability services. He and the state ministers had agreed to meet again late in the year—probably December, but no date was finalised—to discuss this very issue of unmet need. When I was given this expanded portfolio by the Prime Minister in mid-October, it was important for us to put together a portfolio which had a very wide ranging number of responsibilities across child care, disabilities, income support, housing, et cetera. It was not possible for me to meet with the state ministers in December as had been talked about but not scheduled. I then worked with the ministers to set a date, which is the first date that everybody could be present together. From memory, I think that is about 9 April. I think it is an important meeting that we are planning to have.

answer.para: However, you should understand that in your question you were talking about accommodation and respite services. Those in fact are the responsibilities largely, almost entirely, of the states. The Commonwealth does provide them with a considerable sum of money towards that, but there is divided responsibility, by agreement with the states: the Commonwealth takes responsibility for income support for people with disabilities and employment services for people with disabilities and the states take responsibility for accommodation, respite and support services.

In that context, as ministers we will be looking across state and Commonwealth governments at how this very difficult problem of unmet need will be met in each of our own areas of responsibility. It would be remiss of me to not point out that this is not something that has just happened. This is something that has been happening over the last 10, 15 or even 20 years. It is not something that will be easily solved; it is something on which governments will have to work together very carefully.

One of the things I was saying this week in answer to a question about tax reform was very appropriate to this issue: the states will shortly have flowing to them $25 billion of revenue from the GST, which will enable them to improve their services in the disabilities area. This reform is something which many premiers are either publicly or privately saying that they cannot wait to see happen. They need that money. We cannot have states to continue to go cap in hand to Canberra to get money for basic services. That was the system we inherited. Our government has taken the decision to reform the whole of the tax system, including payments to the states. The GST will provide them with an assured revenue stream, which will grow over the years as the population grows and as more people are brought into the tax system compared with those who are now avoiding it. That is how over time more good can be done for people with disabilities.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, we are more than aware of the relationship between the states and territories and the Commonwealth when it comes to funding these services. Therefore, are you aware that delaying this meeting until April will leave an inadequate time frame for charitable and community groups to examine and digest any recommendations or outcomes, therefore denying these groups informed participation in the budget 1999 submission process?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —On the contrary, my department has been meeting with organisations who have an interest in this matter for some time. Only today I met with ACROD. They will be having more meetings with the government between now and 9 April. I do not think there has been a lack of consultation. Their views are being taken into serious consideration as the providers of many of the services we are talking about.
—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. I refer to the minute from his departmental secretary dated 23 December last year concerning Jabiluka. It stated:

question.para: A key focus will be on lobbying capitals to assert a whole of government approach on their Committee members.

Minister, does that mean you do not want UNESCO committee members to decide based on world heritage obligations? Instead, isn't the government using political pressure to get member countries to vote with Australia? Isn't this grossly inappropriate behaviour which threatens to subvert the World Heritage Committee? Isn't this systematic interference with member countries? Why is the minister using thuggish pressure to get his way?

talk.start.para: —It is a pity that Senator Allison did not speak to her colleague Senator Bartlett, who represented her at the estimates committee last night and heard about two hours of answers to that particular question because it was repeated so often.
—They were not convincing at all.

—The position is that Australia needs to correct the falsities of the Australian Democrats, the Australian Labor Party and others who have so badly misrepresented the true position in relation to Jabiluka.
—All the prominent leading scientists don't say that.
—Order! Senator Bolkus cease interjecting.
—The Jabiluka mine prospect in the Northern Territory has undergone some three years of assessment and been found to be totally environmentally safe.
—Not even an EIS.
—Senator Bolkus!

—It has therefore gained all Commonwealth approvals necessary for an export licence to be granted in due course, presuming that the company complies with the conditions that were associated with the approval. Notwithstanding that very rigorous assessment process—
—You know it wasn't rigorous. You were pushed into it by Parer.

—and the fact that the Ranger Mine has operated in the near vicinity safely for a period of 18 years the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and certain fringe NGOs have decided to undermine the Australian government's position by misrepresenting the position to the World Heritage Committee.
—You're just Minchin's puppet. He's running it.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, you have been interjecting since the answer started. I would ask you to abide by the standing orders and cease interjecting.

—Our responsibility will be to ensure that the member states that make up the committee are properly informed as to the true facts in relation to this matter and then all we will request of them is a fair and objective assessment of those facts, because on a fair and objective assessment there can be no question about this world heritage area being described as being in any danger at all. If it has not been in any danger from 18 years of mining at Ranger, how can it possibly be in any danger from a mine 20 years on, an underground mine as opposed to an open-cut mine, with newer technology and a much smaller footprint? It does not make any sense whatsoever.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his attempt at an answer. My colleague reminds me that he did not answer the question last night either. Minister, in the letter that you wrote me you insisted that you were only interested in correcting errors of fact, science and law. That sounds reasonable enough until I read this internal government strategy where I see that you are considering incentives, pressuring and various external tactics like cross-trading votes on committees. Isn't it the case that you are not interested in the merits of the argument at all and that this is about winning at all costs regardless of the impact on the Mirrar people and regardless of the impact on Kakadu? Does it bother the minister that he is politicising the World Heritage Committee to such an extent that he could fatally erode all of the goodwill and the good faith so many countries have taken so long to achieve?

—It is the Australian Democrats and the ALP who have politicised this process by going behind the back of the elected government of Australia to misrepresent the position at the meeting at Kyoto of last year. It was the Australian Labor Party who stood by for 13 years alongside the Ranger Mine and said that it was not in any way a danger to the world heritage area and it is the Labor Party who are undermining the integrity of the world heritage process. It is our wish to restore that integrity, and that is why we are taking the position that we are.

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services. In an earlier answer to a question from me about the impact of the tax package on your department's clients and the failure of the department to do any work on that matter, you tried to depict the secondment of one officer from your department to the Treasury as being your evidence of the department's involvement.
—Senator, your question should be directed through the chair.

—Sorry, Madam President. Despite that, Minister, are you aware that at the estimates committee the officer made it very clear that he was seconded on the basis of his skills, not as a representative of the department, not to represent the department's view? He was seconded to use his particular skills. Will you now confirm the evidence given by your department that you have done no modelling on the impact of the tax package on your department's clients?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer I gave previously was perfectly truthful and straight up and down. There was a very senior officer from my department seconded to Treasury. He spent a number of years gaining experience in social security issues. He was an invaluable member of the working party on tax reform, and the tax package shows the results of his expertise working with the Tax and Treasury people.

—My question is to the Special Minister of State. The government accepted the recommendation of the Constitutional Convention that the question of Australia becoming a republic be put to the Australian people in a referendum. The government has confirmed that it intends to follow closely the republic model endorsed by the convention. Will the Special Minister of State advise the Senate on the method of public education and information that the government intends to implement?

—I thank Senator Brownhill for this question because it is timely as the government has recently announced its public funding of $15 million for the yes case and the no case. Firstly, let us look back to the Constitutional Convention, which recommended that there be a bipartisan appointment of a president. The government undertook to put that model at a referendum, and we will be doing that in a referendum some time in November this year. The convention also stated that there should be a public education campaign which should be impartial and which should be designed to inform the people of Australia as to the constitution governing the country and its system of government. That was in order to assist people in making an informed choice as to whether this country should become a republic or not.

answer.para: There will be three phases to the information campaign. The first will involve that impartial education campaign which I have just referred to. I have been working with the Attorney-General on the referendum task force to develop a campaign which will be intended to provide straightforward, easily understandable information in relation to the system of government, the specific proposal for change, the referendum process itself and the changes in the relationship between the Commonwealth and the states. It is very important that the people of Australia have an understanding of the system of government, the referendum, the process and especially the question.

The second phase involves the campaign itself, which will involve funding for the yes case and the no case. There will be two committees drawn from delegates to the Constitutional Convention and each committee will comprise nine in number. The majority of those will be non-parliamentarians. Those committees will then apply the $7½ million respectively to a campaign of advertising and information as they see fit to the yes case and no case respectively. I might add that there will be a government process in relation to the approval of that advertising. It will not go to the substance of the advertising but merely to the fact that the advertising is not misrepresentative and that it conforms with the usual guidelines in relation to standards of advertising. It will not be dealing with the substantive matters as to the advertising concerned.

The third phase will involve the traditional yes and no cases. As with a normal referendum, the Australian Electoral Commission will send to Australian households across the country the yes and no cases. Of course they will set out in succinct form the cases for and against Australia becoming a republic. That will be provided in a booklet form closer to the referendum.

It is essential that the people of Australia have a good grasp of the question that is being put them, of the issues at hand, and an understanding of the system of government in this country. It is essential that the Australian people have this knowledge in order to make an informed choice, and that is the aim of these three phases of information. Debate can be conducted with vigour—with passion, as the Prime Minister has said—but it is most important that debate on this issue be informed and conducted with maturity.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Can the minister confirm that under current child disability assessment tool provisions in the child disability allowance a minimum of 3,800 children are no longer eligible for the payment? Is the minister aware that many families of children with a disability suffer severe financial hardship due to the added expenses incurred by a disability and that sweeping exclusions from this payment only serve to further pressure their economic situation? Is the minister satisfied with the method by which the application of the assessment tool is made by Centrelink?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Senator Gibbs asks whether 3,800 children are no longer eligible. I cannot confirm that today, but I will get her the detail. What I can say is that, of those who ceased to be eligible in the reviews prior to 30 June last year, a number may be eligible for health care cards, as I am sure she would be aware. For many families of children with disabilities the assistance with pharmaceuticals is one of the most important elements of the non-means tested assistance.

answer.para: You will recall that the Senate passed a method of evaluating objectively the disabilities that have been suffered and the need by children for care. That will be evaluated in the normal way, with most social security programs being evaluated after the first year of implementation. Under the new arrangements children can be eligible either for a health care card or if the need for care is much greater than simply the provision of pharmaceuticals they no doubt will be eligible for the payment as well as the card. I will have a look at the detail of your question and see if I can get more answer for you, Senator.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister familiar with the tragic situation whereby a leukaemia sufferer from the Northern Territory undergoing chemotherapy and coping with the amputation of his leg below the knee was initially deemed not eligible to receive a disability allowance? Is the minister aware that this boy's family had to fight with Centrelink to prove that his overall development is affected by his illness and that he requires more care than other children of his age? Was it the government's intention that this assessment tool operate to exclude children who are clearly disadvantaged from receiving this payment, and how does the minister intend to ensure that in the future children with a disability are not excluded from this allowance due to inadequate assessment procedures?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I am sure the senator would not expect that the minister would be determining people's eligibility on an individual basis. The social security system has never allowed for that. If a decision of Centrelink is not accepted by the family concerned, they have very important review rights within the Centrelink system and appeal rights to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the AAT, the Federal Court and the High Court. So there is no way that family did not have the right of appeal, and it appears they must have succeeded. I recall that was a case last year, but I do not recall the outcome of it. Obviously, though, from the way you describe it, they did use their appeal rights, and it is an indication that the system works fairly.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. Australia has always been a world leader in innovation. I understand that our scientists are now developing groundbreaking research in the field of renewable energy through solar power. Could the minister advise the Senate what the government is doing to recognise the achievements of our scientists?

—This morning I announced that Professor Martin Green and Professor Stuart Wenham from the University of New South Wales were the winners of the 1999 Australia Prize. This is an annual award to acknowledge excellence by scientists and technologists in applying their skills for the benefit of humanity. It is awarded in a different category each year.
—Started by the Hawke Labor government.

—And I acknowledge the fact that it was initiated by a former Labor government. This year's field is energy, science and technology. Professor Green and Professor Wenham have made an outstanding contribution to the science of photovoltaics, the conversion of sunlight into electricity. They have also worked closely with industry to turn their research into a viable commercial enterprise. Last year solar cells developed by Professors Green and Wenham became the largest manufactured solar cell technology in Europe. Their solar cells have achieved a 24½ per cent efficiency in the conversion of sunlight into electricity, which is the current world record by a very large margin. Their cells produce up to 30 per cent more energy and are 20 per cent cheaper to make than competing technologies. The solar cells will also power each of the homes in the athletes village for the 2000 Olympics.

answer.para: Professors Green and Wenham provide a leading example of how commercialisation of innovation offers export and development opportunities for Australia. The coalition government recognises the importance of Australian research and will continue to foster an environment in which collaboration between industry and science can flourish. We want to encourage commercialisation of research, particularly in this renewable energy field.

Our policies reflect this commitment, in particular the renewable energy showcase, the renewable energy commercialisation program and the renewable energy equity fund, which all encourage the commercialisation of renewable energy innovation. I take this opportunity, on behalf of all senators, to congratulate Professor Green and Professor Wenham on their achievements. I look forward to meeting them this evening at the presentation dinner in the Great Hall where the Prime Minister will award the Australia Prize.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I have answers to questions that Senator Margetts asked me yesterday. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows—
Question: Can the Minister indicate if a contract has finally been finalised with COGEMA, if so who signed it, and have all Ministerial approvals been given?

Answer: A contract was signed on 22 January 1999. It was signed by the Executive Director of ANSTO and a senior executive of Cogema. I approved ANSTO entering into the contract, in accordance with the requirements of section 31 of the ANSTO Act 1987.
Question: Will it be tabled in the Senate or at the Senate Economics References Committee Inquiry into the new ANSTO reactor and if not, why not?
Answer: The contract will not be tabled in the Senate as it is a commercial contract that is confidential to its signatories.

Question: Does the contract with COGEMA include reprocessing fuel from the new ANSTO reactor and if so, doesn't this pre-empt the outcome of the Senate Commission's inquiry and any environmental impact studies to the reactor?

Answer: The contract provides for the reprocessing of spent fuel arising from the operation of the replacement research reactor, on terms to be agreed once the reactor is selected and the fuel type is known.
The terms of reference of the Senate's reactor inquiry do not include a specific requirement for consideration of the management of spent fuel from the replacement reactor.

The Committee's reporting date is listed for 18 February 1999 and there is a notice of motion on the Senate Notice Paper indicating that the Committee would like to move the report date back until the 27 May 1999, therefore the contract with Cogema does not pre-empt the Committee's findings.
The Environmental Impact Statement for the replacement reactor, which ANSTO completed recently, indicated that ANSTO had an agreement that included spent fuel from the replacement reactor.
Supplementary Question
Question: Can Minister clarify whether any actual environmental impact study was part of that due process.

Answer: The overseas shipment of all the HIFAR spent fuel was subject to environmental assessment in 1997 under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (the EPIP Act). That assessment is now being reviewed by Environment Australia in the light of the changed destination of the non-US origin fuel In accordance with the provisions of the EPIP Act, Environment Australia will be forwarding a report to the Minister for Environment and Heritage in the near future.
Question: How much will the reprocessing contract with COGEMA cost ANSTO?
Answer: The cost of the reprocessing contract with Cogema is commercial-in-confidence.
Question: Is this in excess of the amount that should see the contract referred to the Public Works Committee?
Answer: Works covered by the PWC involve buildings and structures. The overseas shipment and reprocessing of spent fuel are outside the scope of the Public Works Committee's reference.
Question: what penalty clauses are there if either side decide to withdraw from the contract?

Answer: As is normal in commercial contracts, penalty provisions do apply. The details are commercially confidential. Legal advice from Attorney General's Department and from a French lawyer engaged to represent ANSTO in the negotiations confirmed that the terms of the contract are in accordance with accepted practice.

talk.start.para: —I have an answer to a question that Senator Faulkner asked me yesterday. I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Yesterday Senator John Faulkner asked me a question regarding the government's submission to the Remuneration Tribunal regarding charter entitlements.

The submission was taken forward by the Hon John Fahey MP, Minister for Finance and Administration. The submission followed consideration by government of the existing procedures and ambiguity surrounding them.
The government believed that more flexible arrangements should be introduced. The Remuneration Tribunal accepted the government's submission.

At the time these matters were dealt with, Senator Ellison was Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Senator Minchin was Special Minister of State. Of course Mr Fahey continues as Minister for Finance and Administration.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I apologise to Senator Mackay because I forgot to tell her that I had an answer for her on the matter she raised with me yesterday, which was on whether the review into BASI, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, would be made public. I indicated to her that I would refer that to Mr Anderson for a response. I am advised that he will be making the results of the review public.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Questions without Notice

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Newman) to questions without notice asked today, relating to the proposed new tax system and family and community services.

What was clear from the answers given to the Senate chamber today is that the minister has no idea what the impact of the government's GST package is on her department's own clients. The pensioners, the disabled, the people who need our support rely on her to ensure that the GST package is fair and that adequate compensation applies to them. What is perfectly clear is that she does not have a clue how the package impacts on her clients. She does not seem to care and has taken no steps to find out what the impact is on those clients. The most vulnerable in the community rely on her as minister to make sure that they are protected.

What is clear from the answer she gave today and what was clear at the Senate Community Affairs References Committee hearings is that she does not have a clue and has taken no steps to protect those people. She shows no interest in ensuring that those people are protected and instead relies on trotting out the same glib government line that, `Everyone will be better off. We will have a new tax, but you will all be better off.' The logic of that escapes most Australians, and it certainly escapes me. The minister cannot back it up with any analysis. What she said yesterday in attacking the Anglican Church, because they dared to raise some criticism, was:
I think it is very sad that those who purport to speak for the poor and the disadvantaged frequently do so with total ignorance.

That is dead right, minister. And there is no-one more ignorant than you on this issue. You proved today again that you speak with total ignorance about the impact of the GST on the clients of your department—the pensioners, the disabled the other social security recipients. You have no idea. I questioned the department closely at the community affairs committee hearing about their involvement, and the minister today tried to pretend that they had been closely involved. This is what they said in answer to questions I put to them the other day at the community affairs committee inquiry into the GST. I asked:
So was there any formal DSS involvement in the preparation of the document, the tax package?
Mr Tune, the Executive Director of the department, replied, `No.' I asked:
Has the department formally provided advice to the government about the package itself?
He replied, `No.' I then asked:
So with the modelling that was done in terms of the tax package, there was no Social Security or Family and Community Services involvement?
His answer was, `No.' My next question was:
Has the department done any work on the impact of the tax changes on its clients?
Mr Tune replied:
No, other than through implementation work that we are putting in place.
I asked:
So the department has not provided any views to Treasury about what should be the basis for the assessment of compensation?

Mr Tune said, `No.' The department has done no work, the department has done no modelling on the impact on its clients. The department was not involved or consulted in the preparation of the tax package. They have got no idea of what it means for housing, for pensioners, for the costs of living of the clients of the department. They do not know whether the compensation package is adequate. They have not done any work on it. The minister does not know whether it is adequate, because she has done no work on it. She has not asked the department to do any work on it. She is not interested in asking. Treasury have said to her that it will all be okay, so it is all okay; we need not worry. The fact that everybody else in the community raises concerns about the disproportionate impact on low income earners in this country does not worry her, does not require any analysis of the problem, any work, to be assured that those people will not be worse off.

talk.start.para: —What did you do in 1993? Did you talk to them?
—Order! Senator Campbell.

—All the evidence to the community affairs committee inquiring into the GST illustrates the fact that these people will be worse off. They spend all their income on food and the basic necessities of life. They will have the GST imposed on those things. They fall below the government's average because they have to spend every cent they get on essentials and basics. Under the government's proposal those will be taxed. The minister today tried to say, `I had an officer over there at Treasury and he was looking after our interests.' I asked him that very question. I said to Mr Tune:

speech.para: So when you were seconded to Treasury, was your role to represent the department or was it Treasury using your skills?
Mr Tune said:
It was Treasury using my skills.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Campbell, please withdraw that unparliamentary language.
—This bloke put up taxes on pensioners by 10 per cent in 1993 with no compensation. I withdraw the word `hypocrite'.
—Go take your tablets, Senator Campbell, and calm down. Mr Tune said:

speech.para: It was Treasury using my skills. Whilst I was a DSS officer I was seconded to Treasury for that period.

So clearly, on the evidence of the department, the minister had no involvement and the department had no involvement. They do not know what this means for their client base, for low income people in this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The crocodile tears from the other side of the chamber are an absolute joke, absolute hypocrisy. Labor has refused to admit how the present structure of our tax and social security systems conspires to keep families and people on welfare dependent on benefits, and discourages them from taking up work. It is a commonly held view that the highest marginal tax rates are paid by people at the top end of the income distribution scale. However, the interaction between Labor's income tax and social security systems means that many low and moderate income families keep only a few cents of the additional income they earn. That is what we inherited from Labor. When people on moderate incomes got a few extra dollars in their pay they went out the door backwards, that is, they experienced a reduction in disposable income as their earned income went up.

speech.para: For example, a single income family with two children faced an effective tax rate of 105 per cent on private income between $27,600 and $29,600 a year. This is the system we inherited from Labor. As soon as people on middle incomes got some extra overtime or were promoted in their job, they went out the door backwards. Those opposite have the hide to come in here and claim that in the tax reform package no notice has been taken of the impact on social security recipients or welfare beneficiaries. That is absolute humbug. That is not the case. Of course the officer in the department will have brought to bear his skills and knowledge. He may not have been representing the department, but his skills and knowledge were there. That is why this system is much fairer and much better. It means that people on middle incomes, when they have an increase in pay, do not go out the door backwards.

Senator Ian Campbell was absolutely correct: in 1993 the Labor Party put up wholesale sales tax by 10 per cent. I might just remind people that wholesale sales tax went up on strawberry Quik but not on chocolate Quik. Why? Because chocolate Quik doesn't have a tax on it, and strawberry Quik does. That is how ramshackle your wholesale sales tax system was—a tax on strawberry Quik and not on chocolate Quik, on toothbrushes and not on toothpaste. It was a ramshackle, out-of-date tax system which was narrowing and narrowing and had no hope in the future of sustaining or maintaining the social security system. What we have in the tax reform package is some interaction between income tax and welfare benefits and family benefits to ensure that we have a sustainable system into the future.

To stand here and cry crocodile tears is absolutely outrageous. To say that Senator Newman doesn't know and doesn't care is also outrageous. She is the best social security minister. She is saving $47 million a fortnight in fraud and overpayments in social security, enabling us to give benefits to profoundly disabled children who are in the care of parents and who are under 16. Labor never cared about that. It had families with profoundly disabled children receiving no assistance at all. What was it doing? It was squandering that money, borrowing from overseas, borrowing $10 billion a year to pay for social security fraud, to pay for its incoherent system.

You stand here and talk about the tax package, the GST. You never talk about it as a tax reform package. You never accept that it is a whole package. You never accept that there is also compensation. The senator who spoke previously said that food is going to go up, that prices are going to go up. Of course we have admitted that there will be an increase in prices, estimated at 1.9 per cent. People will get a four per cent increase on their benefits prior to the GST. If the impact is higher, their benefits will stay 1.5 per cent above the inflation rate. We are compensating them for it.

So to get up here and cry about the fact that the social security department wasn't represented is absolute nonsense. No social security department was represented when the wholesale sales tax went up. There was no compensation for people who buy all the items that have wholesale sales tax on them, wholesale sales tax that is cascading down. It is outrageous and hypocritical that the Labor Party should get up and make the sorts of claims it is making today.

talk.start.para: —I find it very interesting that Senator Newman has gone and left Senator Patterson to defend the government in this debate. It is probably because Senator Patterson is better able to do it, but she has got a dreadful job. Suddenly the government is very loud and very aggressive in its campaign for this GST. It knows that out there in the community people are beginning to understand the impact of this GST on their lives, their income, their capacity to cope. It is anything but a fair tax. Time and time again the witnesses before our GST committee have pointed out that if you are old, if you are poor, if you are disabled, if you are working for a charity or if you depend on charities, you will be badly affected, negatively affected, by the introduction of a GST.

speech.para: The government's program for the last few days to try to address these serious issues has been to start accusing people like Anglicare, the Anglican Church's service organisation, of being ignorant and unaware of what happens. Who more than Anglicare would know about the impact of the GST on the lives of the many thousands of people they see at the low end of the income scale? That is why they have bothered to write a submission. They have said in their submission that this GST is going to be very damaging. I have here from the Age, first edition, Wednesday, 17 February 1999, an article that starts:

The Federal Government's tax reform plans suffered a significant blow with one of the church's most influential church leaders describing the GST on food as inequitable . . . Anglican Archbishop Peter Hollingworth—who played a key role in forcing the former Liberal Leader Dr John Hewson to rewrite his 1992 Fightback package to exclude food—yesterday said a GST compensation package could not be trusted.

It is much more than that. If you want to start arguing the case in the community about the virtues of the GST why do it by fighting Anglicare? Why do it by fighting the Salvation Army and the Smith Family and St Vincent de Paul? They are to come up tomorrow, are they? Anybody who disagrees with the government is wrong and wicked, according to Senator Newman, or at least they are ignorant.

We have had other evidence that should give the government considerable pause. Professor McDonald, department head of the demography program, Research School of Social Sciences at the ANU argued before the committee that, according to the household cameos in tax reform, the presence of a child increases the GST inflation of living costs by a mere 30c a week. For example, the GST would increase the living costs of a couple with one child by 30c more than the inflation experienced by a couple with no children. He goes on to say:

The income tax cuts favour high income, childless households. The double income couple with no children earning $125,000 a year receives a tax cut of $108 a week. A double income couple with one child earning $45,000 benefits by only $13 a week.
The people in the community know that this is unfair as it is structured. The service organisations say that it is unfair.

talk.start.para: —What about your tax cuts?
—You can shout all you like, but you are shouting because you are concerned that the community is begin ning to understand. They are beginning to understand how unfair this tax is.

speech.para: The government has calculated its own Treasury figures and made an admission that the figure of 1.9 per cent for inflation in the first year is wrong. The Treasury now says it is at least 3.1 per cent. People listening should know that the government has calculated its increase on the CPI, which does not include health costs. Anybody who ever incurs health costs—and thousands of old, sick and young people do—should know that that calculation is not included in the Treasury's figures.

Finally, Senator Newman has said all the GST money will go to the states to provide services. Anybody in the states in Australia knows that the states are very loath to spend money on services. We have seen so many of those services cut back. Schools in Victoria are an example that springs to mind. Money for home and community services to assist people to stay in their homes and communities has been cut back and cut back. We have no guarantee that the government's GST will give those services to the people in the states. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Crowley starts off by talking about witnesses who appeared before her GST committee. That only highlights Senator Crowley's ignorance, because her committee is looking into tax reform. It is not looking into a GST; it is looking into tax reform. She just simply does not understand that, when you talk about tax reform, you must talk about a total package. Senator Evans came in here earlier and said that Senator Newman has no idea. The only thing that is clear to me is that Senator Evans has no idea.

speech.para: Where was Senator Evans in 1993 when the Labor Party decided it would increase the taxes on low and middle income earners and welfare recipients by two per cent on every item that attracts wholesale sales tax? Where was the compensation that was offered to low and middle income earners—

talk.start.para: —Tax cuts.

—You did not deliver the tax cuts. Where were Senator Evans and Senator Crowley speaking out against the increase in sales tax by the Labor government in 1993, which applied equally to low income earners and welfare recipients in the same way that it applied to those people on higher incomes? They were silent because they had no compensation and no justification. In fact, they could not come up with a tax reform package. They could only come up with an increase in the rate of indirect sales tax.

speech.para: We have heard a lot today about the people on social security and low income earners. When you consider the tax package as a whole, who better to consider it as a whole than ACOSS, the Australian Council of Social Service? They are the people who are supposedly very concerned and looking after the interests of those people on lower than average incomes or who are welfare recipients.

What did ACOSS do in the debate about tax reform? They actually assessed that, in their own view, the Treasury's estimate of a 1.9 per cent CPI increase could not possibly be correct. So they urged the government to release the household expenditure survey data, which the government did. That still did not suit their argument, because they still found that the increase that would apply across the board was less than the four per cent compensation that this government is offering by way of compensation to low and middle income earners and welfare recipients.

They decided they would commission a survey of their own. They got Melbourne University to do a survey of their own, using the sorts of figures that they wanted to put in. Do you know what happened? Melbourne University came up with a figure of 3.6 per cent; still lower than the four per cent compensation being offered by this government to the people they represent.

The problem we have with people like Senator Evans and Senator Crowley is that they can only talk about a goods and services tax. They cannot talk about tax reform or a total tax package which will apply to all people living throughout Australia and will provide a net economic benefit to every Australian, regardless of whether they are low income earners, welfare recipients, people in business, exporters, primary producers or manufacturers.

That is the problem that arises when people like Senator Evans get up and say that we have no idea. They have no idea because Senator Crowley and Senator Evans have a total focus on that one portion of the tax reform package which talks about a goods and services tax; a broad tax, a tax which for the first time taxes services which is a growing sector, and takes the pressure off the indirect wholesale sales tax which is in a declining sector with a lessening tax base. The only way to maintain an indirect revenue base is to put up the rate, which is what the Labor Party did in 1993 with the wholesale sales tax.

Do not let Senator Evans and Senator Crowley come into this place and say that we do not understand the impact it will have on low income earners and welfare recipients. We do, and that is why we have made sure that they will be overcompensated. It even allows for a cushion of overcompensation, and this government has said that whatever the CPI effect is—if the modelling is a very small margin out—we will guarantee compensation for that 1.5 per cent above the CPI impact to low income earners and welfare recipients. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I wish to take note of the answers from Senator Newman today, particularly in relation to disability services. The minister started today by actually implying that Anglicare should do their homework when it comes to presenting information before the committees that are looking into the impact of the tax reform package put forward by the government. Her answers today reflect that it is the minister who ought to do her homework. Her answers reflect that she has no heart or feeling when it comes to disability services in this country.

speech.para: Let us take some of the examples today she referred to, or in fact did not refer to. Warwick Smith, the previous minister, undertook to meet with disability services groups some time last December. That meeting still has not occurred. It would be true to say that this minister has not met with those groups in the community that have responsibility for disability services. For example, ACROD, a peak disabilities group, may be meeting with her department once a month, but the department is not good enough in this instance. They should be meeting with the minister. The fact that the minister has failed to schedule meetings regularly with this group shows a lack of commitment on her behalf to understanding the problems and the complexities of disability services.

The meeting that was scheduled for last December has now been put off until 9 April, which will be far too late. If these groups are going to have an input on the budget this year, then 9 April will be well and truly too late. The budget is handed down in May, and decisions and commitments will be locked in by 9 April. There is really no commitment by this minister to get a grip on the problems facing disability services in this country.

We asked a question today about a little boy in the Northern Territory and the fight his family had to gain access to disability services and to qualify for an assessment by Centrelink. It may well be true that that family accessed their appeal rights, but the heart of the matter, which the minister failed to grasp, is that the actual assessment criteria are inadequate. Yes, it is true that ministers should never interfere with decisions by Centrelink, but what this minister fails to understand is that she needs to be across the assessment criteria. She needs to be aware of how inadequate they are. She needs to be aware of where there are problems with the system that need to be addressed.

This little boy who had his leg amputated below the knee due to an illness was assessed by Centrelink as not having a disability, because the assessment did not require that Centrelink must say that he did. The assessment was not adequate, and it is in the minister's own interest to be aware of these problems within her portfolio. If she attended meetings with ACROD, if she was across the issues in Centrelink and if she was across the assessment criteria, these kinds of heart-wrenching struggles and disappointments faced by families, like the family of this little boy in the Northern Territory, would not have taken so long to be resolved and, in fact, would never have had to occur in the first place.

Yesterday, we saw an example of another mean-spirited policy by this government. The Howard government is in the process of taking away the child disability allowance from nearly 3,846 children with a disability. No doubt this is to achieve budget savings of nearly $7½ million during this financial year. Parents around Australia have only been given 21 days to reapply for their child disability allowance. That means that they need to fill in a quite complex form. They need to make appointments with specialists. They need to get that referral and all of that information into Centrelink within 21 days. For some parents in capital cities—let alone those in rural and remote Australia—this is just not possible. This is a payment that is worth $75 a fortnight and that helps parents with extra costs associated with caring for a child with a disability.

Once again, this is simply a backdoor way of taking money from families. It is another indication that this minister has not got a handle on the child disability problems and the disability service problems this country is experiencing. It is another indication that this minister really does not care about what happens to disability services in this country.
