talk.start.para: —What we have seen today has been a shameful and stuttering attack by the opposition on the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. It peaked in the question that was asked by Senator Gibbs and referred to by Senator Crossin here just a moment ago about the assessment of the disability payment for a boy from the Northern Territory who had leukemia. I would hasten to bet that most of the senators in this chamber have probably never seen the form that a parent or carer would fill in to seek a disability payment for a disabled child. Most of them would probably have never seen the form, yet the Labor Party can come in here and work themselves into a lather of indignation without a proper knowledge of the facts.

speech.para: The facts are these. The form which has been referred to is in fact an assessment of a person's degree of disability. There are certain categories of people for whom completion of the last part of the form—which is the functional disability test—is not necessary either because of their age or because they have certain categories of disability which automatically qualify them. But anybody who knows anything about disabilities knows that a person can be disabled yet fall into a whole range of possible degrees of impairment. That is why you have to have a functional disability test. Not everybody who is an amputee is going to be disabled in the same way. Not everybody who has an intellectual impairment may be equally intellectually impaired. You might have an intellectual impairment which is very minor and which allows you to function normally in the community, or you may have an intellectual impairment which is profound and requires assistance.

It would be absurd if we were to say that every person would be treated equally. That would be a failure of our duty to those people who are truly in need. It would be unfair on the taxpayer to support people whose degree of impairment is mild or minor. That is a sensible attitude to take. That is why you have to have a functional disability test.

Of all the thousands of people who apply and receive disability payments, we get a story of one person whose functional disability test was rejected by Centrelink at first instance. Senator Crossin out of her own mouth said that it would be wrong and it should never happen that a minister interferes with the assessment by Centrelink. Yet Senator Crossin then proceeded to spend the rest of her speech blaming Senator Newman for the fact that Centrelink at first instance rejected the claim, having already said at the start of her speech that it would be wrong for the minister to interfere. If it is wrong for the minister to interfere, how can you expect the minister to take responsibility for an administrative decision, which Senator Crossin by her own admission said should be made by Centrelink? That is the absurdity of the case that we have had from the other side of the chamber.

What the other side of the chamber gild over and do not want to talk about is the fact that, when this case went to review, the parents of the boy in question received access to the payment they sought. In other words, the system worked. It does not always work perfectly at first instance—no system will—because, if it did, you would not need review criteria, you would not need review procedures. But the system worked.

What should be condemned is not this minister: what should be condemned is the arrant ignorance of how these matters are dealt with, which exists on the other side of the chamber. What should be condemned is this pathetic attack that we saw today. It took up half of question time; it has taken up half an hour after question time; and still they have not proved one single allegation against this minister. All this has proved is that this opposition is incompetent, this opposition does not know what they are talking about and they should be condemned.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

The estimated out turn cost of the proposal when referred to the Committee was 22.3 million dollars.
The Committee has recommended that the works should proceed.

By way of background, the Queensland Centre for Advanced Technologies was established by an agreement between the Queensland Government and the CSIRO to expand and diversify research and development in the mining, energy and related manufacturing industries in Queensland and nationally. The Centre brings together resources from the State Government, universities, CSIRO divisions, Queensland and Australia-wide minerals, energy and manufacturing industries in collaborative activities.

The proposal examined by the Committee includes the construction of a research building, a technology transfer building, a number of new industrial type buildings, extensions to existing buildings such as the library and canteen, and site works, including new roads, carparking and environmental rehabilitation.

The Centre was originally designed to cater for research and development projects involving 130 staff. Since the Centre was established, research activities have grown at a rapid rate and existing facilities will be inadequate to support planned increases in research personnel and projects.
As a consequence, the Committee has concluded that there is a need to provide additional facilities at the Centre to house and support planned increases in personnel and research projects.
The Committee found that master planning studies of the site, undertaken by the CSIRO, have identified areas suitable for further expansion well into the next century.

Based on the evidence, the Committee also concluded that the extent of the proposed works will provide for the planned expansion of research and development projects and provide capabilities expected to stimulate their further expansion.

para.inline: CSIRO National Centre for Petroleum and Mineral Resources Research, Bentley, WA

speech.para: The second report which I have tabled involves the construction of another national centre for the CSIRO. This one will be located in the Perth suburb of Bentley and will be known as the CSIRO National Centre for Petroleum and Mineral Resources Research.

The Bentley Centre will provide a focal point for research excellence and collaboration between CSIRO, Cooperative Research Centres, university researchers, Government agencies, resource companies and associated technology suppliers and providers.

The proposal examined by the Committee involves the construction of laboratories and research facilities, process bays, support and stores areas, staff amenities, public facilities, associated site works, roadworks, carparking, engineering and communication services and landscaping.
When referred to the Committee, the estimated out turn cost of the proposed work was 31.8 million dollars.
The Committee has recommended that the work proceed as proposed.

By way of background I should mention that the CSIRO, or its predecessor organisations, has had a presence in Western Australia spanning more than 80 years. It now employs more than 400 staff at six locations in the State.

The proposed work is a recognition of the fact that the mining, oil and gas industries are the mainstay of the Western Australian economy. For this reason, CSIRO and the Western Australian Government have identified the need to increase substantially the State's research capability to support the sustained development of resource industries in an era of heightened international competitiveness.

The CSIRO divisions involved in the mining, oil and gas industries have established research teams and formed alliances with other research and development partners to undertake projects in Western Australia and nationally.

Based on the evidence, the Committee has concluded that returns to the community and resource companies from investment in research and technology transfer can be significant and are highly influential in the creation of new investment and employment.

The Committee also concluded that the extent of the proposed work can be justified as providing modern facilities designed to enable CSIRO Divisions and alliance partners to undertake research into minerals and petroleum research at increased levels and will overcome current unsatisfactory conditions.

Two other significant factors also emerged from the Committee's inquiry. The first is that co-location of two key CSIRO divisions, Exploration and Mining, and of Petroleum Resources will deliver cost savings and will maximise research effort in support of both oil and mining industry sectors.

Secondly, the proposed site for the Centre, adjacent to Curtin University of Technology and within Technology Park, Bentley will provide the capability to foster collaborative research between the university and private sector research and development organisations. CSIRO has developed a master plan for the site which makes provision for further expansion of facilities and staff.

The third report which I have tabled involves the second stage of the redevelopment of Lavarack Barracks in Townsville.There are nine major components in the proposed works. These comprise accommodation and messing, operational, logistic support and infrastructure development facilities. The main component consists of new living-in accommodation for 1,112 officers, senior non-commissioned officers and other ranks, associated mess complexes and a central food preparation facility
When referred to the Committee, the estimated out turn cost of the proposed work was $139.3 million.
The Committee has recommended that the works proceed as proposed.
The Committee has concluded that the provision of new airconditioned living-in accommodation should improve living standards for on-base personnel and should lift the morale of personnel.

Similarly, the Committee established that there is a need for new messes, on a scale commensurate with requirements identified in Department of Defence planning studies, to be provided at Lavarack Barracks adjacent to the sites proposed for new living-in accommodation.
The Committee believes there are uncertainties about the appropriateness of the cook-chill method of food preparation based on its untested nature in the Australian Defence Force.

For this reason, the Committee recommended that the Department of Defence should report back to the Committee on the operation of the cook-chill process after it has been fully tested at Lavarack Barracks, before its wider implementation within the Australian Defence Force.

The report concludes that the remainder of the works, namely a new Communications Centre, new transport facilities, the Eastern Deployment and Assembly Area, new heavy vehicle roads, and waste collection facilities will all provide substantial improvements to the functionality and environmental management of this, one of the Army's largest bases.
I commend the reports to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I present the second report of 1999 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 2 of 1999 , dated 17 February 1999.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —Senator Bartlett, are you seeking leave to go back to the matter of public importance?
—If the Senate is willing to be gracious, given the confusion over the placing of this due to it not being listed on the red, I seek leave to return to the matter of public importance.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I have already referred to the letter that proposes that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion. I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I understand that an agreement has been reached between parties as to speaking times in this debate. I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.
—I thank the Senate for their consideration. Obviously, the Senate as a whole is of a view that this is an important matter which does need highlighting.

speech.para: I rise to speak on this matter of public importance because I believe that the Senate needs to devote some time to this this afternoon. It is a vital issue to the future of native forests of this country and indeed to the future of our nation overall—our economy as well as our environment.

Australia is a unique land. Our native forests, in particular, are an ecological wonder. Our forests range from tropical to temperate, from open dry woodland to closed and wet canopy. They are host to a variety of ecosystems, encompassing many of the world's most unique animals and plants. They are found over flat, riverine or escarpment areas from the southern most part of the country to the northern tip. What is particularly extraordinary is the diverse range of forest ecosystems between and within regions. This makes it all the more crucial that we should protect and care for our forests. If properly managed, they could provide a sound economic base for a truly sustainable timber industry and a strong and permanent environmental base for our nation.

However, successive governments have sold these forests to the woodchip industry. This industry to date has shown little regard for biodiversity, little regard for the diverse range of ecosystems—animals, plants and genetic base—and little regard for the interdependence of all these. It has little regard for water quality issues or other users of forest areas other than woodchippers. The woodchipping industry does have a high regard for getting the maximum amount of corporate welfare from state and federal governments and views the chopping and shredding of the maximum number of forest areas very warmly.

When the evidence about this industry started to become well known in the public arena around five years ago, the media took a considerable amount of interest and, to their credit, published a lot of information on various forest issues, including economic and biological arguments as well as the basic environmental aspects of the issue. This certainly scared the industry and governments who, when their actions were exposed, were left able to do little more than defend the indefensible.

It was a time of full-blown crisis for the industry and, somewhere out of the public relations and damage control spin, the Regional Forest Agreement process was born. This meant that—instead of the industry each year having to face another public relations disaster as a new round of export licences were approved, instead of continual revelations about the appalling process used to determine those licences, instead of all that—we would have a Regional Forest Agreement which would be signed for each general logging area and which would allegedly meet competing demands and allegedly be ecologically sustainable.

However, the process that we have seen so far has been characterised by a lack of transparency, by bureaucratic obfuscation and by allowing much more woodchipping than previously occurred—so much so that even industry groups are alarmed by the destruction of many areas of significance and its potential impact on long-term ecological sustainability as well as environmental sustainability. Time prevents me from listing all of the problems with the Regional Forest Agreements so far. I am sure there will be other senators who will add to that body of knowledge, but I would like to highlight a few examples which go to demonstrate why this is a matter of such public importance.

In Tasmania the Regional Forest Agreement, as it currently stands, will remove 39,000 hectares of provisional coupes from the register and then add 40,000 hectares more. In other words, another 1,000 hectares will be available for logging. The state undertook to publish, by 31 October last year, a description of the methods of calculating sustainable yield. This has not occurred. They have also not published, nor made publicly available, compliance audits of the Forest Practices Act or the code of reserve management. Nor have they developed and implemented a threatened species protection strategy.

In the East Gippsland area of Victoria, certain data on wood, which it is claimed is publicly available, is not provided at all by forest agencies and there are regular attempts to make the process as difficult as possible for people seeking information. These sorts of petty impediments distract from the real tragedy and the real area of great concern—that forests along the banks of heritage-listed rivers will be decimated, leading to shocking water quality consequences.

In Western Australia the process is so bad that the environment minister has promised, after the RFA is finished, that there will be further changes. Clearly, the RFA there will not be the last word, as was promised. More than 30,000 people sent in submissions to that process, yet the environment minister will not allow the release of the audit into those submissions until after the RFA has been signed. What exactly is being hidden? Perhaps the fact that 80 per cent of people in the state of Western Australia want no native forest logging and no woodchipping. Even the National Party in that state, and some Liberal Party branches, are expressing extreme disquiet with relation to government policy on RFAs, because the Western Australia forest process is in such a mess. The department which, at state level, is in charge of the negotiations in the RFA process—the Department of Conservation and Land Management—clearly has a vested financial interest in the outcome. The department has a clear interest in ensuring the maximum area is available to loggers.

The forthcoming Regional Forest Agreement legislation that is being considered in this parliament is a small bill of only a few pages, but it represents one of the biggest environmental issues to come before the Senate. It is an issue that most Australians feel very strongly about.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: in view of the fact that this legislation is before the parliament currently and there was a reference to the committee that I chair, I believe it is outside of standing orders to be making reference to that legislation or, in fact, be dealing with any issues pertaining to anything that might come out of the committee's report. I would like a clear ruling on that at the start of this debate.

—I do not uphold your point of order for two reasons. Firstly, there is a general debate before the chair on the issue of RFAs and forests. Senator Bartlett is clearly addressing that. Secondly, I understand the President would not have approved the MPI if it had been contrary to standing orders. Her advice is that it is appropriately before the chair and, consequently, Senator Bartlett is in order.

—I therefore want to ask a question with regard to this issue. I allowed Senator Bartlett to proceed until such time as he made reference to the legislation that is currently before us. That is my question to the chair. While we can have a general debate, is it in order to be actually raising issues pertaining directly to that legislation? He made particular reference to the fact that the bill contained eight clauses.

—He can talk about the subject of the bill. He cannot anticipate the bill. I will be listening closely to Senator Bartlett's comments but so far, overwhelmingly, I think his comments have been in line with standing orders.
—I can understand why the government may be apprehensive about the reality of that legislation being brought to the attention of the Australian people, because of the impact that it will have.

speech.para: I think I just said that it was a small bill, rather than it had eight clauses—because I was not aware of that off the top of my head, and it is not in my notes—but I am willing to be credited with that knowledge, as well.

The reason why that legislation is important—without talking specifically about the content—is its oversight of the entire Regional Forest Agreement process which is happening throughout Australia at the state level, and the impact it will have on the future of our native forests. That is why it is such a major environmental issue which this parliament obviously needs to consider, and consider very deeply. It is an issue that most Australians feel very strongly about and it deserves clearer and stronger highlighting and more thorough consideration—because the bill itself, as part of the overall Regional Forest Agreement process, is an attempt by the Commonwealth to abrogate its responsibility for forests back to the states.

Forest agreements are being put together at state level in those states that have vested short-term economic dependence on woodchip royalties. We have a system where so much public money is given to the native forest industry in government subsidies that it makes the plantation industry almost untenable. That is what is at risk of being enshrined. The bill will force massive job losses to occur in the timber industry, particularly in the small sawmilling sector, and will be responsible for an unprecedented level of native forest destruction.

Important safeguards that have been put in place by this parliament over many years, such as the Australian Heritage Commission Act, the Environmental Protection Act, the World Heritage Act and export controls, will not apply to vast regions of our most important forest areas under what is being proposed by the government. That is made doubly horrifying because of the sorts of agreements that have been agreed to already at state level and those agreements that are yet to be reached in other states. Those important safeguards that this parliament has seen fit to put in place to protect our environmental heritage will be voided for 20 years. This legislation upholds a process which is fatally flawed, and it will destroy rather than protect our native forest areas.

The Democrats are determined to ensure that the public are made aware of the major threats posed to the survival of our forests by the Regional Forest Agreement process as it stands at present, because it is such a crucial issue to the very survival of our forests and the survival of communities and economies that depend upon those forests and on the long-term survival of a massive amount of biodiversity and genetic diversity in species which are also dependent on those forests. Those are all at risk now in this country. The Democrats believe it is crucial that that risk is highlighted to the Australian people and as much effort brought to bear to prevent the calamity that is before us from occurring.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this matter of public importance before us to hopefully put a few myths to bed. One of the interesting things about this debate is the endeavour by those opposite to try to shift the goal posts in regard to what was determined in the national forest policy statement and subsequent regional forest agreements.

speech.para: I think it is most inappropriate that we are debating this here today when the legislation is before us and a Senate inquiry will be making recommendations in a report to be tabled in this parliament. In particular, I would say to Senator Bartlett that I think he has compromised his colleague Senator Woodley to an unacceptable and unfair degree. I think he should think very hard about bringing these types of debates on when the Senate inquiry is yet to report to the parliament.

Having said that, I want to deal with some of the problems. I got in touch with the clerks to find out what I could and could not use. A quote from Mr Pearce, who gave evidence to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee, sums up the position of those people who want to keep shifting the goal posts and who do not accept Australia's responsibility. In answer to a question from Senator Brown, he said:

He does not like the answer he is getting. The point is there has been a long movement over this issue of sustainability. I have noticed that when people like yourselves who argued for sustainable development 20 years ago discovered that in fact you can have a sustainable development arrangement in the forests whereby the needs of the environment are looked for and the forests are harvested on a sustainable basis, you have jumped ship on sustainable development and started trying to develop other definitions which mean, in effect, sustainable ecology, that you cannot do these things. You have done that, Senator, because you have discovered over time that the sustainable development thing which you argued for 10 or 15 years ago did not produce what you want, which is no industry at all in a good many areas of Australia. Although you are here arguing that about the forests today, you will be in other committees arguing about other industries in other areas of Australia on other occasions.

My definition of these things is that you strike a balance between all of the needs of our people, and they do require large areas of untouched natural forest, on your definition and mine, put aside and safeguarded for all generations in the future. I agree with that and our industry agrees with that, and it is the striking of the balance which is important there. But our people also need jobs and our people use timber and paper and timber products. They use more than they produce.
I repeat: they use more than they produce. He goes on:

Senator, and people in Australia who argue for the proposition that we should not touch our own forests but continue to use wood and paper products in the way that we are are simply arguing for ripping off other people's forests, and that is not a position which I believe is morally sustainable.

I think that is the crux of or one of the key issues in this debate. I wish to make the point that currently Australia is using 14 million cubic metres of our own timber a year and importing seven million cubic metres. Approximately a third of the timber we use for things such as the paper I am reading from, the pads I am writing on, et cetera, is imported from another country. I find that an untenable position.

I want to make a few points. Once the RFA is signed, the forest management plan will be prepared. The plan will be released for public comment and full assessment by the Environmental Protection Authority. You hear in debate from the other side that once the RFA is signed that is the end of the matter; it is not. Why don't we get told occasionally that once an RFA is signed the states have to report to the Commonwealth minister? They have to report every year. These are the facts that need to be put on the table.

Further to this assessment, the EPA will be involved in two processes to ensure sustainable wood production. First, it will participate in an expert panel to verify the level of wood yield before the RFA is signed. Second, it will be represented on a task force to assess forest management and timber harvest levels before the next forest management plan is commenced. Once again, that absolutely destroys the oft repeated lie that the process is left uncontrolled.

Moving to the regional forest agreements, there are many stages involved in this. The first and one of more important stages is the Commonwealth-state agreement on deferred forest areas. The second state is a formal Commonwealth-state scoping agreement. The third stage is a CRA, a comprehensive regional assessment. The fourth stage is public consultation. The final stage is negotiation of a formal Regional Forest Agreement to be signed by the Commonwealth and appropriate state governments.

Some of the most important evidence that was given to the committee—and we do not have time to consider it today but I refer senators to it—was from the Deputy Premier of Tasmania, Paul Lennon, when he put a few things in perspective.

Western Australia gets a lot of mentions in this matter because of the current situation. We have what I consider to be a very unfair campaign, and it is being run on emotion and not on facts from the consultation process that has gone on and the various reports that have been done. I place on the public record that 39 reports have been released to the public since it started in Western Australia. Currently, another eight reports are being prepared and are to be released, I understand, in due course. That is a total of 47. This process has been inquired into to an extent that no other industry has been—whether it be on environmental, tourist or forest aspects or on the matter of shutting up land for wilderness protection.

You may not like the outcomes, but to claim that there has not been a process of public consultation on forest management in Western Australia is just plain dishonest. I will run through some examples of the process: 1982, EPA review of karri forest; 1987, regional forest management plans; 1990, resources assessment inquiry; 1991, review of ecologically sustainable development; 1991, National Forest Policy Statement; 1992, draft forest management plan; 1993, appeals committee review of forest management plans; 1995, deferred forest assessment process with 500 public submissions.

The list continues: 1997, eight public meetings in Perth and throughout the south-west; 1997-98, 122 meetings with organisations; 1996-98, nine meetings of Stakeholder Reference Group; 1996-97, five meetings with Noongar Action Group; 1997, nine public open days in Perth and throughout the south-west; 1997, 10 public open days in Perth and throughout the south-west; 1997, 10 community heritage workshops in Perth and throughout the south-west; 1997-98, seven indigenous workshops throughout the south-west; 1997-98, 195 meetings with organisations; 1998, the inquiry which produced 30,000 public submissions. I think that accurately puts on the table the processes that have gone on in Western Australia.

This has not been something that has been restricted to this side of politics. When Labor governments were in power in Western Australia and in other states, they were part of the process—including the governments of Brian Burke, Carmen Lawrence, Peter Dowding. Richard Court's government has been involved and, prior to all of these, so was the government of the final days of Sir Charles Court and that of Mr O'Connor when he was Premier of Western Australia. So this process has been ongoing. I think it is about time people focused on the truth when they selectively criticise the process of the RFAs. I will leave it to my colleagues to deal with the others.
In the time remaining I quote Carmen Lawrence in 1990 when she was Premier. She said:

One of the major achievements of the final Management Plans was the identification of areas to be included in conservation reserves. While creation of all of the reserves is still continuing, all areas identified for reservation are being managed for that purpose in the interim. When the reserve system has been completed there will have been a 340 per cent increase in the conservation estate of the South west that is an increase of some 550,000 hectares. Many of the reserves, such as the Shannon river basin, have been made into national parks.
That process has been going on in Western Australia for a long time. Finally, I quote Carmen Lawrence again:
. . . it is far better to use timber from well managed Australian forests, where every tree cut is regrown, than to lock up our own forests while plundering the forests of developing countries.
I put to the Senate that Democrats Senator Bartlett's matter of public importance, if ever implemented, will result in the plundering of other nations' forests. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —At the outset I also want to express a concern about the fact that Senator Bartlett has raised this matter today. He may believe this is a matter of public importance, and no doubt this issue is, but Senator Bartlett is well aware, having attended at least for a short time the hearings of the Senate rural and regional affairs committee, that we have just completed three sessions of public inquiry. We have taken evidence on these very issues, and the committee is at this very time in the process of finalising its report to be tabled next week before the legislation is brought back into this Senate in the following week. I would have thought that in those circumstances Senator Bartlett may have held his fire a bit and enabled that process to be completed and then, if he wanted to address these issues, he could have done so through the debate on the legislation.

speech.para: I also note that Senator Bartlett, having made his short address, has left the chamber. I have always taken the view when I have been involved in proposing a matter of public importance in this Senate that as a matter of courtesy the proposer should be prepared to sit and listen to the arguments put by other senators. I know senators have other commitments, but I believe that that course is appro priate, particularly if you put forward the proposition as being one of such major public importance.

The next point I wish to make is that we do not accept the statement within the matter of public importance, namely, `the failure of the Regional Forests Agreement process to protect the remaining native forests of Australia.' Our view, which has been put on the record in the other place by the shadow minister, Mr Ferguson—and I do not want to transgress the standing orders by canvassing some of the issues that will arise when we debate the bill—is that the Regional Forest Agreement process is an appropriate process and is a process that by and large is working. That is not to say that there are not some problems. But the problems, in our view, are not necessarily problems with the rules that are set down within the process that is to be followed. Rather, it would appear from at least some of the evidence that has been presented to our committee that the problems are in the attitudes that are being adopted by various parties. It is a bit like a football game. If the teams are not playing the game properly, you do not turn around and blame the rules of the game.

In our view the Regional Forest Agreement process is the appropriate way forward. In order to appreciate the process we have to at least look at some of the background of how this process developed. Every member of this Senate—indeed, including those who were not here at the time—remembers the divisiveness, the bitterness, surrounding the forest industry debates, particularly in 1995 when this parliament was blockaded for the opening week or two of the parliament. That was the culmination of this divisiveness, this aggravation, this hostility that existed in respect of the management of Australia's forests for a number of years prior.

We had, on one hand, those who believed that native forests should never be logged. We had on the other side—I suppose, at the other end of the spectrum—some representatives of the timber industry who believed that it should be open slather and that you should be able to export as many woodchips as you liked.

In order to overcome the impasse that existed as a result of the legitimate interests of conservationists and industry and also to overcome the myriad of constitutional problems—where, on the one hand, it is the states that own and manage the resource but it is the federal parliament, the federal government, that has increasingly used its powers to regulate forest management—we established, under the then Labor government, the RFA process. Of course the genesis of that process was the National Forest Policy Statement of 1992, a statement that ultimately was adopted by the current federal government, the Howard Liberal-National Party government. Therefore, it has bipartisan support at the federal level. It is also a statement and, subsequently, a process which has been adopted by every state government in this country. I will come back that process in the moment.

I want to take issue, particularly, with a statement Senator Bartlett made in his address that there should be no logging in native forests. What disturbs me is this approach that is adopted by Senator Bartlett and certainly by some interested groups involved in this debate that the only solution is their solution, and their solution is `no logging in native forests'. That is an attitude that is contrary to the National Forest Policy Statement and quite contrary to the RFA process, because, whilst the statement and the process recognise the fundamental importance of conservation values, of protecting of our native forests, particularly our old-growth forests, it also recognises that there is a place for forestry use on a commercial basis. Right through the statement you will see references to that because the statement is about a balance. It states:
The objectives and policy initiatives are underpinned by the following agreed approaches to forest management.
That includes:
. . . commercial uses of forests, including wood production, that are based on ecologically sustainable practises are appropriate and desirable activities.
It also states:

The governments also acknowledge that a variety of uses of public native forests is desirable, provid ed those uses comply with the principles of ecologically sustainable development. The objective here is the management of public native forest so as to retain the full suite of forest values over time. The governments acknowledge, however, that some uses, including non-commercial uses, may inevitably compromise other values, such as tourism and recreation values, at least in the short term.
Further on in the statement in section 4(2), dealing with wood production and industry development, it states:

Sustainable economic use of native forests and plantations is one of the principal objectives of this statement. Wood production is a major commercial use of Australia's forests. It can be integrated with a range of other commercial and non-commercial uses, among them nature conservation, recreation, tourism and water catchment production. Ecologically sustainable management of native forests for wood production involves maintaining a permanent native forest estate while balancing these uses.

And I could go on. It is a very detailed statement, as honourable senators know. The point is that some people just do not accept that the principles that underpin the National Forest Policy Statement and the RFA process involve both recognition of conservation values and the application of resource security for the timber industry. Until they understand that, they are not going to come to this debate with clean hands, with an objective approach.

In his address, Senator Bartlett briefly canvassed some of the evidence that was put to the committee. There was, of course, evidence put to the committee which submitted that the RFA process has not been carried out appropriately in some states. That has also been put on the public record. There is currently a major debate going on within the Western Australian government about whether or not the RFA negotiated in that state is appropriate, whether or not the assessments have been properly made. There is also some debate with respect to the RFAs that have been negotiated and signed in Victoria.

I believe the central problem at the moment is the politicisation of this process by the current federal Minister for Forestry and Conservation, Mr Tuckey. It seems that ever since Mr Tuckey was appointed to this portfolio following the last election we have had nothing but trouble and a reversion back to the bad old days when people were at each other's throats in respect of this industry. Mr Tuckey, for blatant political reasons, has attacked the New South Wales government. The New South Wales government has negotiated one of the best, most environmentally friendly agreements on regional forest management ever in this country. The New South Wales government under Bob Carr has the most enviable record in terms of protecting our national estate, our national heritage, our environment and, particularly, our native forests.

Since the Carr government came to office it has declared a total of 151 new national parks and nature reserves, exceeding its original election commitment by more than 600 per cent. It has recently announced the most comprehensive forest decision in the state's history, with some 380,000 hectares of North Coast forests reserved. At the same time, it has also delivered unprecedented security to the timber industry and its workers; a package that has been endorsed by the industry, by conservation groups and, indeed, supported by the coalition parties in the New South Wales parliament.

But what has occurred at the federal level? Mr Tuckey, for blatant political purposes, refuses to provide the funding that is required under the agreement for exit assistance because he wants to play politics. He wants to play politics even with his own ideological colleagues in Western Australia on this issue. That is not the way to deal with this very important issue. The way to deal with it is for the parties in all of the states to get back to the principles that underpin the RFA process, that is, achieving both ecologically sustainable development and resource security, hand in hand with conservation of our great national heritage. It should be done under the process that was established and supported by all state and federal governments of both political persuasions. That is the way forward. We believe the process is working. There are some issues that need to be addressed. I have got no doubt that we will be able to deal with those when the legislation comes before the parliament soon. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I feel somewhat frustrated because there is only three minutes allocated to me to speak on this matter. I am also angry because we are seeing a process in this parliament whereby, without the knowledge of most Australians, we are facing legislation within two weeks which will hand across millions of hectares of what is left of the wild forests in this great nation of ours to the woodchippers. That is called the regional forest agreement. Behind that name is the lie that it has the support of the Australian people. Every opinion poll shows that that is not the case. It has the support of the big logging corporations, in particular the export woodchip corporations, and through them I submit it has the support of the major political parties.

speech.para: The problem here is that we do not have an adequate debate, with an opposition on one side and a government on the other. Both the political parties are lining up to push through this legislation in the interests of those logging corporations against the 80 per cent of Australians who do not want this continuing and unnecessary destruction of not only the great wild forests that are left in this country but also the wildlife in them.

I have in my hands a picture which you cannot see, Mr Acting Deputy President, but which I can. When we look at that picture, which is in the rainforests of the Tarkine Wilderness in Tasmania where clear-felling takes place, what we see is a whole mountainside in flames where once the rainforest stood. It has been scalped. Every blade, every leaf, every living animal, every living entity in that forest has been totally and utterly destroyed. Members come in here and say that this is ecologically sustainable.

On the committee evidence that earlier members have averred, when I have asked representatives of the logging industry—not least the Deputy Premier of Tasmania—what a natural forest ecosystem is, with one exception, they have totally failed to provide an answer. When you ask, `What does sustainable mean?' again they cannot answer—or they won't. To be honest about it, you cannot be cutting, firebombing and then poisoning these forests to kill any grazing animals that come into them after they have been destroyed and call that ecologically sustainable. That is a lie. Anybody in the street can tell you that that is a fabrication. Yet that lie is going to be incorporated into action for far more extensive destruction of these forests and the wildlife that goes with them, including world heritage value forests in this great country of ours under this legislation which has had far from adequate exposure to the public.

In Western Australia in particular at the moment the debate is raging. The opinion polls show that a growing proportion of people are horrified by the potential for legislation to lock up these forests. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to reiterate what has been said by a couple of earlier speakers about the matter coming forward today when the bill is being debated. I am sure that both Senator Bartlett and, no doubt, Senator Brown will have plenty of opportunity to put their views on the table. I must say, although Senator Brown complains about the amount of time he has had here today, I think our chairman, Senator Crane, has been more than patient with Senator Brown at the three days of committee hearings; he has given him a lot more time than permanent members.

speech.para: In any event, I do not think Senator Brown will ever agree with any process we come up with in this place. The track record goes back some 10 years. With any opportunity that has been put forward by whatever government happens to be in power federally or in the state, Senator Brown and his friends in the green movement pay lip-service initially and, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, then walk away from the process. I really query why the Democrats want to derail a process which is guaranteeing the protection of potentially vast amounts of Tasmanian wilderness and old growth forests and replace it with increased exploitation of wilderness and old growth forests in other countries.

I would be the first to admit that the issues surrounding the best conservation use of Tasmania's forests—and in this case I would like to refer to Tasmania because it has completed an RFA and, therefore, I think it is appropriate to tell the chamber what has happened there—are both complex and difficult. One of the main difficulties that arises is ensuring that the economical harvesting of timber can continue to be carried out in a manner which does not threaten fragile ecosystems, particularly where they are unique; that future generations are able to continue to appreciate existing natural wilderness and that harvesting does not occur at a rate which is unsustainable in the long term. I believe the RFA process was commenced to ensure that these and other difficulties are overcome.

It is worth looking at the objectives of the RFA process. They come as a result of the national forest policy statement that the Federal Labor Party put down. They come, in Tasmania's case, after 28 or so inquiries over a period of 10 or more years, when a lot of emotional debate has gone on and a lot of small industries in Tasmania have gone to the wall. A lot of jobs have been lost, and further jobs will be lost if we cannot collectively come up with a process that meets the objectives.

The objectives of the RFA process included social, economic, environmental and heritage objectives. I will outline what they were. They were to manage the forests for a potentially expanding and value adding industry. It is very important that we have that value adding industry because it provides jobs for the people of Tasmania, and we certainly need them at the moment. They were to provide for sustainable high value species timbers, to maximise areas available for intensive management, to protect a comprehensive, adequate and representative sample of forest biodiversity, commonly known as the CAR reserves, to protect vulnerable, rare and endangered forest ecosystem biodiversity and to protect wilderness and old growth forests.

The final outcome as recommended in the agreement signed between the federal and Tasmanian governments has delivered outcomes which meet all these objectives—far beyond recognised national and international best practice reservation standards. For example, under the RFA, 40 per cent of Tasman ia's land area will be classified as reserves, including 39 per cent of Tasmania's forests, 68 per cent of the old growth forests and 95 per cent of all wilderness. These percentages far exceed the JANIS guidelines set as goals at the commencement of the process.

The new Tasmanian Labor government is a very strong supporter of the RFA outcomes for Tasmania. The Deputy Premier himself came to Melbourne to give evidence and strongly support the Commonwealth RFA legislation. Since the process was started by the Keating Labor government I am surprised that some of my Tasmanian Labor colleagues have not been more vocal in their support for the process—not Senator O'Brien, I must admit, nor you, Senator Sherry. But for some reason one or two others have been rather quiet.

After all, the RFA is expected to have many benefits for Tasmania, for its people and for the protection of its forests. Those benefits include the development and launch of a widely supported forest industry growth plan, a significant increase in plantation establishment, hundreds of new jobs to be created, resource security resulting in millions of dollars being invested in Tasmania, guaranteed quality of sawlogs available to Tasmanian sawmill operators, world's best reservation standards met and exceeded, with some 95 per cent of Tasmania's high quality wilderness reserved, and social and economic outcomes given equal consideration with environmental and heritage objectives.

One of the major things that this regional forest agreement process does is to create certainty. Well, hopefully it will create certainty. The sorts of arguments we have heard and this matter being brought forward today do not provide any more certainty. It seems to me that all it will provide is more of the same argument that has gone on for the last 10 or 15 years. I guess that is what some of these people are all about, particularly in the Democrats' case. I think one of Senator Bartlett's former colleagues, Senator Bell, would still be here in this parliament if it had not been for the ridiculous attitude the Democrats took towards some issues. Senator Bartlett may care to look at some of the speeches Senator Bell made when he was in this place. I think Senator Bell, for a Democrat, was rather supportive of sustainable forestry development.

I take issue with what Senator Forshaw had to say about my colleague Mr Tuckey. Mr Tuckey, since he has come to this job—I know for a fact, from talking to some of the union representatives in Tasmania—has gained the respect of the CFMEU members. The statement on sustainable forest management in Tasmania put down by Mr Tuckey and Paul Lennon was welcomed by the industry in my state. I also believe that the action plan he intends to put in place and the commitments he has given to encourage downstream processing are all positive things that will help the industry and the people of Tasmania and create jobs. I reiterate that this motion today is inopportune. It has been put forward at the wrong time. I look forward to debating the matter further.

talk.start.para: —A great deal has been said about the fact that this debate occurs at a time when the legislation committee is considering this legislation, so I do not propose to add anything further on that point; it has all been said. But certain things occurred during the committee's deliberations, many of which are on the public record, which I believe it is appropriate I refer to today.

speech.para: The motion we are discussing is the failure of the regional forest agreement process to protect the remaining native forests of Australia. That is one of the more misleading statements that I have ever seen put before this chamber in terms of our being asked to discuss it. The very process that is being pursued as the Labor Party contemplates the RFA process is to lead to renewable, sustainable forests for harvesting together with reserves of forests, not the removal of the native forests, as is suggested in this proposition.

The first and most important point to be made is the Australian people should not be misled that the RFA process is about removing native forests. It is about retaining native forests either protected from logging or guaranteed to be sustained in a renewable form. It also contemplates the creation of plantations so that, in the future, timber for pulping purposes, for example, will substantially come from the hardwood plantations that are grown as a result of the RFA process. My recollection of the environment movement's views on the use of forests is that it was preferable to use plantations for timber purposes. We have to get to that point somehow. The RFA process, as the Labor Party would contemplate it, will indeed lead us to that process.

Senator Bartlett's comment that he anticipates that the RFA will hurt small sawmillers flies in the face of the attitude of some of the green supporters who attended the hearings that we conducted in Melbourne. I was interested in the evidence of the Victorian Association of Forest Industries, particularly with regard to downstream processing. I asked for them to send me more information, and Mr Graeme Gooding sent me this letter and reinforced my recollection of something that took place at the hearing. A passage from his letter states:
I found the whole Senate Inquiry quite astounding with most issues raised by those submitting to your group quite irrelevant.
He is referring to the greens. He goes on:

Some seemed to think it was another RAC Timber Inquiry rather than a review about legislation. In particular I found it amazing in our session that the greens applauded the likes of Judy Clark when she essentially advocated closing down the 50 or so viable small (hardwood) businesses in Victoria and replacing them with one or two huge (softwood) corporations. They then laughed when I noted that Demby's sawmill in Toolangi had more than tripled their employment from less than 10 to 30 people. I could not stop thinking about what I thought was a bizarre event—environmental ideologues advocated big business is better than small family companies. Afterwards I recalled two points of relevance:

1. A media report last year noted that Auspine's relatively large pine mill in Portland had doubled its output last year and increased employment by 5 people. Gary Demby's little mill had doubled its output and increased employment by over 20 people. Gary is one of eight hardwood sawmills in the Central Highlands we surveyed who have increased direct employment in total by 160 people by value adding.

It is my recollection that, when that sort of evidence was given, there was an attempt from the audience to belittle the witnesses. There was giggling and laughing—indeed, someone was blowing a whistle when evidence they did not like was being presented. I suppose every group can have its people who misbehave. Unfortunately, there seemed to be an organised pattern of behaviour indicating disrespect for the evidence that was being given.

Senator Calvert has given evidence of the sort of material that we received in evidence, which I also think is generally publicly known, about the outcome of the RFA in Tasmania. Having gone through numerous inquiries into its timber industry, world heritage areas and logging practices—and I am sure it will go through a number of other inquiries as it follows the RFA process and, as far as is possible, perfect the operation of the timber industry—Tasmania starts with a world-class forestry industry in many respects but will end up with an even better one. At the end of the RFA process, assuming that the Senate gives approval to the process—and that is a matter which I do not propose to comment on now—it will have an even better industry. I would hazard to suggest that, at the end of that period, even more timber will be taken not from native forests but from plantations, and I suspect that plantations will increase as a result of the RFA process.

One of the problems we have in dealing with this sort of legislation and environment issues generally is the nature of environmental politics. I have been a long-time supporter of environmental issues, and I have supported the environment movement in relation to many issues they have taken up about the forestry industry. Indeed, the forestry industry now will say that some of their past practices were horrendous, were unsustainable and ought to have been changed, and they have recognised that those practices changed, in part, through the contribution of the environment movement. I put on record today that the environment movement has played an important part in correcting some of the problems in the forestry industry and some other environmental issues.

The problem we have is the environment movement has not become an issues movement but a party political movement. To sustain itself, it needs the big issues to attract voters. It needs the icon environment issue so that it can run around and attract supporters to vote for it at the next election. Unfortunately, if the issue is not there, it has to do something, and that something is manufacture the issue. Unfortunately, there is a strong element of manufacturing issues in the complaints being made about the RFA process.

I am not saying the process is perfect and I am not saying that there is no scope for improvement. What I am saying is that we have moved from the environment movement saying that we need more and more plantation timber, that pine plantations were bad and that we should have a sustainable forestry industry, and we will get to the point where parts of the environment movement will do anything possible to sabotage the industry, irrespective of the impact that will have on jobs in regional economies in Tasmania, parts of Victoria, parts of New South Wales and parts of Western Australia. I am not saying that every RFA will necessarily be good.

talk.start.para: —How many jobs has it created in Tasmania?

—I listened to you peacefully, Senator Brown, so give me the same courtesy. In terms of each of those RFAs, the outcome of this legislation is as yet not determined. As I said before, I cannot make any comment without anticipating the debate on that legislation, which would be out of order. That debate is yet to be had. To have said in this debate that the RFAs fail to protect the remaining native forests of Australia is blatantly arrant nonsense and, as has been suggested, it has placed Senator Woodley, who is part of our committee, in a difficult position in relation to his position on the committee's report to the Senate. However, I noted that there was a difference of opinion between the Democrats earlier today on one of the votes. (Time expired)

—I will take up directly what Senator O'Brien just alluded to. Senator Bartlett chose to speak for the Democrats today. He stated that their policy was that the Democrats stand against the RFAs in total, which has totally compromised Senator Woodley. We on the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee know only too well that Senator Woodley would be quite split with Senator Bartlett on this issue. As far as I can gauge to this point, Senator Woodley has agreed with the processes and principles of the RFAs. But now we have to assume that the Democrats are against the processes and outcomes of all RFAs.

speech.para: Senator Bartlett failed to put any alternative before the Senate. The Democrats have no policy, other than to be against the RFAs. We can only assume that Senator Bartlett and the Democrats want to take us back to the old system, which was no system at all. It was just a system of confrontation, and it was the very reason the RFA process and outcomes were produced. Prior to that, we had terrible confrontations. Senators would remember only too well the logging trucks that surrounded Parliament House. That was one of the most dramatic demonstrations. The greens who invaded the East Gippsland area created another dramatic confrontation. All of those confrontations bring instability and uncertainty to the industry. All of them produce great social unrest and conflict for the 6 o'clock news, but that, it seems, is what the Democrats want to take us back to. The truth is they now join the extreme greens. Many of them, if not most of them, came before the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee to give evidence. They also wanted the total abolition of the RFA. That is the bottom line.

The truth is that they really do not want any logging at all. That is the stance of Senator Brown, which does not surprise any of us, but it does surprise us when the Democrats want to take up that position. They seem to be taking the side of the environmental movement, which wants the total abolition of the industry regardless of the $2 billion trade deficit we have at the moment. Senator O'Brien and Senator Forshaw, who surprisingly made some good contributions to this MPI—

talk.start.para: —They are usually excellent. This time they were good.

—Senator Forshaw, you spoilt your contribution when you politicised it by attacking the minister. You felt you had to do that, but that was nothing compared to the submissions we received from the environmental movement when they came before the committee, particularly when we were in Melbourne. Never have I seen a movement marginalise themselves so much before a Senate committee. They were intransigent. They were exhibitionists. They exaggerated their case. They were unresearched and fanatical.

speech.para: Senator Brown interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They were all those things, Senator Brown. I will give just one example. One group before us was Environment Victoria Inc., as they call themselves. They were involved in the early part of the RFA process and negotiations in East Gippsland. They went to the point of comparing the process of the RFA to Nazism, but they just could not get their point through. Their point was ridiculous. That was the type of language they used and it totally marginalised them in the debate.

speech.para: The truth is that they objected to the outcomes of the RFA, not the processes of it. If the processes fell completely their way, they would not be against RFAs. They objected to the outcome—an outcome that is based on some pretty sound principles, which it looks like they will never agree to. There are 11 national principles stated in the RFA as well as broad criteria for biodiversity. No criteria are broader than these: the protection of 90 per cent or more of high quality wilderness, and East Gippsland meets that criteria; a retention in reserves of at least 60 per cent of existing old growth, and East Gippsland meets that criteria; and a benchmark of 15 per cent of the pre-1750s distribution of each of the forest communities to be protected, and we meet that criteria and better it.

The truth is that, without the RFA process, without the RFA outcomes, we are going to go back to the bad old days of confrontation. That is what the Democrats want. Of course, that is what Senator Brown wants. He loves to see himself on the 6 o'clock news. But it will bring down the industry and it will cause great social disharmony.

cognateinfo.title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CHOICE OF SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bills received from the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: —I indicate to the Senate that those bills which have just been announced are being introduced together. After debate on the motion for the second reading has been adjourned, I will be moving a motion to have three of the bills listed separately on the Notice Paper . I move:

speech.para: That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—
SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1998
This bill amends the superannuation legislation to strengthen the efficiency and effectiveness of the superannuation supervisory framework.

Superannuation plays a significant role in the Government's commitment to increase national saving and in the Government's retirement income policy. It is therefore vital that an effective regulatory regime is in place and maintained to enhance the security of members' benefits and to ensure that superannuation entities operate for genuine retirement purposes.

The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (the SIS Act) provides for the prudential regulation of the superannuation industry between the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) and the Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC). An important aspect of prudential regulation is the monitoring and investigation powers of both Regulators.

This bill will improve monitoring and investigation powers by increasing the flexibility of the Regulators' existing powers, expanding the parties to whom they apply and increasing penalties for non-compliance. It is vital to the prudential regulation of superannuation moneys in Australia that the Regulators have effective monitoring and investigation powers.

Another important aspect of the regulatory framework is the existence of a complaints handling body to deal with member's superannuation complaints. The Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act (the SRC Act) established the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal to resolve fund member complaints about trustee decisions in a manner that is fair, informal and quick. This bill will enable the efficiency and productivity of the Tribunal to be improved, including allowing single member review panels. This will enhance the Tribunal's role in promoting public confidence in the superannuation regime.
The bill also contains a number of measures which will finetune and clarify the operation of the supervisory framework which will assist trustees in discharging their obligations to fund members.

In conclusion, this bill implements miscellaneous amendments to maintain and strengthen the superannuation supervisory framework. The amendments will increase the efficiency and effectiveness of the regulatory regime and improve confidence in the superannuation system more generally.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CHOICE OF SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 1998

The bill implements the Coalition Government's choice of superannuation fund measure. This measure was a key initiative in the 1997-98 Budget and involves reforms to give employees greater choice over which superannuation fund or Retirement Savings Account will receive superannuation contributions made on their behalf by their employer.

The choice of fund arrangements are about giving employees greater choice and control over their superannuation savings, which in turn will give them greater sense of ownership of these savings. The arrangements will increase competition and efficiency in the superannuation industry, leading to improved returns on superannuation savings.

The Government has consulted widely in putting together the details of this important reform. Extensive consultation led to enhancements of the original model being announced in November 1997. These were designed to significantly reduce the administrative burden on employers by allowing greater flexibility in how choice is offered, while ensuring that employees still had an effective choice of fund. The announced enhancements were widely welcomed by industry.

The Government is continuing to work with industry on the design details of the proposed key features statements. Draft key features statements were prepared in consultation with industry and have been market tested with a variety of groups. The results of the market testing is being fed into a redesign of the key features statements.

While the Government is prepared to consult and listen and respond to ensure the smoothest possible implementation of choice, it is not prepared to compromise on the fundamentals. The fundamentals of this reform are that employees get a genuine choice as to which fund their superannuation is paid. Models for implementing choice which effectively allow employers to veto an employee's choice simply do not meet this essential criteria.

The reforms to which this bill gives effect are scheduled to first operate from 1 July 1999 in respect of new employees, having already been deferred from 1 July 1998. It is time to conclude the debate on these important matters to allow their orderly implementation, for the benefit of all Australians as they save for their future.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1998

The bill contains two new exemptions from sales tax. The exemptions are for commercial space equipment and for certain goods imported by overseas participants and delegations attending the Sydney 2000 Olympics, Paralympics and associated events.
The bill will also remedy some weaknesses in the recently enacted scheme to prevent sales tax evasion in the computer industry and correct a deficiency in the temporary importation exemption.

The bill will implement the Government's policy to exempt from sales tax space launch vehicles, payloads and other goods intended for launch into outer space or to be brought back from outer space. This measure was announced on the 23 June this year.
The exemption will:
. encourage the development of a commercial space launch industry in Australia; and
. provide Australia with access to the growing world demand for commercial space launch facilities.

The space equipment exemption will apply from the date of Royal Assent. However, there will be a transitional credit for dealings on or after 23 June 1998 and before the date of Royal Assent. This will ensure that, as announced by the Government, dealings on or after 23 June do not bear sales tax.

The bill will also provide that certain goods, imported by or on behalf of non-Australian Olympic and Paralympic Family Members and delegations and participants in the Olympics, Paralympics and associated events, will be exempted from sales tax.
This exemption is in line with current sales tax arrangements with respect to SOCOG.
The first events covered by the new exemption and which occur during 1998 will be the Cultural Olympic event "A Sea Change" and the International Sailing Regatta.
The exemption will not apply to goods for sale, alcohol and tobacco products, motor vehicles and motor vehicle parts, television cameras and equipment for radio and television broadcasting.
The amendments complement recent changes to the customs law to exempt the same goods from customs duty.

The exemption will apply from the date of Royal Assent and, as for the space equipment measure, there will be a transitional credit arrangement. The credits will apply to dealings on or after 1 March 1998 (ie the commencement date for the proposed changes to the customs law) and before Royal Assent.
The Government proposes three changes to overcome some technical problems with the new scheme for dealing with sales tax evasion in the computer industry.
The first change will remove anomalies arising from current descriptions and tariff classifications in the law. This will apply from the date of introduction of the bill.

The second change will increase the maximum penalty for a person falsely representing himself or herself to be accredited or falsely representing a transaction to be authorised, and will increase the maximum penalty for making improper or false quotes under the law. The new maximum penalties of $5500 will apply from the date of Royal Assent.
The third change will close a loop-hole that allows traders to falsely present themselves as exporters in order to purchase or lease goods tax-free. This will apply from a date to be proclaimed.

The amendments will enhance the integrity of the new sales tax rules for computers which have addressed the entrenched culture of sales tax evasion previously evident in parts of the personal computer industry.

The bill also amends the sales tax law so that goods imported into Australia under a temporary importation exemption, used in Australia, exported and then re-imported, are subject to sales tax at the time of the second importation.
The amendment will correct a deficiency in the sales tax law from 13 May 1997 which is the date the Government announced the measure.
The explanatory memorandum explains in detail the changes to the law that the bill contains.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 5) 1998
This bill amends the income tax law to give effect to the following measures:
Firstly,

This bill gives effect to the 1998-99 Budget announcement to replace the existing late payment penalties in various taxation laws with a uniform tax deductible general interest charge. The new arrangements will be simpler and better reflect movements in market interest rates. The changes follow a review by the Australian Taxation Office of late payment and notification penalties in consultation with professional and representative bodies. That review flowed from the Government's response to the recommendations of the Small Business Deregulation Taskforce.

The charge on an outstanding amount will be calculated daily on a compounding basis. The nominal interest rate from which the daily charge is calculated will be set at the 13 Week Treasury Note rate plus 8 percentage points. The penalty for late lodgement of income tax returns of individuals and the penalty for underpayment of income tax will also adopt the general interest charge.
Secondly, the

This bill implements the announcement in the Government's tax reform paper, Tax Reform: not a new tax, a new tax system, that from 1 July 1999 the remittance dates for medium and small Pay As You Earn (PAYE), Prescribed Payments System (PPS) and Reportable Payments System (RPS) payers will move from the 7th to the 21st of the month.
The alignment to the 21st of the month is in anticipation of a large number of businesses being required to make one payment on the 21st of each quarter to cover most tax debts.Thirdly,

This bill also introduces amendments to support a system of running balance accounts. The objective of this measure is to establish a taxpayer accounting system under which the Australian Taxation Office can record and monitor all of a business's different tax liabilities on a single account. Debts under the sales tax, pay as you earn, prescribed payments and reportable payments arrangements for the year ending 30 June 2000 will be administered in this way.
The introduction of running balance accounts will provide for simpler tax accounting and collection arrangements.

These new accounting and penalty arrangements will position the ATO to better assist taxpayers in minimising any escalation of taxation debt and will allow for a simpler and more efficient process of penalty calculation.
They will also enable the ATO to provide a comprehensive statement of a taxpayer's outstanding tax debts at a particular point in time.
These amendments will provide an accounting platform in the lead up to one running balance style account to support most taxation debts after 1 July 2000.
And lastly,

para.inline: Tax avoidance: foreign tax credit schemes

speech.para: This measure amends the general anti-avoidance provisions of Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (the act) to render ineffective schemes designed to acquire or generate foreign tax credits that can be used to shelter low-taxed foreign source income from Australian tax.

A foreign tax credit scheme operates on the basis that foreign income is earned which gives rise to an entitlement to foreign tax credits. A scheme is entered into whereby a foreign income stream is acquired by another taxpayer. Where the acquisition cost of the income stream is deductible to that another taxpayer those deductions largely cancel out the foreign income the other taxpayer has now acquired. The major portion of the foreign tax credits which relate to the acquired foreign income stream are then available to offset tax payable on the taxpayer's other foreign income of the same class.

The Australian Taxation Office became aware that these types of schemes were being promoted in Australia. The Commissioner of Taxation does not accept the efficacy of these arrangements, and proposes to challenge them under the existing law in the courts. To put a stop to the development of future schemes the Government announced on 13 August 1998 that it would amend the general anti-avoidance provisions of Part IVA of the act to render such schemes ineffective.
These types of arrangements have also been identified in the United States and the United Kingdom and remedial action has also swiftly been taken in both those countries.
The amendment is designed to protect the revenue base. In the absence of such swift action the revenue base could be exposed to a significant threat.

The Government also announced on 13 August 1998, as part of its tax reform package Tax Reform—not a new tax—a new tax system , that it will modernise the general anti-avoidance rules. This process will be conducted in line with the principles of the integrated tax code. In view of the threat that the foreign tax credit schemes posed to the revenue base it was necessary to announce the measures and bring legislation to the Parliament as soon as possible rather than await the modernisation of the general anti-avoidance rules.
Full details of the measures in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
GENERAL INTEREST CHARGE (IMPOSITION) BILL 1998
The bill accompanies Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1998 which replaces existing late payment penalties in various taxation laws with a uniform tax deductible general interest charge.
The Imposition Bill will impose the new general interest charge as a tax to the extent to which the charge cannot validly be imposed as a penalty.
Details of the measures in both bills are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
