This is obviously a very important issue. It is an issue that has arisen from a lot of public concern and many concerns raised in the parliament, particularly by me on behalf of the opposition in relation to what I believe has been a mechanism used by the government to subvert the disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act.

What our amendments are about—the first three that have been accepted by the committee and these three—is simply this: we want to end once and for all what we believe is the vehicle by which the Liberal Party has exploited any real or apparent loopholes in the Electoral Act. The vehicle that is being used, the Greenfields Foundation, has meant that one of the major political parties in this country, the majority party in this coalition government, has been able to dodge full and transparent disclosure. I want to say this, being as generous as I can in the circumstances: the government did take some steps to address recommendation 10 of the March 1998 report of the AEC into funding and disclosure by broadening the investigative powers of the AEC in dealing with and determining whether or not an organisation is an associated entity.

We found out, as senators would know, during questioning of the Australian Electoral Commission at Senate estimates hearings last week, that the AEC recently utilised these powers for the first time to serve notice on the Greenfields Foundation on 15 January 1999. While those particular government amendments were sufficient for the purpose of broadening the investigative powers of the AEC in pursuing suspected associated entities, they have not gone far enough in relation to the crucial issue of closing the loophole in the legislation. That is what the opposition wants to do.

Let me explain to the committee what our amendments here are about. Firstly, they tighten the definition of `associated entity'. Secondly, they close the loophole in the event of the loan being given ultimately becoming a gift. Thirdly, they prevent loans from being received from anyone other than a registered financial institution unless certain information, such as terms and conditions of the loan, are disclosed. I might continue arguing this very strong case tomorrow.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is the final report of the Safety Review Committee which has the responsibility to ensure the safety of the operations at Lucas Heights. It is the final report because its responsibilities are being taken over by the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency and its councils and committees. The responsibility of this committee cannot be underestimated. Nuclear safety is an issue of paramount concern, and I have no reason to doubt the integrity or the qualifications or the commitment to safety or even the effectiveness of the committee in ensuring safety. But this report gives me no reason to have a lot of confidence either. One of the problems is the superficiality of much of the report. Whenever there is something of potential concern, it gets a glancing mention which raises more questions than answers. I will come to some of those concerns and the questions that come to mind in a moment.

The other problem is that the committee considered there were no matters arising in regard to the committee's functions B, C and D during the period of the report. These are the functions involving investigating and advising on matters which may have adverse consequences or safety implications. Even from the relative superficiality of the report, it is clear that there were matters that could well have been investigated. For example, there is the matter of the granting of temporary exemption from certain operating limits and conditions.

The report gives us no indication of which operating limits or conditions. Perhaps the minister could throw some light on this. Were these exemptions related to allowed levels of radiation exposure? What were the causes of the events which led to exemptions? Were the causes age related and do they have implications for the reactor surviving to the year 2005? Following these exemptions, the report tells us, the Nuclear Safety Bureau required ANSTO to provide data on the state of the reactor 24 hours after start-up. It would be nice to know that what that data said was okay.

Another issue worthy of investigation is the advice from the Nuclear Safety Bureau that, with foreseeable resource demands for the replacement reactor project, the potential exists for resources to be diverted from HIFAR to the detriment of current high standards of reactor operations. When the Nuclear Safety Bureau starts flagging concerns like this, it is time to take notice. They draw attention to the loss of two senior staff, which they say represents a significant loss of managerial and technical expertise.

What this highlights is the issue of the skills base in Australia and the potential for difficulties in staffing the new reactor and the various monitoring bodies, especially when the new reactor might be running alongside the existing one for a period of time. It is good to see the Nuclear Safety Bureau being proactive in drawing attention to this problem, and I wonder if they have expanded on those concerns in the environmental impact statement on the new reactor.

Another issue arises in relation to the intermediate level liquid wastes. We are told liquid waste will be treated in a hot cell by a process of evaporation, de-ammoniation and solidification. We have been told this before. The question is: when will the process start? We are told the solid product may be suitable for processing into a ceramic form similar to synroc. May? This is typical of attitudes throughout the nuclear industry: create any amount of waste and work out what to do about it eventually. This is really not good enough.

Then there is the problem of the water in the spent fuel storage tubes. Again, it gets a mention in the report, but again the interesting thing is what is not said. How did the water get there? If it is rain water, then it must have been there for more than 10 years. What does that say about monitoring? How often are they checked and how? What about some genuinely independent monitoring? The International Atomic Energy Agency's monitoring is only to see if the seal is still in place. That is not safety monitoring. Is there any chance that corroded fuel elements will corrode further now that they are back in the ground? If water can get in through a faulty seal, one must wonder what can get out.

One area in which the Safety Review Committee seems to have been doing some good work is in putting pressure on the industry in relation to worker safety. It is disappointing to note that there are still three radiation related injuries and five occasions on which radioactive materials were an accident factor. Thankfully, the doses involved were relatively small, but the fact is that any radiation accident is a serious worry. In the same way as we must work towards zero accidents, we must also work towards zero waste emissions. What guarantees can the minister give that the budget for capital works upgrade of waste management will be sufficient to achieve that end?

Finally, it is worth noting that what I see as deficiencies in the comprehensiveness of this report may be addressed to some extent by the strengthened community representation and reporting requirements which we achieved through amendments to the ARPANSA legislation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I too rise to make some comments with respect to the annual report of the Safety Review Committee for 1997-98. As Senator Margetts has noted, this is the final report of the Safety Review Committee. That body has now been superseded by the establishment of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency, colloquially referred to as ARPANSA. The establishment of ARPANSA is noted in the report, but for the period that this report covered the legislation had gone through the House of Representatives but was awaiting approval by the Senate. That is noted at pages 5 to 7 of the report.

speech.para: I wish to make some comments about the establishment of ARPANSA. Like many, I was looking forward to the establishment of ARPANSA as setting the scene for an increased level of scrutiny and regulation of Australia's nuclear industry. As honourable senators are aware, I have a particular interest and involvement in this issue because I happen to reside in the Sutherland Shire, not far from the Lucas Heights reactor and, like all honourable members of parliament, what is close to home is often an issue that is dear to our hearts. Of course, the issues involved here are ones which affect all Australians. Consequently, it is absolutely essential that any body established to oversee the operations of our nuclear industry, particularly the operations of ANSTO, is totally independent.

My initial enthusiasm for the establishment of ARPANSA, which filled in many of the gaps that existed in the regulatory system within Australia, has waned somewhat. It has waned, firstly, because the legislation, when it was brought to this Senate, was grossly inadequate. It was only because of the amendments that were put forward by the opposition parties and the Greens in this chamber that we ended up with an act which goes a long way to ensuring that improved system of regulation and improved system of scrutiny. Since then, however, I have become rather concerned about what the future holds.

At the recent Senate estimates committee on 8 February—the Community Affairs Legislation Committee estimates—representatives of ARPANSA and the Department of Health and Family Services appeared before the committee. In evidence to that committee it was indicated that the chief executive officer's position at ARPANSA has still not been filled on a permanent basis. A Dr John Loy is in an acting capacity.

What was more disturbing was that—following questions from myself to the departmental officer—it was revealed in evidence that a selection committee had been established within the department to draw up a short list of applicants to go to the minister, from which he would make a choice as to who the new chief executive would be. The most disturbing feature of all is that one of the three members of that committee drawing up that short list of applicants is the current head of ANSTO, Professor Helen Garnett.

I make no personal reflection upon Professor Helen Garnett's professionalism or qualifications but, as is said in the law, justice must not only be done, it must be seen to be done. If ARPANSA is to be an independent regulatory authority charged with the responsibility of overseeing the operations of ANSTO—in particular, the Lucas Heights reactor—then the head of ANSTO, the body to be regulated and scrutinised, should not be on the selection committee determining who should head up this independent regulatory authority. I am amazed by that and I would urge the government to rethink its approach to filling this position. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.01 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —In a well ordered world, the role of the state is to protect the individual. The role of the state is to ensure that mechanisms exist so that the weak and the vulnerable do not fall prey to others in society who would wish to take advantage of them. To this end, we have established in this country—and elsewhere in the Western world—elaborate mechanisms to protect the weak and vulnerable. The problem arises, however, that sometimes those systems become corrupted. Sometimes, organs of the state, instead of being a protection for the weak and the vulnerable, become instead mechanisms of oppression.

speech.para: Tonight, in the first of two planned contributions in this chamber, I want to outline the circumstances by which one of those organs of the state, instead of protecting the weak and vulnerable people—as the intention was when it was established—became a mechanism to continue the oppression of the weak and the vulnerable. The organ to which I refer was the then Australian Securities Commission. The matter in question arose out of a failed fraudulent investment scheme in Queensland called Aust-Home Investments. It was a scheme which, at its height, conned hundreds of people into investing their funds, never to see them again. To this day, the promoters of this scheme have not been prosecuted. They have been allowed to go unscathed by the law, notwithstanding the fact that what they did constituted a criminal fraud.

I will outline how that situation arose. It was because of the manner in which investi gators in the Australian Securities Commission handled, or mishandled, the investigation of the case. The circumstances were these. On 24 April 1991, the Australian Securities Commission commenced an investigation, under section 13 of the Australian Securities Commission Act, into the affairs of Aust-Home Investments Ltd. On 27 and 30 May of that same year, they attended the premises of Aust-Home Investments and served statutory notices on 13 scheme companies—that is, companies associated with the principal entity, including all core entities. Certain documents were obtained as a result of those notices being served, but the ASC came to believe that other documents were not produced which should have been produced under those notices. Consequently, from 30 June until October 1991, the ASC conducted examinations of 21 persons related to that scheme. Some of the people who were examined were, in fact, scheme promoters, but many others who were examined were innocent victims of the fraud.

On 30 and 31 July 1991, and also on 6 August 1991, search warrants, pursuant to section 10 of the Crimes Act, were executed on offices which belonged to Aust-Home Investments at Astor Terrace in Brisbane and on 9 August warrants were executed on the residence of a scheme promoter. An enormous amount of information was obtained. How, then, can it be that, in spite of a substantial investigation, in spite of the fact that millions of dollars had disappeared, and in spite of the fact that millions of dollars of incorrect tax deductions had been claimed—innocently by the victims of the fraud but as a deliberate consequence on the part of the promoters—nobody has been prosecuted? The answer to this question lies in something called the derivative use immunity.

The problem was that the examinations were conducted under provisions of the Australian Securities Commission law contained in section 19 of its act, which enabled the investigators to compel people to answer questions. The problem was that evidence obtained under compulsion could not be used in a prosecution against the people who were the subject of the examination. So all of the evidence obtained by the investigators in their examinations of the promoters was tainted evidence. It was flawed from the start. So, notwithstanding the fact that all of the information was available to the investigators of the Australian Securities Commission, once they had obtained all that information that showed what had happened to the money no prosecutions arose.

Over the years I have detailed some of the activities of the promoters of this scheme. I do not intend in this place at this time to rehash that, but honourable senators who are interested can find it easily in the Hansard. They will find, for example, that these promoters tried on subsequent dates in different places to perpetuate the same schemes in other states to con other innocent investors. One of the claims that the promoters used when they went to these other states and set up similar schemes was that it could not have been illegal to do what they had done because otherwise they would have been prosecuted by the Australian Securities Commission. A glib line, a line that tellingly assisted them in conning other innocent people.

But it was not just the promoters who were examined under section 19. Some innocent investors, for example, Mrs Margot Bunt in Queensland, were also examined. The emotional toll that this took on Mrs Bunt and others is incalculable. Many investors had their private assets frozen for years whilst the Australian Securities Commission continued with the fiction that they were ultimately going to prosecute the scheme promoters. However, no prosecutions arose. Eventually, a condensed report was prepared by the Australian Securities Commission, dated 19 October 1995. This report sought to explain why no prosecutions took place. Section 17 of that report at clause 8.1.5 says:

In the immediate case, it was believed that the immunity unavoidably affected the admissibility against the principal scheme promoter of all evidence obtained by the ASC on execution on 9 August 1991 of search warrants at 35 Astor Terrace office of the scheme and the promoter's residential address. This was because the sworn information relied upon by the ASC to support the granting of the subject warrants made a general reference to answers given during ASC examination pursuant to Section 19 of the ASC law on 6 August 1991 during the course of which privilege against self incrimination was claimed.
The report goes on to say:

In late January 1995, following consideration of advice received from DPP, it became apparent that all evidence obtained by the ASC subsequent to execution of the warrants, but which in any way was sought by the ASC in whole or partial reliance on the search warrant evidence may be inadmissible. In practical terms, it is believed that the immunity would also impact upon the admissibility on all other evidence obtained subsequent to the examination.

But the fact is that in 1991 the ASC knew of the impact of the derivative use immunity and in fact mention was made of it on 13 August 1991 in a submission to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, in which the ASC said that care had to be taken in framing an investigation to ensure that derivative use immunity did not allow criminals to get off the hook. Yet this is what happened, and the ASC continued with this fiction for four years to cover up what could at best be described as its own negligence. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an opinion from Hunt & Hunt Lawyers and an attachment thereto.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Hunt & Hunt
Lawyers
Incorporating
Thompson King Connolly
OPINION RE: MRS MARGOT BUNT

Mrs Bunt has consulted us over many months in relation to matters relating to Aust-Home Investments Limited and the investigation by the Australian Securities Commission (as it then was) of the affairs into that company in the early 1990s.
We have previously prepared a memorandum setting out a chronology of the events that occurred in that matter and append a copy of it.

What was clear at the time the memorandum was prepared and what remains clear today is that practices and procedures of the Australian Securities Commission (as it was then) were either not followed in the course of the investigation in relation to Aust-Home Investments Limited and associated companies and its directors or were disregarded. The consequence of the failure to follow the directions or of the disregarding of them is that the Australian Securities Commission was unable to bring any proceedings against the perpe trator of the scheme which solicited millions of dollars of investor's funds which were lost.
That the Australian Securities Commission was aware of the relevant procedures is clear from the references to it in the attachment.

In clause 9.0.6 of the Condensed Report by the Australian Securities Commission under section 17 of the ASC Law dated 19 October 1995 said "notwithstanding the achievement of civil remedies, it is a fact that further ASC investigation did not culminate in criminal prosecution action. It is an unfortunate feature of this investigation that the impact of derivative use immunity was not fully identified until enquiries had reached a well advanced stage".
The Report went on to say, in 9.0.7:

"Whilst the immunity, since the amendment of subsection 68(3) of the ASC Law, currently does not affect evidence collected by the ASC, the experience nevertheless provides a salutary lesson to the ASC of the need to ensure the early identification of thresholds issues in relation to the immiscibility of evidence, prior continuing in investigation with an attendant expenditure of time resources and inconvenience to both witnesses and persons themselves the subject of investigation".

In 9.0.9, the report stated "whilst nevertheless conceding that the officers' subsequent actions had inadvertently attracted the derivative use immunity, it is not altogether certain that the officers could have acted differently and still ensure the efficient and expeditious procurement of evidence necessary to support the ASC's civil application".

Mrs Bunt is offended by the reference to the actions "inadvertently" attracting derivative use immunity. ASC was well aware of the matters at exactly the same time as the officers were carrying out the raids (see attachment for chronology).

Mrs Bunt's life has been devastated by the events surrounding the investigation, the freezing of assets, subsequent delays, the impact of the ASC's examination into the life of herself and her husband. As a result, her marriage has broken down and she is greatly concerned that she has lost not only the assets of herself and her husband but her marriage.

She believes she is strongly aggrieved and, upon consideration of the sequence of events, the attempted justification by the Commission of its actions as mere "inadvertence" does nothing to satisfy Mrs Bunt's anger or pain in the matters that have affected her life.
In the circumstances, an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the investigation and the subsequent report would appear to be justified.
Hunt and Hunt
Lawyers
DJG98803409NOPI

Mrs Bunt's concern is based upon the treatment she received from the investigators under ASC and the difficulties which ASC suffered in pursuing a criminal prosecution because of the way they carried out their investigations.

Mrs Bunt's concern is that the purported explanation of ASC does not accord with what one ought expect the ASC to say if it was acting consistently with a submission made jointly with DPP to the Joint Committee on Corporations & Securities and dated 13 August 1991.
The chronology is as follows:-
April 24 1991:
ASC intervened and commenced an investigation under Section 13 of the ASC law into the affairs of Aust-Home Investments Limited ("AHI").

ASC officers attend AHI premises and served statutory notices on 13 Scheme Companies including all core entities. Certain documents were obtained as a result of those notices being served that ASC believed that there had been a failure to produce documents which should have been produced under those notices.
June 30—October 1991
ASC conducted examinations of 21 persons relative to the scheme.
July 30 and 31 1991 and August 6 1991

Search warrants pursuant to Section 10 of the Crimes Act 1914 (Commonwealth) were executed on office premises of AHI at 35 Astor Terrace, Brisbane and on August 9, 1991 upon the residence of a scheme promoter.

Subsequently no prosecutions were launched against the scheme promoter in respect of what appears to be breaches of the Corporations Law. The Section 17 Report of ASC dated 19 October 1995 said, at clause 8.1.5:-

"In the immediate case, it was believed that the immunity unavoidably affected the admissibility against the principal scheme promoter of all evidence obtained by the ASC on execution on 9 August 1991 of search warrants at 35 Astor Terrace office of the scheme and the promoter's residential address. This was because the sworn Information relied upon by the ASC to support the granting of the subject warrants made a general reference to answers given during ASC examination pursuant to Section 19 of the ASC law on 6 August 1991 during the course of which privilege against self incrimination was claimed."
In clause 8.1.6 of the Report, it claimed:-

"In late January 1995, following consideration of advice received from DPP, it became apparent that all evidence obtained by the ASC subsequent to execution of the warrants, but which in any way was sought by the ASC in whole or partial reliance on the search warrant evidence may be inadmissible. In practical terms, it is believed that the immunity would also impact upon the admissibility on all other evidence obtained subsequent to the examination. . . .."

This attributes to the ASC a lack of knowledge, appreciation or understanding of the effect of what had been done in executing the warrants in August 1991 until DPP advice was received in January 1995.
And at Clause 9.0.7 it says:

"Whilst the immunity, since the amendment of Section 68(3) of the ASC law, currently does not affect evidence collected by the ASC, the experience nevertheless provides a salutary lesson to the ASC of the need to ensure the early identification of threshold issues in relation to the admissibility of evidence, prior to continuing an investigation with an attendant expenditure of time and resources and inconvenience to both witnesses and persons themselves the subject of investigation."
In clause 9.0.9 it further says:

"Whilst nevertheless conceding that the officers' subsequent actions had inadvertently attracted the derivative use immunity it is not altogether certain that the officers could have acted differently to ensure the efficient and expeditious procurement of evidence necessary to support the ASC's application.".

The question Mrs Bunt asks, in our opinion reasonably, is why the term "inadvertently" is used. The term implies accidental or unintended consequences. However, in the 13 August 1991 Submission to the Joint Committee on Corporations & Securities, it discusses in paragraph 2 the "practical and substantive difficulties arising out of the derivative use immunity." In clause 2.1 the Submission states:-
". . . .if an investigation is to proceed, a plan is prepared having regard to the means available to the ASC to gather information as evidence."

In Clause 2.2.2, the submission states:-". . . when the investigation plan is being prepared, the ASC cannot know whether it will pursue civil remedies or criminal prosecutions or both, nor will it be in a position to remedy the specific remedies or charges which will arise for consideration of a possible or likely defendant. The strategy which must be adopted, therefore, is that the Commission must have regard to the derivative use of immunity so as to minimise any prejudice to the possibility of either civil or criminal proceedings."

Why, then would the ASC be surprised by the advice in January 1995 of DPP as to the impact of the derivative use immunity rule on the evidence obtained as a result of the execution of the warrants in the same month as the ASC was submitting it concern as to the impact of those warrants in its submission to the Joint Committee? It is perfectly clear that the ASC understood the problems involved. In this case, did the ASC proceed knowing the possible consequences and notwithstanding those consequences? Simply put, the statements made in paragraph 2 of the submission make it clear ASC knew in August 1991 the difficulties that existed by reason of the derivative use immunity rule and that, in recognition of the difficulty, it had put a procedure in place within ASC to take that into consideration. If it was aware of the consequences, why did it state in its Report to the Minister in clause 8.1.6 line 2 that "it became apparent. . . .", which conveys to the reader that this was a position which ASC did not appreciate or understand before that time? This would mean that the practice referred to in the Submission was not on this occasion followed. If that was true, Mrs Bunt is entitled to know why that was not done.
See Girvan Report 1.1 where demonstrates the existence of procedures which, when followed, avoided a scenario by which the persons suspected of offences were not orally examined.

Our client finds no adequate explanation has been given to her. We believe our client is entitled to a proper explanation and a reason as to why prosecutions have not been launched against the scheme promoter and the reasons for the ASC's actions in taking the steps it did.
Could you please obtain an adequate response for our client on this issue.

talk.start.para: —I am speaking tonight in response to Senator Vanstone's answer in question time yesterday in regard to drug strategies and the assertion that the Carr government should put up or shut up when it came to the question of drugs. Given the facts of the situation and the efforts of the Carr government, it is the Howard government and Senator Vanstone that should put up or shut up.

speech.para: Last December Senator Vanstone claimed in a press release that the Commonwealth was winning the war on drugs. Yesterday she was attacking Bob Carr and the New South Wales government for failing to stem the drug problem in New South Wales. How can the Commonwealth be winning the war on drugs if the New South Wales situation is as bad as Senator Vanstone suggests? Surely New South Wales is not faring as badly as Senator Vanstone suggests or the tough on drugs strategy is not winning the war on drugs. Which is it?

I suggest there is no easy answer to the problems Australia is facing with the increasing use of illicit drugs. There is no magic wand that can be waved that will make the drug problem go away. But the New South Wales government under Bob Carr is certainly doing its best and exploring all options to deal with the drug problem, with very little help from the Commonwealth government. Here are a few facts for the good senator about what is really happening in the New South Wales.

More drugs are being seized in New South Wales. In the year to June 1998, drug detections in New South Wales rose by 12 per cent. In 1997, a total of 211 kilograms of heroin was seized, which was almost 80 kilograms more than under the previous coalition government reign. Last year just under half a billion dollars worth of heroin was seized in New South Wales alone. The Carr government has increased the number of police specifically targeting drugs. There are almost 90 more police men and women solely responsible for fighting the war against drugs than there were previously under the coalition government.

The New South Wales police agencies that focus on drugs and drug related crime have been reconstructed so that they are more effective. This is a direct result of the damning evidence to the New South Wales police royal commission about corrupt practices in the old Drug Enforcement Agency—a system which the New South Wales opposition has repeatedly advocated a return to. In 1997-98, the New South Wales Crime Commission seized assets from major drug dealers more than ever before. More than $11 million was seized. More major drug offenders have been arrested.

The Carr government has recently spent large amounts of money on new facilities for detoxification and drug and alcohol treatment in Sydney's west, on the north coast, and on the Central Coast. And is this represented in the report mentioned by Senator Vanstone? No. The report which the senator is using as the basis for her attacks on Bob Carr is flawed. The methodology is defective. It does not consider changes in accounting procedures when it claims that the per capita expenditure on health related drug programs in New South Wales has fallen. It does not consider recent initiatives such as the spending on new detoxification facilities or the money for the trialling of naltrexone—for which there was no help from the federal government. The report and the federal government are also ignoring the Carr government's newest initiative of the drug court.

The New South Wales government is leading the way with the drug court. There is $12 million of new spending on the court, including $5.6 million for new drug treatment services. The aims of the drug court are to reduce crime caused by heroin addiction, to help the offender get off drugs, and to reduce recidivism. The American experience has shown that the drug court can be quite successful in achieving these objectives.

The drug court provides an opportunity for drug addicts who have committed crimes to support their addiction to get treatment. To be eligible for the drug court, offenders must be dependent on drugs, facing a prison term, prepared to admit guilt and willing to participate in the treatment program. However, those charged with sexual or violent offences cannot go before the court. If the offender admits guilt and chooses treatment, their sentence is suspended, and they are given 12 months of drug treatment and rehabilitation. The offender must comply with strict rules, including regular court appearances and random drug testing. If these rules are breached, strict penalties, including imprisonment, will apply.

Of course the drug court is no panacea, nor is it going soft on drugs. Instead, it is just another part of the multifaceted approach of rehabilitation, education and tough law enforcement undertaken by the New South Wales government and Bob Carr. The government in New South Wales is doing what it can to resolve the drug problem.

But what is the federal government doing? The federal government, not the New South Wales government, has jurisdiction over imports to Australia. The New South Wales government cannot do much about customs at all. That is a federal responsibility.

According to statistics, all heroin is imported into Australia, but it is estimated that only 10 per cent of the 2,000 kilograms of heroin used in Australia each year is detected. Only two per cent of international flights are searched for prohibited drugs. That means that 98 per cent of international flights are not searched at all. So unless Customs or the Federal Police are made aware that person X is likely to be smuggling drugs the drugs will just fly straight into our country.

Heroin enters Australia predominantly through commercial shipping and flights—with the much larger quantity through importation by sea cargo. But Australian Customs searches only three in 10,000 containers. That is 0.03 per cent of all containers that enter this country. So for the three containers that are searched, 9,997 are not.

Eighty per cent of heroin enters Australia though Sydney, and Sydney is Australia's principal distribution centre, unfortunately. All evidence supports an increased effort in Sydney, but the National Illicit Drug Strategy, of which Senator Vanstone is so proud, will divert resources away from Sydney. This is precisely the opposite of what is needed.

There are no easy answers to the issue of illegal drugs and the problems that result from their use. But Senator Vanstone's approach of claiming credit when there is none to be claimed and then attacking the one state government in Australia which is daring to explore new avenues for coping with drug related crime is an unhelpful and unconstructive contribution to a very important debate facing our society today.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to complete some remarks I made yesterday after question time in response to Senator Alston's remarks when he said:

speech.para: It has been perfectly clear that there has been a pattern of obstruction and a deliberate attempt being made on a regular basis to stall proceedings.

He was referring to me. If anyone is putting at risk the time line for completion of the Telstra sale inquiry, it is the government. And if there was any question of my wanting to delay the proceedings, I could have easily done so on Monday during that hearing, when there was not a quorum and the hearing process could have been stopped at that point. But I did not do that, because I have at all times—as have other members of the committee—made every attempt to cooperate, however absurd the government's time lines turn out to be. There is no need for me to go over those time lines tonight, but it must be said that submissions to that inquiry closed on 15 January. The government says there have been two months, but of course December-January is not an ideal time to call for submissions to an inquiry, particularly when this inquiry is competing with two other inquiries of the committee.

But the point is that on this inquiry, as on all others, I have made every effort to fit in with the wishes of the chair and the other members of the committee. Let us take the events leading up to yesterday's hearing. On Thursday, 3 February the hearing in Canberra was scheduled to finish at 4.45 p.m. I had a meeting arranged with two of my colleagues in Sydney at 7.30 that evening prior to a half-day meeting the following day, and I arranged to fly out at 5.20 p.m. from Canberra on that Thursday night.

During estimates, the committee met and government members—no doubt on the instructions of Senator Alston—proposed that we hold a Senate inquiry one evening during estimates. It is my understanding that all senators are entitled to attend estimates, and I certainly had many issues I wished to and subsequently did raise with the environment minister. That estimates session did not conclude until around 11.30 p.m. that night. Had we scheduled the Telstra hearing for five o'clock on that day, it would have to have been cancelled and arrangements with people who would have appeared would also have had to be cancelled. In any case, I was not prepared to give up what I regard as a very important part of my role in participating in estimates, particularly in the areas of environment and education, and I stand by that decision.

As Senator Bishop mentioned on Monday, a short private committee meeting agreed that we would complete the inquiry on the morning of Monday the 15th. I indicated that our regular party room meeting was on at 9.30 a.m. and that, particularly since this was the first meeting of the new sitting, I was not prepared to proceed beyond that point. I was willing to start at 8 o'clock or earlier to allow time for further questions of the department and for Telstra's presentation. In any event, the committee decided to schedule the meeting for 8.30 a.m. on Monday, and this decision was made in a private meeting last week before I had a chance to arrive, in spite of the fact that I came as soon as I was advised. I understand it was decided to conduct the hearing until 10.45 a.m. in the knowledge that I could not be there beyond 9.30 a.m.

Senator Carr and I were ready to begin at the appointed time on Monday, but it was, in fact, almost half an hour later that the teleconferencing link was actually made through to Telstra in Sydney and Melbourne, leaving just 30 minutes for the hearing. Again, it was not my fault that proceedings were delayed. As I have said, the hearing finally did go ahead without a quorum. The government must take full responsibility for both the impossible time lines it has adopted and the abuses of process that have been necessary to achieve that.

I am happy to show Senator Alston my diary, which shows that between 3 February and 15 March there are only two weekdays on which there are no Senate committee hearings or parliamentary sittings, and I have offered both of these as possible hearing dates. If Senator Alston and Senator Eggleston insist on bulldozing government legislation through the Senate committee process and attacking the Democrats with false accusations, the cooperative approach which I have been describing may have to give way to an insistence on formal compliance with standing orders. The Democrats remain at all times professional and responsible in our handling of government legislation, and it is my view that Senator Alston should apologise for his intemperate and misleading remarks.

Last night the committee did indeed finish the Telstra sale inquiry, and it did so at around 11 p.m. when there was sufficient time for us to ask questions of both Telstra and the department, although I must say that a lot of questions still remain to be answered, and I look forward to the minister's response to those when the bill comes into the parliament.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals: Battery Hens

talk.start.para: —Last week the RSPCA launched a national campaign to help keep hens out of cages. The campaign calls for an end to the production of eggs by intensive husbandry. The RSPCA calls it `battery hen produced eggs'. The campaign is being supported by radio commercials, postcards, posters and direct mail. Letters have already been sent to some of us, imploring that we should help the society to end the suffering of battery caged hens. The RSPCA calls for `the Australian public to support alternative systems of egg production for the sake of layer hens'. In fact, they say it is up to the Australian public to care enough about the suffering of what they call battery hens to insist on humane egg production. I quote from a letter the society's president, Dr Wirth, wrote to me, which claims:

speech.para: .. preventing hens from performing natural behaviours causes immense frustration.
Further, he said:
. . . restricted movement and lack of exercise in battery cages causes skeletal and muscle weakness and the cages' mesh floors and lack of perches can cause serious muscle damage.

He goes on to claim that legislation should be passed in every state and territory to ban battery hens. You might say this is the role of the RSPCA, that concern for the plight of animals is a primary part of the society's objective to prevent cruelty to animals by enforcing the existing laws—`all creatures great and small', according to their general publicity.

I support and commend the work of the society in their efforts to reduce animal cruelty. They have as their creed the five freedoms for animals: freedom from hunger and thirst; freedom from discomfort; freedom from pain, injury and disease; the right and freedom to express normal behaviour; and freedom from fear and distress. Campaigns in the past have all focused on those five points and on the society's objectives.

The society's concerns about the well-being of birds led it to be part of a 1994 report into the industry. In 1994 a working group which included the society made a recommendation which concluded that `no attempt be made to ban cage system egg production'. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy at the time, then Senator Bob Collins, said after the agreement was made that he was delighted at the outcome and pleased that both the industry and mainstream animal welfare interests supported the approach to ensure the welfare of layer hens.

Subsequently, the RSPCA was given an accreditation scheme for barn-laid eggs. So after the 1994 investigation and report all parties seemed satisfied with the outcome. The industry was happy with the code of conduct and so was the RSPCA. I am therefore somewhat puzzled as to why the RSPCA is now pursuing this very negative campaign against a legitimate Australian industry. Could it be that the RSPCA now lacks confidence in the existing legislation, then endorsed by all states and territories, governing hen production? Maybe so.

Dr Wirth said over the weekend that he was sure that 75 per cent of egg producers were doing the right thing, and I suspect the number is a lot higher. So it seems unlikely to me that this is the basis for the campaign. To be frank, if that was so, I would have expected the society's campaign to be targeted more towards the law-makers—the state and territory governments. But, instead, the society is hitting consumers and legitimate egg producers with a `buy barn-laid eggs' campaign—in other words, `Don't buy the eggs which just a couple of years ago were endorsed by the organisation.' So what other reason could there be? I wonder whether, in an industry worth over $525 million in retail sales in 1997, there is some other gain to be made by the RSPCA in the promotion of barn-laid eggs?

We have a situation now where the RSPCA receives royalty payments from the commercial sale of barn-laid eggs. In fact, the royalty is said to be about 5c for every dozen eggs sold. Yet nowhere in this campaign, nowhere in the materials that have been sent to me, does the RSPCA make it clear that by supporting the increased demand for barn-laid eggs, consumers will in fact be contributing dollars in revenue to the RSPCA. Nowhere in the campaign package, in its media releases or even on its Internet site does the RSPCA acknowledge the monetary gain it is making from this campaign.

Yesterday, a week after the campaign began, Dr Wirth, the President, admitted somewhat reluctantly on ABC Radio that the society has a `vested interest because we of course get a royalty'. So there you have it. Dr Wirth has been calling for a `consumer-led revolution on behalf of these poor unfortunate chooks'. Now we have to ask: is this a genuine concern about animal welfare by the society or is it a covert attempt for competitive advantage in this industry?

Let us remember that around 200 million dozen eggs are produced in Australia each year, with 93 per cent coming from caged birds, two per cent from barn-house birds and five per cent from free-range birds. So if the RSPCA earns two per cent from the sale of barn-laid eggs, the organisation is getting around $200,000 a year in royalty payments. How many of these well-meaning consumers and the recipients of the campaign material know this? If, as the RSPCA wants, egg production by intensive means is banned, industry sources suggest that the price of a dozen eggs would increase by at least a dollar. If barn-laid and free-range eggs were to capture at least half that market, the RSPCA would then be in line for millions of dollars in royalties.

It seems to me that this publicity campaign is now very close to becoming a conflict of interest. Tonight I call on the RSPCA to publicly disclose this financial interest, to tell us how much they have received in royalties from barn-laid eggs and to tell the Australian community why this interest was not disclosed in any of their publicity material and was not disclosed in all of the talkback radio interviews they have done over the last week. There is no doubt that the RSPCA is a credible community organisation with a very important role to play in the welfare of animals. But on this occasion it has just a few too many golden eggs in one basket and it has, at the least, been very tardy in its public disclosure.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak on the situation at the Gordonstone mine in Queensland where the illegal sacking of 312 miners in October 1997 has resulted in a 16-month picket line which has now been maintained longer than any other in Australian coalmining history. The company which carried out the sackings, Arco, sold out to Rio Tinto late last year; now this company has continued along the same path. Picketers have clashed with Rio Tinto during the last week as it has attempted to bus in non-union labour to replace the illegally sacked workers.

speech.para: The situation at Gordonstone must be seen as irrefutable evidence of this government's approach to industrial relations being not just unfair and unjust but downright underhanded. The original owners of Gordonstone, Arco, carried out an open campaign to de-unionise coal workers, which culminated in the sacking of the 312 workers.

In February 1988 the Australian Industrial Relations Commission found that the dismissals had been unfair and ordered the company to pay compensation and also instructed Arco to give preference to former workers in the recruiting of their new work force. They found that the company had deliberately set out on an anti-union tack and also that the company was motivated by a desire to avoid its obligations under an enterprise agreement which it had entered into in 1996. Arco continually refused to employ the workers they had sacked, despite the rulings of the AIRC. Having failed to de-unionise Gordonstone, they decided to sell to Rio Tinto.

Now Rio Tinto has stepped in where Arco left off. In December Rio Tinto commenced recruiting for the Gordonstone mine. The recruitment was carried out in secret and 23 hand-picked employees were engaged. The company, Mine Management, which recruited the work force, is a $2 shelf company which is a 100 per cent subsidiary of Rio Tinto. Some of those employed came from the Gordonstone management previously employed by Arco. These people accepted a non-union agreement that would cover all work at the mine by all employees for two years. The agreement overrides all existing obligations of any employer at the Gordonstone mine and was ratified on 2 February. The AIRC has no discretion when ratifying agreements under this government's legislation and union submissions were not allowed at the hearing.

Rio Tinto intends employing up to 200 workers under this certified agreement. No preference will be given to the former Gordonstone workers who were unlawfully dismissed by Arco. This government has therefore allowed these large multinationals to completely disregard and disrespect the authority of the AIRC. There seems to be absolutely no compulsion for these companies to abide by the commission's decisions, which is an utter disgrace.

The situation is made particularly ironic by the fact that the 312 workers that were sacked in 1997 were deemed to be among the most productive by international standards. Just months before the miners were illegally sacked, Arco had erected a statue to the Gordonstone work force describing them as `the best miners in the world' after they had broken a succession of international production records.

While the treatment of the Gordonstone miners has clearly been unfair from a vocational perspective, there are other aspects of the situation at Gordonstone that I find distinctly disturbing. This struggle has been maintained not just by workers but also by their families.

When I visited the area last year I saw significant evidence that Arco had been using intimidation and standover tactics to demoralise and upset miners and their families. Arco had employed a veritable private army of security guards to patrol the mine day and night. Furthermore, I heard other disturbing accounts of intimidation. The wives of several miners told me that they and their children had been intimidated on the streets of Emerald by members of Arco's private army. I am sure most people in our community would agree that the intimidation of women and children by multinational bullies should not be a part of the Australian approach to industrial relations. In fact, these actions are completely un-Australian. Is this the new flexible approach to industrial relations that the government wants us to embrace?

I have now been informed of several instances of violence by police against the passive demonstrators at Gordonstone in the past few days. Obviously, these people continue their struggle in relative isolation, with little sympathy from the government or law enforcement authorities. The waterfront scenes from last year are now being replicated at Gordonstone. Obviously, the federal government learned nothing from its conflict with the MUA last year and remains determined to crush the union movement in Australia, regardless of the implications for everyday Australians and their families. Is this the sort of industrial relations system we want to take with us into the new millennium? Is the bullying of women and children by multinational corporations acceptable behaviour in the 1990s?

It seems to me that, unless we act quickly, this government will turn the clock back to the 1900s and remove all the working standards and conditions that we have come to rely on in a civilised society. Perhaps computers are not the only ones confused by the millennium bug. Mr Howard does not seem to know which century he is in, either. The situation unfolding at Gordonstone can, therefore, be seen as a battle to defend the values and standards that prevail within the Australian community. The basic principles of justice, equity and democracy are now at stake and we must all rally to defend them.

Democracy demands that all Australians enjoy freedom of association. This government is trying to take those basic rights away from unionists by allowing their families to be bullied and intimidated by multinational corporations. They have, therefore, failed in their duty of care to the Australian people. The ALP supports the miners and their families at Gordonstone. After all, their struggle is merely to protect their jobs and provide a decent living for their children, which is every Australian's right. It has always been every Australian's right to belong to a union and to work for decent wages and conditions. We are, after all, living in a democracy.
