debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Isolated and Remote Students: Retention Rates
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 16)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, 23 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Does the Government agree that retention rates for isolated and remote students at 51 per cent and for boys at 44 per cent in Year 12 are unacceptably low.
(2) What are the social and economic implications of such low rates for these young people and the families and communities from which they come.

(3) Will the Government consider increasing the basic boarding allowance (BBA) of the Assistance for Isolated Children (AIC) scheme to its original intent of 55 per cent of the average boarding fee; if not, why not.
(4) Is the Government aware that the average boarding fee in 1997 was $6 783.
(5) Will the Government consider increasing the second home allowance of the AIC scheme to achieve parity with the BBA; if not, why not.

(6) Will the Government consider tapering the means tested additional boarding allowance of the AIC scheme up to the average boarding fee when the parents have nil or negative income with small increases applying as family incomes rise, as proposed by the Isolated Children's Parents' Association (ICPA); if not, why not.
(7) When will the Government adopt the recommendations of the ICPA to:
(a) recognise that families subject to an asset test for AUSTUDY should not also be subject to an assets test on their income earning assets;

(b) subject to appropriate substantiation, treat wages paid to students from their family's company, partnership or trust in the same way as earnings from an outside employer or sole trader partner; and
(c) provide adequately trained staff to assist people with queries surrounding the complexity of the AUSTUDY application form.
(8) Will the Government honour its 1996 election promise to raise the discount on farms and small business income earning assets from 50 per cent to 75 per cent; if not why not.
(9) Will the government consider introducing a geographically-isolated tertiary students scheme, as proposed by ICPA; if not why not.
(10) (a) Will the Government consider providing an allowance to isolated parents who educate some 3 300 children at home; and
(b) how much do these parents save State and federal governments by virtue of their supervisory role.
(11) Will the Government consider the proposal by ICPA to provide recurrent funding of $1 000 for each isolated student enrolled in government and non-government boarding schools.
(12) (a) What is the low fee regional boarding schools and school term hostels which have been closed in the past twelve months; and
(b) how many places have been lost to these closures.
(13) What are the implications for isolated and remote students of these closures.

talk.start.para: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

answer.para: (1) The figures quoted are not rates of retention of secondary students to Year 12, but estimated Year 12 completion rates for remote students in respect of 1996. They appear in the National Report on Schooling in Australia 1996. Completion rates express the number of Year 12 completions (that is, Year 12 certificates issued by State education authorities) as a proportion of the estimated population that could attend Year 12 in a particular calendar year.

It is true that completion rates for remote students are lower than students from both urban areas and non-remote rural areas, and that rates for boys are lower than for girls. The Government agrees that it is desirable for more students to complete Year 12.

(2) The Government acknowledges that there are established links between educational achievement and employment outcomes. The Commonwealth's concern for the education of students living in rural and remote areas of Australia is based on a need to ensure their equitable access to quality education which will assist them to achieve outcomes and participation rates at least equal to students in urban areas. To assist these students, the Government provides a number of programs that offer additional support and help. For example, the Commonwealth provides $17.7 million to State and Territory government and non government education authorities annually to help schools and students in rural and remote areas of Australia. The Country Areas Program assist parents, administrators, teachers and other members of the community to work cooperatively to improve the delivery of primary and secondary school educational services in rural and geographically isolated areas.

(3) The Government increased the basic boarding allowance from $2,500 to $2,900 in the 1996-97 Budget. This brought the basic boarding allowance up to 55% of the average boarding fee. The Government has undertaken to further increase the basic boarding allowance from $2,900 to $3,500 and index this amount in future years. It also undertook to increase the maximum amount that can be received under a combination of the basic boarding allowance and additional boarding allowance to $4,347.

(4) The Isolated Children's Parents' Association's (ICPA) method of deriving an average boarding fee is a simple average of fees charged by all boarding institutions and gives undue weight to the level of fees at expensive boarding schools which have relatively few AIC beneficiaries. The Department's calculations are derived from the fees charged by boarding institutions at which AIC recipients are actually enrolled and weighted accordingly.

(5) There is not necessarily a connection between the second home allowance and basic boarding allowance. The basic boarding allowance was increased in the 1996 Budget from $2 500 per year to $2 900 per year per student in line with the Government's specific 1996 election commitment to increase the basic boarding allowance to 55% of the average boarding allowance. No evidence has been presented of increased costs faced by recipients of the second home allowance. While the value of the basic boarding allowance and the second home allowance may previously have been aligned, the government's initial concern was to provide additional help to those families who needed to board their children in a non-family environment.

(6) Firstly, no family should receive more than their actual boarding fee outlay. Secondly, the ICPA proposal does not acknowledge that low income families have access to a higher level of Family Payment which may be used by families to meet boarding costs.

(7) (a) AUSTUDY was replaced on 1 July by the Youth Allowance for students under 25 years of age and AUSTUDY payment for those aged 25 and over. Both programs are the responsibility of the Minister for Family and Community Services. Means test rules remain in general the same, with the exception that students classed as independent are no longer subject to an actual means test. The ICPA proposes that families applying for student assistance should not be subject to an assets test on their income earning assets. As with AUSTUDY, only fifty per cent of the net value of income earning assets that are also business assets is taken into account under the Youth Allowance family assets test. The assets test is complemented by the Family Actual Means Test (FAMT), which is a test of expenditure and savings. Expenditure that was tax deductible in the previous financial year because it was necessarily incurred in carrying on a business is excluded from the FAMT.

(7) (b) Under the Youth Allowance Family Actual Means Test up to $6,000 of income earned from independent employment by students in a family aged 16 and over may be excluded. "Independent employment" is employment engaged in by a person that is not provided by a member of the person's family or by a proprietary company, an unlisted public company, a partnership or trust in which the person, or a member of the person's family, has an interest.

The exclusion relates to income from independent employment because the Government is concerned to ensure that only bona fide income earning activities are recognised. The Government considered that, to maintain the integrity of the FAMT, income earned should be restricted to employment outside family business structures.

(7) (c) The matter of providing Centrelink staff to assist people to complete student assistance claim forms on a question by question basis is one that should be taken up with Centrelink. Centrelink staff are trained in all aspects of Youth Allowance administration including, of course, the Family Actual Means Test.

(8) Prior to the 1996 election the Coalition made an undertaking to consider raising the AUSTUDY assets test discount for farm and other business assets to 75%. Given the high cost of implementing this measure (estimated at some $18.5 million in a full year) and the fiscal restraints faced after the election, the Government was unable proceed with this undertaking. The Government was concerned also about making AUSTUDY and more recently Youth Allowance available to families with unencumbered business assets of up to $1.63 million, at a time when public expenditure is under close scrutiny.

The value of the family residence and up to two hectares of surrounding land is exempt from the Youth Allowance assets test. A 50% discount is available on the value of farm and other business assets, which means that in 1998, children become ineligible for Youth Allowance under the assets test only when the family has unencumbered assets of the value of $814,500 or more.

Since 1 July 1998, when the main form of financial assistance to full time students became the Youth Allowance for students between the ages of 16 and 24 and the new Austudy payment for students 25 and over, policy responsibility for these schemes has rested with the Minister for Social Security. The Youth Allowance and the Austudy payment have retained the range of concessions available to rural students under AUSTUDY, including the concessions for farming families suffering drought or other exceptional circumstances, and those for families with two or more tertiary students living away from home to study.

(9) These issues were considered in the development of the Youth Allowance. The Government considered that access to post-secondary education, even for students living in non-isolated areas, often involves living away from home. Under the Youth Allowance eligible students who have to live away from home may be entitled to rent assistance.
(10) Introduction of an allowance to isolated parents would have considerable cost implications and need to be considered by the Government in the Budget context.

While State and Territory governments have the primary role in the provision of education to school aged children, the Commonwealth assists geographically isolated families with students studying by distance education through the payment of the AIC distance education allowance. This allowance is intended to contribute toward incidental costs associated with distance education study. In the 1996 Budget, the Government announced a substantial increase to the Correspondence Allowance from 1997 and specific funding to State and Territory Governments for the purposes of extending services to rural and remote schools, as well as for technological innovations in distance education delivery. These initiatives are viewed as the fairest and most efficient means of addressing the educational needs of geographically isolated students.

The Commonwealth provides general recurrent funding for government school systems and non-government schools and systems. Non-government schools are funded on a needs basis and placed in one of 12 funding categories. Given these differential rates of funding, and as it is not possible to identify which schools the students schooled at home could attend, it is not possible to determine the saving to the Commonwealth where students are supervised and schooled at home by their parents.

(11) Consideration of this proposal would need to be in the Budget context. It should be noted that hostels which provide accommodation for government and non-government students are eligible, under the Commonwealth Capital Grants Program, for grants from the Government Component and Non-Government Component respectively of the Program.

Through its Schools Programs the Commonwealth provides recurrent funding for schools. Where boarding facilities are part of the school (ie. it is a boarding school) the assessment of the school's funding category through the Education Resources Index (ERI) takes boarding school costs into account. However, no ongoing recurrent funding is available for private hostels or other boarding arrangements.

The Commonwealth, through its General Recurrent Grants Program for schools, provides per capita assistance for government and non-government schools in respect of students attending those schools. This per capita funding assists schools with the recurrent costs of schooling like teaching and ancillary staff salaries, professional development of teachers, curriculum development, and school maintenance and general operation provisions. The current legislation governing the General Recurrent Grants Program does not envisage per capita payments to assist particular students with the costs of their schooling.

(12) The Department is aware of one non-government school approved for Commonwealth general recurrent grant funding that provided boarding facilities and which was located in a regional area outside the capital cities and other metropolitan centres, which closed in 1997. That school, which attracted funding at the category 9 level, reported 23 boarding students as at the 1997 schools census day. The Department does not maintain a specific, regular data collection in relation to low fee regional school term hostel closures and the number of places lost to these closures in the past twelve months.

(13) There are a number of schools offering boarding facilities in the area in which the closed school operated. These schools attract a comparable level of Commonwealth recurrent funding to that of the closed school. It would therefore be possible for students requiring boarding facilities to transfer to a similar environment. In line with its election commitment, the Government is providing short-term emergency funding to particular school term hostels in serious financial difficulty, while the Commonwealth sits down with the States to agree upon a significant long-term sustainable package for this sector.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Tax Office: Individual Taxpayer Audits
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 157)

talk.start.para: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 November 1998:

question.para: (1) How many audits have been undertaken by the Australian Tax Office (ATO) of individual taxpayers for the 1996-97 financial year with particular reference to: (a) the income matching system and the number of audits that identified errors relating to interest, dividends and rebates; (b) the number of ATO audits conducted on tax agents practices in relation to individual taxpayers work related expenses; (c) the number of desk audits related to taxpayer claims for car, home office, self education and superannuation claims; and (d) the number of audits that can be classified as `real time audits' as a result of ATO identification of excessive expenditure claims and what were those groups of expenditure that were targeted for real time auditing.

(2) With reference to part 1 of the question, can information be provided in regard to the individual audits, namely; (a) how many returns subsequently amended as a result of the ATO audit; (b) what was the additional tax collected as a result of the ATO audits; (c) what was the initial amount of tax and what was the subsequent amount of tax; (d) what was the total amount of penalties imposed; (e) what was the error rate in percentage terms; and (f) what was the average amount of tax and penalty per audit case.
(3) Was $2 million per year for 3 years allocated to the test case litigation program (TCLP) up to and including 30 June 1998.
(4) Was only $10 616 spent in the 1995-96 financial year.
(5) How many requests were made in the 1995-96 financial year for funding to be made available under TCLP by: (a) accountants; and (b) taxpayers.
(6) For the 1996-97 financial year can it be confirmed that only $235 668 was spent under the TCLP.
(7) How many requests did the First Assistant Secretary in charge of TCLP receive from accountants and taxpayers in the 1996-97 financial year for funding under the TCLP.
(8) Does the Minister consider the TCLP to be a success when less than 2 per cent of $4 million over 2 years has been allocated to resolve taxpayer issues.
(9) How much was allocated under the TCLP for the 1997-98 financial year including the latest available figures.
(10) (a) Will the Government be extending the TCLP for another 3 years; if so, what will be the funding per year; if not, why not.

(11) With reference to the test case to be run on sunhats, sunscreen and sunglasses as initially confirmed by the Commissioner in 1996: (a) can it be explained whether the objections presented to the First Assistant Commissioner have been processed as June 1998; if not, why not; and (b) when will they be processed.
(12) When does the Commissioner intend this case to be presented before the Federal Court.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The question refers to the 1996-97 financial year. Due to the timing of the receipt of information from external organisations and the complexity of the required matching processes, discrepancies relating to the 1995-96 financial year were reviewed during the year ended 30 June 1998. Information relating to Interest & Dividends and Rebates—refers to the 1995-96 financial year.
The number of audits undertaken in the 1995-96 financial is as follows:
Interest & Dividends—103,428; Rebates—3,742.

(1) (b) There were 33,474 audits conducted, of these 21,261 cases required taxpayers to complete a questionnaire in the first instance. A number of these cases were then escalated to full substantiation audits depending on the details provided.
(1) (c) see table

(1) (d) It is uncertain what is meant by "real time audits". 7857 computer system checks were generated at the time returns were being processed. These cases identified potentially incorrect claims for family tax assistance, spouse and sole parent rebates.
(2) (a) (b) see table
(2) (c) The initial and subsequent amounts of tax are not available.
(2) (d) (e) (f) see table

(2) (e) See table**. The relationship between cases reviewed/audited and cases adjusted is often misinterpreted by extrapolating the rate to the wider community. This relationship needs to be viewed in the context of the type of audit or review program undertaken. For example, in relation to interest, dividends and rebates because cases are selected for review on the basis of information supplied by external institutions and then matched against information contained in tax returns, it is almost certain that errors have been made by taxpayers identified by this process, thus a high adjustment rate. On the other hand, in relation to work related expenses because most taxpayers were advised prior to lodging their tax returns of our intention to review their claims, more care was taken in preparing their returns and less errors were made.

entry.para: (2)(f) Average tax and penalty per productive case
not available (total value of adjustments was $113,158)

answer.para: Note—Superannuation `audits' were in fact computer generated checks at the time tax returns were being processed. Other such checks are included at (1)(d)
(3) Provision was included in the 1995-96 Budget for expenditure of up to $2M per year for 1995-96 and each of the next two years for the purposes of a TCLP for taxation cases.

(4) The program got under way in the second half of 1995-96. Due to the lead time necessarily involved in litigation cases only one case reached the stage where a payment was required. The amount paid in that case was $10,616. A further $636,184 was committed to ongoing cases as at 30 June 1996.
(5) (a) Two requests were received on behalf of taxpayers and there were five cases where litigation funding was offered under the program at the initiative of the Commissioner of Taxation.
(5) (b) Various suggestions were received from members of the public as to issues that might make suitable test case issues in the future.
(6) It is confirmed that an amount of $235,668 was spent on funding test cases in 1996-97. A further $640,000 was committed to ongoing cases as at 30 June 1997.

(7) Applications for funding under the ATO Test Case Program are generally made by a solicitor representing the taxpayer in a litigation case. Applications are sometimes made by taxpayers or other taxpayer representatives. Some funding offers are initiated by the ATO where there is an important issue in a case and, for various reasons, no funding application has been made by the taxpayer in the case. Thirty one funding proposals in total from these sources were processed in 1996-97.

(8) The ATO Test Case Program will be evaluated on the extent to which it meets intended outcomes rather than the extent to which available funds are expended. An evaluation report of the first 3 years of the program is required to be completed during the 1998/99 financial year.
(9) A total of $333,889 was spent during the year and a further $374,110.90 was committed to cases as at 30 June 1998.
(10) Yes, subject to the outcome of the program evaluation the program is to be extended a further 3 years. Up to $2M will be available each year for suitable cases.

(11) (a) No objections have been lodged. A number of draft private rulings requests have been forwarded to the ATO for consideration as suitable binding private ruling requests to be lodged by taxpayers identified by the NSW Cancer Council. These rulings requests will establish the basis of a series of test cases on the issues.

(11) (b) The ATO is working with the NSW Cancer Council to finalise the identification and details of the representative cases. This aspect of the work will be completed in September 1998. It is expected that objections and appeals will be lodged subsequently. This process will take a further 2 to 3 months.
(12) The issue will come before the Federal Court on completion of the processes referred to in the answer to the previous question.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 12 November 1998:

question.para: Has an investigating accountant's report been prepared for the further sale of Telstra; if so, can a copy of the report be provided; if such a report has not been prepared, when will the report by produced.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: An investigating accountant's report has not yet been prepared for the further sale of Telstra. To have done so would have been premature and therefore not cost effective.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 23 November 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) How many applications for child disability allowance (CDA) were received for children with diabetes for the periods, July-October 1997, March-June 1998 and July-October 1998; and (b) for each period, how many of these applications were:(i) successful, (ii) unsuccessful.
(2) Are the new assessment criteria intended to prevent children with diabetes (or other `hidden' conditions like asthma and attention deficit disorder) from being eligible for CDA.
(3) (a) Are the new assessment criteria preventing children with diabetes from qualifying for CDA; and (b) what is the evidence on which this conclusion is based.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The recording of information on CDA applications by disability type only commenced with the introduction of new CDA rules on 1 July 1998. It is not yet possible to provide reliable information by specific disability group. I have asked my Department to examine how reliable data by disability type can be obtained as soon as possible.
(2) There was no intention in the design and development of the Child Disability Assessment Tool (CDAT) to exclude children with any particular medical condition or disability.

The aim of new arrangements for the CDA program is to ensure that the program is targeted to families in the greatest need. The Child Disability Assessment Tool (CDAT), introduced for all new claims lodged on or after 1 July 1998, assesses the level of severity of a child's disability by looking at whether the child functions according to standards appropriate to his or her age. The child's actual ability is measured against the standard for his or her age in a series of functional categories comprising language skills, self-care skills, social and community skills, fine motor skills and gross motor skills. In addition, the child's behaviour is taken into account where it is significantly affected by the disability, along with any special care needs.

(3) (a) and (b) There is no evidence at present to indicate how the new assessment arrangements are affecting grants of CDA to children with diabetes. I have asked my Department to consider this issue as part of its current review of these arrangements. The results of this review should be available in the second half of 1999.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, the Information Technology and the Arts the following, upon notice, on 23 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of the level of dissatisfaction amongst Telstra business sales consultants in Sydney, and that this dissatisfaction relates to their claim that the positions advertised by Telstra in January 1998 turned out to be different once the successful applicants began working for Telstra.
(2) Did Telstra, in the Sydney Morning Herald, advertised a base salary plus incentive and superannuation of $36000 on 21 January 1998.
(3) Does a discrepancy exist between the conditions advertised and those experienced by these Telstra business sales consultants.

(4) Is the Minister aware that the written offer made by Telstra to these employees was made up of a base remuneration of $24,244 and a company superannuation contribution of $4,278, a total of $28,522.
(5) Can an explanation be given of the difference between the advertised amount of $36,000 and Telstra's written `remuneration summary (Attachment B)' which shows a base salary of $28,522.

(6) Is the Minister aware that Telstra employees were advised via `remuneration summary (Attachment B)' that the difference was made up of an `on target commission' of $8,557 making a total of $37,079.
(7) Does the Minister agree that these Telstra employees have a legitimate complaint that Telstra's package as detailed in (4) and (6) above does not correspond with the advertised salary package.

(8) Is it a fact that the Australian Workplace Agreement (AWA) drawn up by Telstra and presented to new employees for signature was not submitted to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission; if so, why does Telstra not comply with the Federal Government's industrial relations legislation.
(9) Has the Minister been supplied with any information about these problems; if not, will a briefing on this issue be sought and will the Senate be advised.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telstra, is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Telstra has advised that it is unaware of any general level of dissatisfaction amongst Business Sales Consultants in Sydney. Telstra also advises that, there has been one isolated case of a former staff member who expressed dissatisfaction with his contract with Telstra. Telstra maintains that the conditions of employment as advertised were identical to the actual conditions applying to the applicants during subsequent employment.
(2) Yes. Telstra advises that the advertisement in the Sydney Morning Herald stated:
"The Rewards
Telstra offers a remuneration package consisting of base salary, incentive and superannuation commencing at $36,000 per annum depending on skills and experience".
Telstra further advises that successful applicants were also sent a letter before commencing that explained that 30 per cent of their package was commission based.

(3) Telstra advises that it believes that no discrepancy exists between the advertised conditions and those experienced by the successful applicants on taking up employment. Telstra has emphasised that the total package available to employees was higher than $36,000.
(4) Telstra advises that full details of the package as communicated to employees was:
Total package—$37,079.
Commission—$8,557; Total Employment Cost—$28,522; Super 5% of TEC—$4,278; Base—$24,244.

(5) See answer to Question (4). Telstra advises that differing terminology—"incentive" or "commission"- has been used to describe the payment to employees based on sales performance, with the amount being a percentage of Total Employment Cost.

(6) Telstra advises that individuals were advised prior to commencement of employment that the roles were sales based and there was a commission structure. Telstra further advises that the letter of offer clearly states a 70/30 package would be offered. The jobs were advertised as sales roles and as such are sales dependent. Telstra also advises that this was communicated at the initial interviews by the Business Sales Consultants Manager.

(7) Telstra considers that applicants were fully advised of the conditions of employment prior to commencement and that such conditions were in line with the information contained in the advertisement in the Sydney Morning Herald.
(8) Under the provisions of the Workplace Relations Act 1996, Telstra must submit AWAs to the Office of the Employment Advocate, not the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

Regrettably, an error in the processing of contracts by Telstra led to the AWAs not being submitted to the Employment Advocate as required under the Workplace Relations Act. Telstra advises that all AWAs were consequently withdrawn and re-submitted. There was no disadvantage to any employee as a result of this process.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 7 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the Coalition Government, in a document, Communications: Making Australia stronger, indicate on page 12 that the Coalition intends to legislate to authorise the sale of Telstra in two or more stages.

(2) Did the document state the Coalition would seek to sell a further 16 per cent of Telstra to take the proportion of Telstra in private ownership to 49 per cent: if so, why does the proportion of Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 state that the Commonwealth may sell 49.9 per cent of its original equity interest in Telstra.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Coalition election document Communications: making Australia stronger stated—"The Coalition will legislate to authorise the sale of Telstra in two or more stages".

(2) Communications: making Australia stronger also stated—"In the first stage, the Coalition will seek to sell a further 16 per cent of Telstra to take the proportion of Telstra in private ownership to 49 per cent. The legislation will provide that the first stage may not occur until the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Act is in place" .

The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 allows the Commonwealth, after Royal Assent, to sell 49.9% of its original equity interest in Telstra, provided it retains a 50.1% equity interest in Telstra.

This legislation reflects the essential element of the Government's commitment to retain majority ownership on the first stage of the sale until an independent inquiry has certified that Telstra's service levels to customers in metropolitan, rural and remote areas are adequate, measured against specified performance criteria.

The Government is expressing precisely in the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 the percentage of the Commonwealth's equity in Telstra which can be sold whilst requiring it to retain majority ownership.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 7 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Can a full account be given as to the current status of the pensioner education supplement.
(2) Will recipients of this program lose the retraining allowance under the proposed goods and services tax.

(3) (a) Is an evaluation currently being conducted as to the efficacy of this program: if so, who is conducting this evaluation, and what are the terms of reference; and (b)when is such an evaluation taking place and can details be provided.
(4) If this program is to be scrapped are there any plans to replace it with another scheme; if so, can details be provided of such plans.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Certain social security and Veterans' Affairs pensioners who are studying may be eligible for a Pensioner Education Supplement (PES). PES is payable to both full-time students and part-time students studying at least 25% of a full-time study load.

Policy responsibility for the AUSTUDY component of PES was transferred from the former Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (now the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DETYA)) to the former Department of Social Security (now the Department of Family and Community Services (DFaCS)) on 1 July 1998. However, responsibility for the ABSTUDY component of PES, which is paid to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students, is retained by DETYA.

(2) There is no "retraining allowance" specifically associated with the PES payment. The rate of PES is to be increased by 4% under the compensation provisions associated with the introduction of the Goods and Services Tax.
(3) DFaCS is currently conducting an evaluation of the AUSTUDY PES scheme.
The terms of reference for the PES evaluation are to examine the objectives of the program and whether the payment is achieving its objectives in the most effective and efficient way.

Key components of the PES evaluation comprise focus groups with PES customers, as well as a national telephone survey of 3,000 customers conducted by a consultant (Rush Social Research Agency). The focus groups with PES customers were completed in September 1998, while the customer telephone survey was undertaken in November and December.
DFaCS anticipates that the evaluation should be finalised by the end of February 1999.

As DETYA retains policy responsibility for the ABSTUDY component of PES, the role of ABSTUDY PES has been examined separately. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, the Hon Dr David Kemp MP, issued a Media Release on 15 December 1998, which stated that from 1 January 2000, ABSTUDY PES will be fully aligned with AUSTUDY PES available under the Social Security Act 1991.
(4) Any decisions regarding the future of the AUSTUDY PES scheme will be made by the Government subsequent to the completion of the PES evaluation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Will the proposed changes to fringe benefits tax (FBT) apply to benefits provided by deceased estates, child maintenance trusts and/or section 102AG trusts.

(2) Will an interest free loan taken from a trust by a beneficiary or by a shareholder from a company, entered into before 1 April 2000, be subject to FBT after 1 April 2000 or will the proposed FBT changes only apply to such loans entered into after 1 April 2000.

(3) (a) Where an employer is required to include on an employee's group certificate a fringe benefit amount for the financial year ending 30 June 2000 and an error is made, will the employee be penalised for any tax shortfall that may arise as a result of the employer incorrectly calculating the grossed up taxable value; and (b) who will be responsible for this tax shortfall, the employee or the employer.

(4) (a) How will employers value the fringe benefit attributable to individual employees who have access to pooled motor vehicles provided by the employer for the use of its employees; and (b) what will be the individual value to be recorded on the group certificate.
(5) What treatment will apply to exempt benefits provided to employees that have to be included on an employee's group certificate such as lap-top computers, Christmas gifts or mobile phones.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) One of the FBT reform measures announced in A New Tax System involves extending FBT to benefits provided by companies to shareholders (in respect of their shareholding) and by trusts to beneficiaries (in respect of the trust relationship) from the 2000-01 FBT year. As a guiding principle, FBT will not apply where the benefit is taxed under the Income Tax Assessment Act or is a return of contributed capital. In light of the proposal in A New Tax System to tax trusts like companies apart from certain excluded trusts, the income tax treatment of the types of trusts referred to in the question is a matter for consideration by the Review of Business Taxation which is being chaired by Mr John Ralph, A.O.

(2) As noted, as a guiding principle FBT will not apply where a benefit is taxed under the Income Tax Assessment Act (ITAA). Non-commercial loans made to private company shareholders are currently taxable under the ITAA and would therefore not be subject to FBT under the proposed reforms. A New Tax System announced that provisions covering private company loans to shareholders would be extended to discretionary trusts and closely held fixed trusts. Consultation on this measure is being conducted through the Review of Business Taxation.

(3) (a) To attract the penalty provisions of the income tax law, a tax shortfall must arise because the taxpayer deliberately entered into a scheme to avoid tax, had failed to exercise reasonable care, was reckless, or had intentional disregard of the income tax law.

Therefore, unless an employee and their employer entered into an agreement to deliberately understate the reportable fringe benefits amount, or the employee ought reasonably have known that the fringe benefits amount was understated, no penalty would generally arise to the employee.

Where an assessment is amended, increasing the amount of tax payable, the employee would be liable for an interest penalty. There may be special circumstances where the Commissioner remits this amount.

For superannuation surcharge and termination payments surcharge purposes, an incorrect reportable fringe benefits amount shown on an employee's group certificate would not result in a penalty to the employee. Rather the surcharge liability in relation to the employee's contributions may be increased by virtue of an amended assessment, and interest would be payable on any increased liability. There is a provision that allows the Commissioner to remit the whole or part of an interest charge.
(3) (b) Subject to the above comments, the employee will be liable for any tax shortfall.

(4) (a) and (b) Where a fringe benefit or class of benefit is provided to two or more employees, the employee's share of the benefit will be the portion of the taxable value that reasonably reflects the amount of benefit received by each employee. The employer must take all relevant matters into consideration when apportioning the taxable value of a benefit and the apportionment must be justifiable.
(5) Exempt benefits such as lap-top computers, mobile phones for predominantly business use and minor benefits of less than $100 will not have to be reported on group certificates.
